The Niagara Falls location will no longer operate on weekends. New hours will be Monday to Friday 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. Welland’s assessment centre is cutting back to Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Hours at the St. Catharines assessment centre remain the same 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. seven days a week. COVID-19 testing at these centres, which are run by Niagara Health, are by-appointment only. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Home Page News Story Part of WB Highway 403 closed News Ontario PSW Association issues a statement following TikTok video backlash Local News Burlington mayor to recommend renaming Ryerson Park Canada News WATCH LIVE: Prime Minister Trudeau to provide COVID-19 update at 11:15… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Local News Burlington mayor to recommend renaming Ryerson Park News Local News Burlington mayor to recommend renaming Ryerson Park By Andrea Lawson - June 18, 2021, 12:21 pm Burlington Mayor Marianne Meed Ward will recommend renaming Ryerson Park next month. On Wednesday, Halton District School Board trustees approved a motion to change the name of Ryerson Public School, which is located beside the Burlington park. Part of that motion included sending a letter to the mayor informing her of the name change. “I support the change the HDSB is making and the reasons behind it,” said a statement from Meed Ward. “As part of our continued commitment to equity, diversity and inclusion, I am working with City of Burlington staff to bring forward a report to Committee and City Council in July 2021 recommending removing the Ryerson name from our park and embarking on the council-approved naming process.” The renaming process is expected to be complete by November 2021, the same time-frame as the school renaming. “Our Indigenous community needs to enjoy our parks and public spaces without a reminder of one of the architects of the Residential School system and the legacy of harm it created for their people,” said Meed Ward. “Renaming our city park is one step we can take toward reconciliation with our Indigenous residents.” TAGS burlington halton region marianne meed ward ryerson park ryerson public school Share Facebook Twitter Pinterest Linkedin Email Print Previous articlePandemic update Next articleCanada’s lunar mission Andrea Lawson RELATED ARTICLESMORE FROM AUTHOR Home Page News Story Part of WB Highway 403 closed News Ontario PSW Association issues a statement following TikTok video backlash Canada News WATCH LIVE: Prime Minister Trudeau to provide COVID-19 update at 11:15 a.m. Canada News U.S. border restrictions to remain in place until end of July: public safety minister News Ontario reports 345 COVID-19 cases, one death Local News Police release dash-cam video of driver nearly hitting a child in Thorold LEAVE A REPLY Cancel reply Please enter your comment! News Canada News Top News Story U.S. border restrictions to remain in place until end of July: public safety minister By Andrea Lawson - June 18, 2021, 10:53 am Travel restrictions at the Canada-U.S. border will remain in place for at least another month. Public Safety Minister Bill Blair says the American and Canadian governments are extending restrictions on non-essential international travel until July 21. As we have said, the government is planning measures for fully vaccinated Canadians, Permanent Residents, and others who are currently permitted to enter Canada and will provide further details on Monday, June 21. — Bill Blair (@BillBlair) June 18, 2021 He says the government will provide details on Monday about plans to let fully vaccinated Canadians and permanent residents enter the country. The measures at the border have been in place since the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic in March 2020. The pressure to relax the restrictions has been building from businesses on both sides of the border, and increasingly from American lawmakers as vaccination rates climb in Canada. RELATED STORY: Growing calls to reopen the Canada-U.S. border Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has previously said that it would take 75 per cent of Canadians getting vaccinated before restrictions can be lifted. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Home Page News Story Transport truck spills its load of steel pipe on highway 403 News Ontario PSW Association issues a statement following TikTok video backlash Local News Burlington mayor to recommend renaming Ryerson Park Canada News WATCH LIVE: Prime Minister Trudeau to provide COVID-19 update at 11:15… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Canada News Pfizer, Moderna vaccines now preferred second dose for AstraZeneca recipients: NACI News Canada News Top News Story Pfizer, Moderna vaccines now preferred second dose for AstraZeneca recipients: NACI By Andrea Lawson - June 18, 2021, 6:04 am The National Advisory Committee on Immunization is now recommending people who got the AstraZeneca vaccine first should get Pfizer-BioNTech or Moderna for their second shot. NACI had previously said AstraZeneca recipients could choose whether to get a second dose of the same vaccine, or an mRNA vaccine. But in new guidance released Thursday, NACI says Pfizer or Moderna are now “preferred” as the second dose. The advice doesn’t mean people can’t still choose AstraZeneca if they want, or if they are allergic to the mRNA vaccines. “People who received two doses of AstraZeneca/COVISHIELD vaccine can rest assured that the vaccine provides good protection against infection and very good protection against severe disease and hospitalization,” says NACI. As of June 5, 2.1 million Canadians had received one dose of AstraZeneca, and 15,186 had received two doses. There are no further shipments of AstraZeneca scheduled, but there are still about half a million doses of it in provinces. Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 20.9 C Hamilton Friday, June 18, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Ontario cabinet shuffle Local News Food prices continue to rise Local News McMaster conducts nuclear radiological exercise to test emergency response Home Page News Story Transport truck spills its load of steel pipe on highway 403 WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Evening News Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen News Evening News Local News Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen By Laura Brody - December 24, 2019, 4:59 pm Hamilton police have arrested a man in connection with a two-month long investigation into stolen, high-end bikes worth more than $40 000. Police say they executed a search warrant at a home in the east end last Thursday and found 26 mountain bikes, along with bike parts, high-end skis and prohibited weapons. They believe the bikes were stolen from residential and commercial properties in Ancaster, Aldershot and Dundas. They say most of the bikes had been taken apart and the parts had been swapped, to try to disguise them. So far, police have returned 3 of the 26 bikes to their owners, and hope to return the rest of them in the next two weeks. Jason Kane, 43, of Hamilton, is facing a number of charges including two counts of possession of a prohibited weapon, and three counts of possession of stolen property. Police say the investigation is ongoing and more charges could be laid. They recommend that you record the serial number on your bike, and call police if it’s been stolen. Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 20.9 C Hamilton Saturday, June 19, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Ontario cabinet shuffle Local News Food prices continue to rise Local News McMaster conducts nuclear radiological exercise to test emergency response Home Page News Story Transport truck spills its load of steel pipe on highway 403 WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Evening News Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed News Evening News Local News Hamilton Home Page News Story Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed By Laura Brody - October 21, 2019, 6:27 pm Hamilton police have identified the suspect in the city’s tenth homicide of the year, and have issued a warrant for his arrest. Twenty-nine year old Obsa Junedi Mohamed was gunned down outside of Boulevard Billiards on York Boulevard at around 1:30 Saturday morning. Police say his killer was his friend, 26-year-old Ibrahim Issak Hussen. The two men were hanging out with a group of other men for awhile before the shooting. About 10 minutes before the shooting detectives say Junedi Mohamed and Issak Hussen got into a physical altercation. Hussen goes by the street name “Seemo.” Junedi Mohamed’s street name was Nanny or Chappel. Detectives say Hussen shot Mohamed point blank in the head. The whole incident was caught on surveillance video. Surveillance images released in the media led to the driver of the getaway vehicle turning himself in to police on Saturday. That man was arrested for first degree murder and accessory after the fact to murder. Police say he participated in a lengthy interview and was released unconditionally later Saturday. But another man was also in the car and police want to speak to him. They are looking for an Asian male wearing a dark parka with fur trim on the hood. The victim was known to police. He was found by officers hiding after another shooting in the same area back in 2015. At the time he was charged with failing to comply and possession of cocaine. Issak Hussen is also known to police and investigators believe drugs are involved in this incident as well. News Evening News Local News Two Hamilton women were invited to meet Taylor Swift at the star’s Nashville mansion By Laura Brody - August 22, 2019, 5:23 pm Two young women from Hamilton were treated to an experience of a lifetime by their ultra-famous idol- Taylor Swift. The multi-grammy award winning pop star hand selected about 100 mega fans from around the world to attend a secret album preview party at her Nashville mansion and 25-year-old Nichole Ridehalgh and 17-year-old Isabella Rose both got a phone call from Swifts team. Ridehalgh was shocked when she called the call inviting her to a special event. She was asked if she could make it to Nashville in less than a week. Without being told, Ridehalgh knew she had just been invited to an event that is the pinnacle of every Taylor Swift fan’s dream- a secret session album preview at the star’s Nashville mansion. Swift has held secret sessions before the releases of several of her previous albums. Fans are picked up at a secret location and driven to her mansion. Those who attend are always mega fans who the star keeps a close eye on on social media. Getting a one on one chat with the star is something Ridehalgh will never forget. “Its 4:30 in the morning, I’m exhausted but, this is my moment. I walk into the room and I turn to my left and I see her and she says hey your Nichole right?Aand in that moment my whole world was made. Without me mentioning Canada at all, she said have a safe flight back to Canada” Swift even shared secret details about her personal life with fans. Isabella Rose is also on a first name basis with Swift. She posted on social media saying “I have loved her for nine years and I will never stop talking about how much I love her but I would not be where I am today without her.” Tonight is the release of Swift’s newest album, Lover. Ridehalgh and Rose were two of 113 fans in the world, that have already heard it. “She was lip syncing and dancing. She was just having a blast.” And that night is a night these young women will replay over and over again. Home News Local News Police release dash-cam video of driver nearly hitting a child in Thorold News Local News Top News Story Police release dash-cam video of driver nearly hitting a child in Thorold By Andrea Lawson - June 18, 2021, 7:53 am Niagara police have released video of a driver who almost hit a boy on a bike. It happened in Thorold in the area of Confederation Ave. and Richmond St. around 2 p.m. last Friday. Dash-cam video released by police shows the driver going through a stop sign and knocking an 11-year-old boy off his bicycle. The child was not hit. On June 11 at 2:11pm, in the area of Confederation Ave and Richmond St. in Thorold, an 11 year old male was riding his bike when a vehicle proceeded through the stop sign knocking the young male off of his bike. Anyone with information is asked to contact us or @niagaratips pic.twitter.com/7plgEOZZ5i — NRPS (@NiagRegPolice) June 17, 2021 Anyone with information is being asked to contact police. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Ontario cabinet shuffle Local News Food prices continue to rise Local News McMaster conducts nuclear radiological exercise to test emergency response Home Page News Story Transport truck spills its load of steel pipe on highway 403 WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Local News Ryerson Public School in Burlington to be renamed News Local News Ryerson Public School in Burlington to be renamed By Andrea Lawson - June 18, 2021, 7:16 am Halton District School Board trustees have voted to rename Ryerson Public School in Burlington. Wednesday’s motion to rename the school passed unanimously. According to the board, the process will begin in September and will be completed by the end of November. Until then, the school’s current sign will be covered. More details on the renaming process will be released in the fall. It’s the latest school to move away from the name Ryerson, following the discovery of children’s remains outside former residential schools. The school was named after Egerton Ryerson, who was instrumental in the creation of Canada’s residential school system. “As trustees, we need to lead by example and have the courage to approach these difficult conversations,” says board chair Andrea Grebenc. “The perspectives of the diverse communities of Halton must be valued and honoured. Indigenous students, staff and the broader community should be able to enter a school without being harmed by the HDSB upholding the name of a person that has contributed to genocide.” Earlier this month, trustees at the Hamilton public school board approved a motion to rename Ryerson Public School in Hamilton. READ MORE: Hamilton trustees vote to rename Ryerson Elementary School The Halton school board will also send a letter to Burlington Mayor Marianne Meed Ward informing her of the decision to change the name. The community park next to the school is also named Ryerson. News Local News Top News Story Father and son struck by driver in St. Catharines, father charged in stabbing: police By Andrea Lawson - June 18, 2021, 6:37 am A St. Catharines man has been charged after police say he stabbed a driver that struck him and his young son in St. Catharines. Emergency crews were called to the intersection of Ontario St. and Scott St. around 7:30 p.m. Thursday. Police say a 46-year-old man and his six-year-old son were in the crosswalk when they were struck by a driver in a pickup truck. The driver got out of the car and police say an “altercation” occurred and the driver was stabbed. Police say the 32-year-old man was taken to hospital with non-life threatening injuries. The father and son suffered minor injuries. Ryan Garrett, 45, has been charged with aggravated assault. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Ontario cabinet shuffle Local News Food prices continue to rise Local News McMaster conducts nuclear radiological exercise to test emergency response Home Page News Story Transport truck spills its load of steel pipe on highway 403 WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility Local News Halton Hamilton News Home Page News Story Ontario News Top News Story Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility By Sylvie Lendvay - May 10, 2021, 11:08 am The province says the eligibility to receive a COVID-19 vaccine will expand the week of May 10th to include people with “at-risk” health conditions, people who cannot work from home (Group 2), and people 40 and older. Starting Tuesday May 11 at 8 a.m, people with “at-risk” health conditions such as immune deficiencies, cancer, diabetes, and asthma will be able to book an appointment either through the provincial portal or their region’s website. Also Tuesday morning, people in Group 2 who cannot work from home including those who work in essential retail, courts and banks can book. Social workers, veterinarians and miners are also apart of the list that can be found here. Thursday May 13 at 8 a.m, people turning 40 in 2021 and older in non-hot spot communities can book a vaccine appointment at a mass immunization clinic. Halton Region has expanded its’ vaccination program to allow residents 16 and older who cannot work from home to book an appointment through the regions online portal. Halton residents 50 and older living in non-hot spot communities can also book. Wednesday May 12 eligibility opens to those 40 and older, Friday May 14 to those 30 and older, and by next week all Halton adults over the age of 16 will be eligible to book an appointment. Halton residents 16+ who cannot work from home can now book a COVID vaccine appointment… as well as anyone 50+. May 12 – 40+. May 14 – 30+. May 19 – 16+. They are following provincial criteria for expanding program based on risk… have enough supply to do it early. @CHCHNews pic.twitter.com/VYwEmaGKLO — Sylvie Lendvay (@sylvie_lendvay) May 10, 2021 Halton region says they are following provincial criteria for expanding eligibility based on who is most at risk, but they have enough supply to do it early. There are several pilot clinics across the province vaccinating residents 18 and older. Four pharmacies in Hamilton are approved to administer Moderna. Each location will receive about 150 shots a week. Adults 40 and older can still book an AstraZeneca vaccine at a participating pharmacy. All booking availability will depend on supply. Constable Frank Trasmundi with Halton Police says sometimes when people report their bicycle stolen, the owner won’t have the serial number. If that’s the case, police can’t return it or lay charges. He says downloading the app ‘529 Garage’ can help people file a report. “We will have picture of your bike, the serial number, and any distinguishing features so it will be easier for us to recover it if we find it.” says Trasmundi. Halton Police recovers 200 bikes per year on average. Only about 10-15 of them are returned. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Ontario cabinet shuffle Local News Food prices continue to rise Local News McMaster conducts nuclear radiological exercise to test emergency response Home Page News Story Transport truck spills its load of steel pipe on highway 403 WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton If you don’t live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor Local News Halton Main News Story News If you don’t live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor By Sylvie Lendvay - December 9, 2020, 10:11 am With cases on the rise in Halton Region, Burlington’s Mayor Marianne Meed Ward residents should be concerned. “The simplest message I could give to residents is this: If you don’t live with somebody, assume that they have COVID and conduct yourself accordingly.” Even with the temptation to gather this holiday season, she is urging residents to follow public health guidelines. “Our [Burlington] numbers are going up again, a little bit. There’s been a lot of talk about a vaccine coming; we know we’re getting that but that’s not the silver bullet. That’s not the only solution. We are going to continue, for at least a year, to need to be keeping physical distance, hand washing, wearing a mask when out in public. Those measures are going to be critically important throughout 2021.” Halton reported 92 new cases of COVID-19 Tuesday. St. Anne Catholic Elementary school in Burlington has had to close down one classroom after 4 cases were reported Tuesday night. There are currently active 14 outbreaks in Halton region. The region’s Medical Officer of Health says the region continues to see community transmission. She is asking residents to avoid carpooling, and having coffee and play dates. Local News Halton News Is Halton heading back to a modified Stage 2? By Laura Brody - October 23, 2020, 8:52 pm Premier Doug Ford is concerned about Halton region’s rising case numbers and says a decision will be made by Monday whether or not to send the region back to modified Stage 2. Halton region is approaching 2,000 total COVID-19 cases; half of which have been recorded in the last two months. “We’re going to have to discuss that over the weekend and we’ll have that answer on Monday. But folks in Halton, I know they’re doing a great job. It’s concerning right now. I’ve seen the numbers go up.” said Premier Doug Ford. “The premier has been terrific to work with throughout this. We recorded 16 new cases today. That’s like 1 in 35,000 people here. I think curves on small numbers are very unreliable ways to judge the future.” said Oakville Mayor Rob Burton. Oakville has already restricted indoor group fitness classes and team sports. The modified Stage 2 would prohibit indoor dining, and close gyms, fitness centres, cinemas and performance venues. The Niagara Falls location will no longer operate on weekends. New hours will be Monday to Friday 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. Welland’s assessment centre is cutting back to Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Hours at the St. Catharines assessment centre remain the same 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. seven days a week. COVID-19 testing at these centres, which are run by Niagara Health, are by-appointment only. Macdonald statue News Local News Petition calls for Hamilton to remove Sir John A. Macdonald statue By Andrea Lawson - June 25, 2021, 2:20 pm The Hamilton Centre for Civic Inclusion has started a petition to remove the statue of Sir John A. Macdonald from Gore Park. This latest push to remove the statue comes on the heels of the discovery of the remains of hundreds of children outside former residential schools in May and June. Other cities, including Kingston, have taken down memorials to Macdonald following these discoveries. Hamilton councillors are set to meet about the issue in July. Macdonald was Canada’s first prime minister and was key in the creation of the residential school system. “We stand in solidarity with all Indigenous community members who are re-traumatized each time they are forced to look upon the likeness of the perpetrators of these heinous crimes against them and their communities,” says the petition. “Welcoming and accepting societies do not commemorate and idolize individuals who have intentionally and unashamedly committed unspeakable atrocities.” WATCH: Protest calls for the removal of the Sir John A. Macdonald statue Indigenous community members held a protest in Gore Park on Sunday, calling for the statue to be taken down. News Canada News Top News Story Prime Minister Justin Trudeau says this Canada Day should be a time of reflection By Andrea Lawson - June 25, 2021, 12:58 pm Prime Minister Justin Trudeau says this Canada Day should be a day to reflect on the country’s history. His comments come after a First Nation in Saskatchewan announced ground-penetrating radar had detected what are believed to be 751 unmarked graves at the site of a former residential school. READ MORE: 751 unmarked graves discovered at former residential school in Saskatchewan Trudeau says he spoke to Cowessess First Nation Chief Cadmus Delorme about the discovery, as well as Assembly of First Nations National Chief Perry Bellegarde. Indigenous communities across the country and many Canadians have been sharing their grief about the deaths of children who attended these schools, since an unmarked burial site was found in British Colubia in late May. Since then, some cities have decided to forgo parts of their usual Canada Day festivities. Trudeau says we all need to work hard to get to the point where everyone across this country can celebrate fully. Conservative Leader Erin O’Toole has said he believes Canada Day shouldn’t be cancelled and the tragedies of the past should be used as motivation to build a better country. News Top News Story World News Death toll in Florida collapse rises to four, 159 people still unaccounted for By Andrea Lawson - June 25, 2021, 11:26 am Officials say four people are dead and 159 are unaccounted for after the partial collapse of a beachside building in Florida. Global Affairs Canada says they have received information suggesting Canadian citizens may be affected. .@CHCHTV @CHCHNews International Affairs tells me that the Surfside condo collapse may have involved Canadians. “We have received preliminary reports indicating that Canadian citizens may be affected. No further information is available at this time.” #surfside — Phil Perkins (@PhilPerkinsCHCH) June 25, 2021 Search and rescue teams are trying to detect any sounds coming from survivors of the collapse. Miami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava says it’s “incredibly motivating” to watch the search and rescue teams risking their lives to find victims. Crews have heard some tapping and other noises, but officials emphasized that the rescuers don’t know whether the sounds are human-made or just caused by the settling of rubble. They have been removing debris using heavy cranes. At the same time, firefighters are tunneling from below to search for pockets in the rubble. They could not confirm the bodies discovered were all children “This could be triggering for many…we always knew there were graves here.” Chief Cadmus Delorme said headstones were once there, but they were removed by the Catholic church and never put back. The Cowessess First Nation says they are treating it as a crime scene. The discovery comes less than a month after 215 bodies were found on the site of a former residential school in Kamloops, B.C. Radar searches continue around each residential school in Canada. This time in Saskatchewan. The Cowessess first nation says they have uncovered the “horrific and shocking discovery of hundreds of unmarked graves” at the site of the former Marieval Indian residential school. The Cowessess first nation is expected to make an official announcement and provide more details on the discovery tomorrow. Renew relationship with Indigenous Peoples without cancelling Canada: O'Toole - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 21.6 C Hamilton Friday, June 25, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Petition calls for Hamilton to remove Sir John A. Macdonald statue Local News Hamilton police conducting sudden death investigation Canada News Prime Minister Justin Trudeau says this Canada Day should be a… News Death toll in Florida collapse rises to four, 159 people still… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Canada News Renew relationship with Indigenous Peoples without cancelling Canada: O’Toole News Canada News Renew relationship with Indigenous Peoples without cancelling Canada: O’Toole By Andrea Lawson - June 23, 2021, 12:50 pm Conservative Leader Erin O’Toole says he’s committed to a renewed relationship with Indigenous People, while speaking out against calls to cancel Canada Day celebrations. The Conservative caucus met Wednesday morning in advance of the House of Commons rising for its summer break. O’Toole called the discovery of the remains of 215 Indigenous children at a former B.C. residential school a “necessary awakening for our country.” READ MORE: Nationwide shock after remains of 215 children discovered at former residential school But added that the road to repairing that relationship doesn’t involve attempts to destroy Canada and spoke out against calls from some to cancel Canada Day celebrations. “I’m concerned that injustices in our past, or in our present, are too often seized upon by a small group of activist voices who use it to attack the very idea of Canada itself,” he said. Like other federal party leaders, O’Toole has had to respond to the discovery of the remains and demands for the government to make better progress on calls to action from the Truth and Reconciliation Commission. The Grace Anglican Church started the planning process on the centre four years ago. They are calling it “Bobby’s Place”, named after local Bobby Smylie who died from the flu in 2018 at the age of 10. The church says the centre will provide a meeting space to learn, socialize, and grow. Construction on “Bobby’s Place” will begin in a few weeks and they hope to have it finished by the Fall. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Hamilton Crews on cargo ships say they’re having trouble getting vaccinated Canada & The World Fourth wave of COVID-19 may still be on the horizon this… Canada & The World Derek Chauvin sentenced to 22.5 years in prison for the death… Hamilton Several people accidentally given the wrong vaccine dose at a Hamilton… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Evening News Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen News Evening News Local News Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen By Laura Brody - December 24, 2019, 4:59 pm Hamilton police have arrested a man in connection with a two-month long investigation into stolen, high-end bikes worth more than $40 000. Police say they executed a search warrant at a home in the east end last Thursday and found 26 mountain bikes, along with bike parts, high-end skis and prohibited weapons. They believe the bikes were stolen from residential and commercial properties in Ancaster, Aldershot and Dundas. They say most of the bikes had been taken apart and the parts had been swapped, to try to disguise them. So far, police have returned 3 of the 26 bikes to their owners, and hope to return the rest of them in the next two weeks. Jason Kane, 43, of Hamilton, is facing a number of charges including two counts of possession of a prohibited weapon, and three counts of possession of stolen property. Police say the investigation is ongoing and more charges could be laid. They recommend that you record the serial number on your bike, and call police if it’s been stolen. Macdonald statue Local News Hamilton police conducting sudden death investigation Canada News Prime Minister Justin Trudeau says this Canada Day should be a… News Death toll in Florida collapse rises to four, 159 people still… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Evening News Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed News Evening News Local News Hamilton Home Page News Story Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed By Laura Brody - October 21, 2019, 6:27 pm Hamilton police have identified the suspect in the city’s tenth homicide of the year, and have issued a warrant for his arrest. Twenty-nine year old Obsa Junedi Mohamed was gunned down outside of Boulevard Billiards on York Boulevard at around 1:30 Saturday morning. Police say his killer was his friend, 26-year-old Ibrahim Issak Hussen. The two men were hanging out with a group of other men for awhile before the shooting. About 10 minutes before the shooting detectives say Junedi Mohamed and Issak Hussen got into a physical altercation. Hussen goes by the street name “Seemo.” Junedi Mohamed’s street name was Nanny or Chappel. Detectives say Hussen shot Mohamed point blank in the head. The whole incident was caught on surveillance video. Surveillance images released in the media led to the driver of the getaway vehicle turning himself in to police on Saturday. That man was arrested for first degree murder and accessory after the fact to murder. Police say he participated in a lengthy interview and was released unconditionally later Saturday. But another man was also in the car and police want to speak to him. They are looking for an Asian male wearing a dark parka with fur trim on the hood. The victim was known to police. He was found by officers hiding after another shooting in the same area back in 2015. At the time he was charged with failing to comply and possession of cocaine. Issak Hussen is also known to police and investigators believe drugs are involved in this incident as well. News Evening News Local News Two Hamilton women were invited to meet Taylor Swift at the star’s Nashville mansion By Laura Brody - August 22, 2019, 5:23 pm Two young women from Hamilton were treated to an experience of a lifetime by their ultra-famous idol- Taylor Swift. The multi-grammy award winning pop star hand selected about 100 mega fans from around the world to attend a secret album preview party at her Nashville mansion and 25-year-old Nichole Ridehalgh and 17-year-old Isabella Rose both got a phone call from Swifts team. Ridehalgh was shocked when she called the call inviting her to a special event. She was asked if she could make it to Nashville in less than a week. Without being told, Ridehalgh knew she had just been invited to an event that is the pinnacle of every Taylor Swift fan’s dream- a secret session album preview at the star’s Nashville mansion. Swift has held secret sessions before the releases of several of her previous albums. Fans are picked up at a secret location and driven to her mansion. Those who attend are always mega fans who the star keeps a close eye on on social media. Getting a one on one chat with the star is something Ridehalgh will never forget. “Its 4:30 in the morning, I’m exhausted but, this is my moment. I walk into the room and I turn to my left and I see her and she says hey your Nichole right?Aand in that moment my whole world was made. Without me mentioning Canada at all, she said have a safe flight back to Canada” Swift even shared secret details about her personal life with fans. Isabella Rose is also on a first name basis with Swift. She posted on social media saying “I have loved her for nine years and I will never stop talking about how much I love her but I would not be where I am today without her.” Tonight is the release of Swift’s newest album, Lover. Ridehalgh and Rose were two of 113 fans in the world, that have already heard it. “She was lip syncing and dancing. She was just having a blast.” And that night is a night these young women will replay over and over again. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Hamilton Crews on cargo ships say they’re having trouble getting vaccinated Canada & The World Fourth wave of COVID-19 may still be on the horizon this… Canada & The World Derek Chauvin sentenced to 22.5 years in prison for the death… Hamilton Several people accidentally given the wrong vaccine dose at a Hamilton… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Home Page News Story Seven people charged with First-Degree Murder in Brantford homicide News Home Page News Story Local News Main News Story Ontario News Top News Story Seven people charged with First-Degree Murder in Brantford homicide By Sylvie Lendvay - June 24, 2021, 12:06 pm Brantford along with Provincial Police (OPP) have charged seven people with first-degree murder after a joint investigation called “Project Grantham.” The investigation was created after the homicides of 22 year-old Coby “Kareem” Carter of Hamilton, 62 year-old Dorothy Lynn Vanevery, and 64 year-old Larry Reynolds both of Brantford. On July 8, 2019 officers responded to a home on Colborne St West in Brantford and located a man, deceased. On July 18, 2019, police were called to a home on Park Road South, also in Brantford, and located a man and a woman, both dead. Brantford Police and the OPP have arrested and charged 24 year-old Abdelaziz Faiz Ibrahim of Hamilton with First-Degree Murder in connection with the death of Coby “Kareem” Carter. Six more people were arrested and charged with two counts each of First-Degree Murder and one count of Conspiracy to Commit Murder in the deaths of Lynn Vanvery and Larry Reynolds. That includes: Malik MBUYI, 20 years old of Toronto, Nathan HOWES, 31 years old of Brantford, Dylan ALRIDGE, 24 years old of North York, Terrell PHILBERT, 22 years old of York, Thomy BAEZ-EUSEBIO, 23 years old of Toronto, and Salloum JASSEM, 32 years old of Brant County. All individuals remain in custody. Investigators have determined that Vanvery and Reynolds were not the intended target. Kerry Schmidt says one transport truck and six passenger vehicles crashed around 7 this morning on Highway 400 South of Finch Avenue. Schmidt says one of those cars was consumed by fire and the person inside was pronounced dead on scene. All other occupants sustained minor injuries. “Witnesses reported hearing screeching tires and saw the transport truck plowing in the back of slowing or stopped traffic. The collision resulted in a chain reaction.” Fatal collision: #Hwy400 SB south of Finch. Loaded transport truck collided into slowing/stopped traffic causing a 7 vehicle wreck. Investigation and cleanup will take hours. Expect delays and avoid the area. pic.twitter.com/1wD16nn3RW — OPP Highway Safety Division (@OPP_HSD) June 24, 2021 Expect delays in the southbound lanes of Highway 400 at Finch until this afternoon as it will be closed for the investigation. On arrival, police learned that the owner of the building had hired a construction company to work on a metal staircase. The staircase fell on both the workers and one was apparently trapped beneath it for a period of time. Both were transported to hospital in non-life threatening condition. A City of Hamilton inspector went to the scene and later deemed the building safe. The Ministry of Labour has taken over this investigation. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Hamilton Crews on cargo ships say they’re having trouble getting vaccinated Canada & The World Fourth wave of COVID-19 may still be on the horizon this… Canada & The World Derek Chauvin sentenced to 22.5 years in prison for the death… Hamilton Several people accidentally given the wrong vaccine dose at a Hamilton… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Local News Niagara Region ends household-only patio dining News Local News Top News Story Niagara Region ends household-only patio dining By Andrea Lawson - June 25, 2021, 9:04 am Niagara Region has ended household-only outdoor dining. The rule, which was part of a section 22 order put in place by Acting Medical Officer of Health Dr. Mustafa Hirji in November 2020, restricted diners to eating out only with members of their household with some exceptions. It also required restaurants, bars and breweries to gather contact information of patrons and ask about COVID-19 symptoms. The dining requirement was lifted on Thursday. Any four people will be able to sit at a patio and share a meal or drink, as per step one of Ontario’s reopening plan. That will change to six people when the province enters step 2 of the plan on June 30. READ MORE: Ontario Moves to Step Two of Reopening June 30th Daily cases in Niagara Region have decreased by 60 per cent over the past two weeks. Still, Dr. Hirji says progress is fragile. “Thanks to ongoing vigilance against COVID-19, cases continue to decline in Niagara allowing our businesses to continue to recover,” said Dr. Mustafa Hirji, Acting Medical Officer of Health. “However, other communities show us that this progress isn’t guaranteed. With the more contentious and more severe delta variant starting to circulate, we need ongoing vigilance around keeping distance, wearing masks, and limiting in-person social interactions until we have the vast majority our population vaccinated with two doses. If you have not already done so, please sign up to get vaccinated so we can make our economic reopening permanent.” TAGS COVID-19 Dr. Mustafa Hirji niagara region ontario patio dining Share Facebook Twitter Pinterest Linkedin Email Print Previous articleDerek Chauvin to be sentenced Friday in the death of George Floyd Next articleBrantford police say missing teen boy has been found safe Andrea Lawson RELATED ARTICLESMORE FROM AUTHOR Hamilton Crews on cargo ships say they’re having trouble getting vaccinated Canada & The World Fourth wave of COVID-19 may still be on the horizon this fall and winter Canada & The World Derek Chauvin sentenced to 22.5 years in prison for the death of George Floyd Hamilton Several people accidentally given the wrong vaccine dose at a Hamilton clinic Local News Petition calls for Hamilton to remove Sir John A. Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 21.6 C Hamilton Friday, June 25, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Petition calls for Hamilton to remove Sir John A. Macdonald statue Local News Hamilton police conducting sudden death investigation Canada News Prime Minister Justin Trudeau says this Canada Day should be a… News Death toll in Florida collapse rises to four, 159 people still… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility Local News Halton Hamilton News Home Page News Story Ontario News Top News Story Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility By Sylvie Lendvay - May 10, 2021, 11:08 am The province says the eligibility to receive a COVID-19 vaccine will expand the week of May 10th to include people with “at-risk” health conditions, people who cannot work from home (Group 2), and people 40 and older. Starting Tuesday May 11 at 8 a.m, people with “at-risk” health conditions such as immune deficiencies, cancer, diabetes, and asthma will be able to book an appointment either through the provincial portal or their region’s website. Also Tuesday morning, people in Group 2 who cannot work from home including those who work in essential retail, courts and banks can book. Social workers, veterinarians and miners are also apart of the list that can be found here. Thursday May 13 at 8 a.m, people turning 40 in 2021 and older in non-hot spot communities can book a vaccine appointment at a mass immunization clinic. Halton Region has expanded its’ vaccination program to allow residents 16 and older who cannot work from home to book an appointment through the regions online portal. Halton residents 50 and older living in non-hot spot communities can also book. Wednesday May 12 eligibility opens to those 40 and older, Friday May 14 to those 30 and older, and by next week all Halton adults over the age of 16 will be eligible to book an appointment. Halton residents 16+ who cannot work from home can now book a COVID vaccine appointment… as well as anyone 50+. May 12 – 40+. May 14 – 30+. May 19 – 16+. They are following provincial criteria for expanding program based on risk… have enough supply to do it early. @CHCHNews pic.twitter.com/VYwEmaGKLO — Sylvie Lendvay (@sylvie_lendvay) May 10, 2021 Halton region says they are following provincial criteria for expanding eligibility based on who is most at risk, but they have enough supply to do it early. There are several pilot clinics across the province vaccinating residents 18 and older. Four pharmacies in Hamilton are approved to administer Moderna. Each location will receive about 150 shots a week. Adults 40 and older can still book an AstraZeneca vaccine at a participating pharmacy. All booking availability will depend on supply. Constable Frank Trasmundi with Halton Police says sometimes when people report their bicycle stolen, the owner won’t have the serial number. If that’s the case, police can’t return it or lay charges. He says downloading the app ‘529 Garage’ can help people file a report. “We will have picture of your bike, the serial number, and any distinguishing features so it will be easier for us to recover it if we find it.” says Trasmundi. Halton Police recovers 200 bikes per year on average. Only about 10-15 of them are returned. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Hamilton Crews on cargo ships say they’re having trouble getting vaccinated Canada & The World Fourth wave of COVID-19 may still be on the horizon this… Canada & The World Derek Chauvin sentenced to 22.5 years in prison for the death… Hamilton Several people accidentally given the wrong vaccine dose at a Hamilton… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton If you don’t live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor Local News Halton Main News Story News If you don’t live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor By Sylvie Lendvay - December 9, 2020, 10:11 am With cases on the rise in Halton Region, Burlington’s Mayor Marianne Meed Ward residents should be concerned. “The simplest message I could give to residents is this: If you don’t live with somebody, assume that they have COVID and conduct yourself accordingly.” Even with the temptation to gather this holiday season, she is urging residents to follow public health guidelines. “Our [Burlington] numbers are going up again, a little bit. There’s been a lot of talk about a vaccine coming; we know we’re getting that but that’s not the silver bullet. That’s not the only solution. We are going to continue, for at least a year, to need to be keeping physical distance, hand washing, wearing a mask when out in public. Those measures are going to be critically important throughout 2021.” Halton reported 92 new cases of COVID-19 Tuesday. St. Anne Catholic Elementary school in Burlington has had to close down one classroom after 4 cases were reported Tuesday night. There are currently active 14 outbreaks in Halton region. The region’s Medical Officer of Health says the region continues to see community transmission. She is asking residents to avoid carpooling, and having coffee and play dates. Local News Halton News Is Halton heading back to a modified Stage 2? By Laura Brody - October 23, 2020, 8:52 pm Premier Doug Ford is concerned about Halton region’s rising case numbers and says a decision will be made by Monday whether or not to send the region back to modified Stage 2. Halton region is approaching 2,000 total COVID-19 cases; half of which have been recorded in the last two months. “We’re going to have to discuss that over the weekend and we’ll have that answer on Monday. But folks in Halton, I know they’re doing a great job. It’s concerning right now. I’ve seen the numbers go up.” said Premier Doug Ford. “The premier has been terrific to work with throughout this. We recorded 16 new cases today. That’s like 1 in 35,000 people here. I think curves on small numbers are very unreliable ways to judge the future.” said Oakville Mayor Rob Burton. Oakville has already restricted indoor group fitness classes and team sports. The modified Stage 2 would prohibit indoor dining, and close gyms, fitness centres, cinemas and performance venues. Home Local News Hamilton Large amount of drugs stolen from Stoney Creek pharmacy Local News Hamilton News Top News Story Large amount of drugs stolen from Stoney Creek pharmacy By Sylvie Lendvay - June 24, 2021, 10:07 am Hamilton Police file photo Hamilton Police say a man robbed a pharmacy of unmixed methadone powder. It happened Tuesday June 22nd around 7:00 p.m in Stoney Creek. Police are concerned as improper consumption of these opioid drugs could be fatal. The risk is especially high in the case of children. If you find lost or discarded medication, police say do not touch it and contact them. Officers are reminding the public that taking medication that is not prescribed, is harmful. Police have not disclosed the location of the pharmacy. If you have any information that you believe could assist Police with the investigation into this armed robbery you are asked to contact Detective Constable Wayne Potter at 905-540-6342 or Detective Sergeant Andrea Torrie at 905-546-2991. The Niagara Falls location will no longer operate on weekends. New hours will be Monday to Friday 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. Welland’s assessment centre is cutting back to Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Hours at the St. Catharines assessment centre remain the same 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. seven days a week. COVID-19 testing at these centres, which are run by Niagara Health, are by-appointment only. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Hamilton announces road closure for maintenance at Tim Hortons Field Canada News WATCH LIVE: Prime Minister Trudeau to provide COVID-19 update at 11:15… Ontario News Ontario reports 484 COVID-19 cases, 28 deaths over two days News All Ontario youth eligible to move up second COVID vaccine doses… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Ontario dealing with massive driving test backlog News Ontario News Top News Story Ontario dealing with massive driving test backlog By Andrea Lawson - July 2, 2021, 6:46 am Ontario is experiencing a major backlog of residents trying to complete their driving tests. The assessments were shut down last year in response to the COVID-19 pandemic and were allowed to resume on June 14. But aspiring drivers say the backlog to book a road test is staggering. They either have to resort to accepting appointments far from home or else have to wait months for available time slots. One resident recently failed his test and says he can’t try again until next January. Ontario’s Ministry of Transportation says more than 421,000 tests have been cancelled since March 2020 due to pandemic-related lockdowns. It says it has invested $16 million to deal with the backlog. Last fall it said it would hire 84 temporary driver examiners for its DriveTest centres, and has so far filled 35 of those positions. It recently announced it would hire 167 additional driver examiners, and recruitment is underway with the goal to have everyone on board by September. The family who owns the home is desperate for help, but so far have found none. Matt Ingram reports. TAGS air bnb booking guests hamilton Share Facebook Twitter Pinterest Linkedin Email Print Previous articlePeople across the region gather on Canada Day to spread awareness and support for Indigenous communities Next articleOntario dealing with massive driving test backlog Dominick Nagy RELATED ARTICLESMORE FROM AUTHOR Local News Hamilton announces road closure for maintenance at Tim Hortons Field Canada News WATCH LIVE: Prime Minister Trudeau to provide COVID-19 update at 11:15 a.m. News All Ontario youth eligible to move up second COVID vaccine doses next week News Tour de France organizers drop legal action against careless fan Local News Truck driver given three-year sentence in fatal crash in Oakville in 2019 Local News McKenzie Meadows development cancelled amid land dispute 11 COMMENTS D Root July 1, 2021, 10:48 pm at 10:48 pm How do people have the nerve to do this? You can’t just stay beyond the contracted time. Ghulam hasnain July 2, 2021, 12:11 am at 12:11 am When laws in the province are so unfair for home owners and landlords that even the police don’t know where they should stand, this is what happens. Karen Bates July 2, 2021, 6:53 am at 6:53 am These people are officially now squatters and trespassing. This is illegal , so why are the police not doing their job. If the couple needs help then get it for them. No matter the reason they need to be escorted off the property. Home owners shouldn’t have to put up with this. Ridiculous . John Doctson July 2, 2021, 11:33 am at 11:33 am There’s risk in every investment, especially air bnb’s Simon Weresch July 2, 2021, 11:37 am at 11:37 am What many don’t know is that when air bnb renters refuse to leave they now have the residential tenancies act for protection and with the delays of covid and the wait lists for hearings can be a long and costly wait. As the owner of a property Management company we navigate and negotiate these issues routinely. Kym July 2, 2021, 11:40 am at 11:40 am Stop paying the utilities let it cut off on them Amanda July 2, 2021, 11:40 am at 11:40 am This right here is exactly whats going to scare people that have their homes on Airbnb. I know for me i would not be renting my place out after this. If there is no way to evict someone if they won’t leave. This system is crazy. Harry July 2, 2021, 11:47 am at 11:47 am Ripping home owners off is now an encouraged way of life thanks to the Landlord & Tenant Board. Anyone renting their home out to anyone these days needs to get their head examined. I don’t ever want to hear people moan about the lack of rental housing – why the market exists at all anymore is incredible to me. Kam July 2, 2021, 11:59 am at 11:59 am LTB is more than 6 months behind in hearing cases. Police won’t do anything to these freeloaders. Banks want their mortgages paid. What the hell is Ford Government doing ? Are they going to help the landlords ? Ontario is the worst province for landlords. By the way, I am not a landlord but do feel for the landlords in this pandemic. Joy Karney July 2, 2021, 12:09 pm at 12:09 pm We wonder why there is a shortage of rentals? The laws against homeowners who rent are ridiculous! There is no recourse against bad behavior in tenants. The laws must change! Umesh Sarang July 2, 2021, 12:35 pm at 12:35 pm Living in other people homes….a glorified name called…..Air ….whatever….why is a generation behaving this way…because its made to believe ..it is ok… Comments are closed. News Canada & The World Top News Story At least 4 Canadians are unaccounted for as the search continues in Miami after a condominium collapsed on Thursday By Alex Last - June 27, 2021, 8:27 pm Global Affairs has confirmed at least four Canadian citizens are unaccounted for in the condo collapse in Surfside, Florida. They have also confirmed with us that three Canadian families are affected by the tragedy. Their statement notes that Canadian officials are in contact with local authorities and the families impacted. Global Affairs will not be able to provide further information due to provisions of the privacy act. News Canada News Top News Story Wildfire leads to evacuation order in B.C. village that set Canadian heat wave record By Andrea Lawson - July 1, 2021, 7:03 am A fast-spreading wildfire led to an immediate evacuation order Wednesday night for residents of Lytton, B.C. Mayor Jan Polderman issued the evacuation order at 6 p.m. local time. It said the wildfire was threatening structures and the safety of residents. Lytton is about a two-hour drive southwest of Kamloops. The village, which lists its population at about 250 people as of 2016, smashed a Canadian record for high temperatures three days in a row this week during an ongoing historic heat wave. Temperatures reached 49.6 Celsius. Most of Western Canada is still baking in extreme heat from that weather system. Conditions remain dangerously hot from southern and central B.C. and east through Alberta, Saskatchewan and Manitoba. B.C.’s chief coroner Lisa Lapointe says at least 486 sudden deaths have been reported to the B.C. Coroners Service since last Friday amid temperatures in the 30’s and 40’s. News Canada News B.C. nations say 182 unmarked graves found in cemetery near former residential school By News Staff - July 1, 2021, 6:11 am Two First Nations say a search using ground-penetrating radar has found the remains of 182 people in unmarked graves at a site close to a former residential school in the southern Interior of British Columbia. But the leadership of the Ktunaxa community of aq’am says several factors make it difficult to establish whether the unmarked graves contain the remains of children who attended the institution. The Lower Kootenay Band, another Ktunaxa community in B.C.’s southern Interior, released a statement Wednesday saying ground-penetrating radar had detected the remains near the site of the former St. Eugene’s Mission School. The statement from aq’am says the history of the area is complex and analysis of the findings is ongoing, with preliminary results finding 182 unmarked graves, some as shallow as 90 centimetres, in a cemetery next to the institution. It says the cemetery was established around 1865 for settlers to the area and many of those buried there died at a nearby hospital that burned down in 1899. The statement from aq’am says hundreds of Ktunaxa children and those from neighbouring Indigenous nations attended the residential institution that was operated by the Catholic Church from 1912 to 1970. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Hamilton announces road closure for maintenance at Tim Hortons Field Canada News WATCH LIVE: Prime Minister Trudeau to provide COVID-19 update at 11:15… Ontario News Ontario reports 484 COVID-19 cases, 28 deaths over two days News All Ontario youth eligible to move up second COVID vaccine doses… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Canada News Peace Tower flag lowered on Canada Day to honour Indigenous children: Trudeau News Canada News Peace Tower flag lowered on Canada Day to honour Indigenous children: Trudeau By Andrea Lawson - June 30, 2021, 1:55 pm Prime Minister Justin Trudeau says he asked that the national flag on the Peace Tower remain at half-mast for Canada Day to honour the Indigenous children who died in residential schools. In a post on his Twitter account, Trudeau says he made the decision as he and many Canadians reflect on the tragedy of the institutions. As people across the country continue to honour the Indigenous children whose lives were taken far too soon, and as we reflect on the tragedy of residential schools, I have asked that the flag on the Peace Tower remain at half-mast for Canada Day. — Justin Trudeau (@JustinTrudeau) June 30, 2021 Cowessess First Nation last week said that ground-penetrating radar detected 751 unmarked graves at the former Marieval Indian Residential School east of Regina, Sask., a few weeks after the finding of what are believed to be the remains of 215 children in Kamloops, B.C. RELATED STORY: Tribute left in Stoney Creek after burial site found at former B.C. residential school Canadian Heritage plans to still go ahead with virtual Canada Day events like last year, with an online music show featuring English, French and Indigenous artists. Several cities and communities across the country have decided to forgo parts of their usual Canada Day festivities. Events will be partially or fully cancelled in Saint John, Fredericton, Victoria, Wilmot Township in Ontario’s Waterloo region, and St. Albert, a city northwest of Edmonton, in solidarity with mourning Indigenous communities. McKenna, who is from Hamilton, represents the riding of Ottawa Centre and is the minister of Infrastructure and Communities. She says she informed the prime minister and the president of the Liberal party of her intention not to run again over the weekend. After a lot of reflection, I decided I wanted to spend more time on the two things that matter most to me: my kids & the climate. Huge thanks to the people of Ottawa Centre & Canadians. It’s been such an honour. 🙏❤️ pic.twitter.com/wPbAAGiyhr — Catherine McKenna 🇨🇦 (@cathmckenna) June 28, 2021 She says living through COVID-19 through a very long year made her step back and reflect on what matters to her most. She wants to spend more time with her three children and fight for climate change. The Grace Anglican Church started the planning process on the centre four years ago. They are calling it “Bobby’s Place”, named after local Bobby Smylie who died from the flu in 2018 at the age of 10. The church says the centre will provide a meeting space to learn, socialize, and grow. Construction on “Bobby’s Place” will begin in a few weeks and they hope to have it finished by the Fall. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Hamilton announces road closure for maintenance at Tim Hortons Field Canada News WATCH LIVE: Prime Minister Trudeau to provide COVID-19 update at 11:15… Ontario News Ontario reports 484 COVID-19 cases, 28 deaths over two days News All Ontario youth eligible to move up second COVID vaccine doses… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Evening News Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen News Evening News Local News Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen By Laura Brody - December 24, 2019, 4:59 pm Hamilton police have arrested a man in connection with a two-month long investigation into stolen, high-end bikes worth more than $40 000. Police say they executed a search warrant at a home in the east end last Thursday and found 26 mountain bikes, along with bike parts, high-end skis and prohibited weapons. They believe the bikes were stolen from residential and commercial properties in Ancaster, Aldershot and Dundas. They say most of the bikes had been taken apart and the parts had been swapped, to try to disguise them. So far, police have returned 3 of the 26 bikes to their owners, and hope to return the rest of them in the next two weeks. Jason Kane, 43, of Hamilton, is facing a number of charges including two counts of possession of a prohibited weapon, and three counts of possession of stolen property. Police say the investigation is ongoing and more charges could be laid. They recommend that you record the serial number on your bike, and call police if it’s been stolen. Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 15.6 C Hamilton Saturday, July 3, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Canada & The World A major evacuation is underway in BC as wildfires continue Hamilton Two new COVID19 outbreaks are hitting long term care homes in… Hamilton AirBnB guests refuse to leave, Hamilton police say owner could be… Local News Hamilton announces road closure for maintenance at Tim Hortons Field WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Evening News Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed News Evening News Local News Hamilton Home Page News Story Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed By Laura Brody - October 21, 2019, 6:27 pm Hamilton police have identified the suspect in the city’s tenth homicide of the year, and have issued a warrant for his arrest. Twenty-nine year old Obsa Junedi Mohamed was gunned down outside of Boulevard Billiards on York Boulevard at around 1:30 Saturday morning. Police say his killer was his friend, 26-year-old Ibrahim Issak Hussen. The two men were hanging out with a group of other men for awhile before the shooting. About 10 minutes before the shooting detectives say Junedi Mohamed and Issak Hussen got into a physical altercation. Hussen goes by the street name “Seemo.” Junedi Mohamed’s street name was Nanny or Chappel. Detectives say Hussen shot Mohamed point blank in the head. The whole incident was caught on surveillance video. Surveillance images released in the media led to the driver of the getaway vehicle turning himself in to police on Saturday. That man was arrested for first degree murder and accessory after the fact to murder. Police say he participated in a lengthy interview and was released unconditionally later Saturday. But another man was also in the car and police want to speak to him. They are looking for an Asian male wearing a dark parka with fur trim on the hood. The victim was known to police. He was found by officers hiding after another shooting in the same area back in 2015. At the time he was charged with failing to comply and possession of cocaine. Issak Hussen is also known to police and investigators believe drugs are involved in this incident as well. News Evening News Local News Two Hamilton women were invited to meet Taylor Swift at the star’s Nashville mansion By Laura Brody - August 22, 2019, 5:23 pm Two young women from Hamilton were treated to an experience of a lifetime by their ultra-famous idol- Taylor Swift. The multi-grammy award winning pop star hand selected about 100 mega fans from around the world to attend a secret album preview party at her Nashville mansion and 25-year-old Nichole Ridehalgh and 17-year-old Isabella Rose both got a phone call from Swifts team. Ridehalgh was shocked when she called the call inviting her to a special event. She was asked if she could make it to Nashville in less than a week. Without being told, Ridehalgh knew she had just been invited to an event that is the pinnacle of every Taylor Swift fan’s dream- a secret session album preview at the star’s Nashville mansion. Swift has held secret sessions before the releases of several of her previous albums. Fans are picked up at a secret location and driven to her mansion. Those who attend are always mega fans who the star keeps a close eye on on social media. Getting a one on one chat with the star is something Ridehalgh will never forget. “Its 4:30 in the morning, I’m exhausted but, this is my moment. I walk into the room and I turn to my left and I see her and she says hey your Nichole right?Aand in that moment my whole world was made. Without me mentioning Canada at all, she said have a safe flight back to Canada” Swift even shared secret details about her personal life with fans. Isabella Rose is also on a first name basis with Swift. She posted on social media saying “I have loved her for nine years and I will never stop talking about how much I love her but I would not be where I am today without her.” Tonight is the release of Swift’s newest album, Lover. Ridehalgh and Rose were two of 113 fans in the world, that have already heard it. “She was lip syncing and dancing. She was just having a blast.” And that night is a night these young women will replay over and over again. Indigenous activists are asking people to pause and reflect this Canada Day - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 15.6 C Hamilton Saturday, July 3, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Canada & The World A major evacuation is underway in BC as wildfires continue Hamilton Two new COVID19 outbreaks are hitting long term care homes in… Hamilton AirBnB guests refuse to leave, Hamilton police say owner could be… Local News Hamilton announces road closure for maintenance at Tim Hortons Field WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Hamilton Indigenous activists are asking people to pause and reflect this Canada Day Local News Hamilton News Home Page News Story Indigenous activists are asking people to pause and reflect this Canada Day By Sylvie Lendvay - July 1, 2021, 10:02 am There will be many ceremonies across the Golden Horseshoe this Canada Day, to mourn the hundreds of children discovered in unmarked graves in residential schools across the country this past month. Indigenous activists are asking people to take some time today to reflect. Sherlene Bomberry went to the Mohawk Institute in Brantford, a former residential school, in the 1960’s. She says she never told anyone about her experience for years, but now she is speaking out. “When I heard about the 215, that’s when my body remembered. I was sitting there watching TV and started crying. I was never able to share how I really felt.” She says she has since taken back her power by going to indigenous ceremonies, using her language, and wearing traditional clothing. “I’m proud,” says Bomberry. One of the ceremonies will be held at Bayfront Park in Hamilton this afternoon. Jordan Carrier who is organizing the event says today is about coming together for healing. “It’s a tough day being Canada Day. I know a lot of proud Canadians are coming to this truth and they are not too sure where they sit with that. For myself, I’m not saying don’t ever celebrate Canada Day again, I’m just saying for this year pause and stand with us.” Carrier says non-indigenous people are welcome to come the ceremony to listen, hear and see indigenous culture. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Canada & The World A major evacuation is underway in BC as wildfires continue Hamilton Two new COVID19 outbreaks are hitting long term care homes in… Hamilton AirBnB guests refuse to leave, Hamilton police say owner could be… Local News Hamilton announces road closure for maintenance at Tim Hortons Field WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Home Page News Story Seven people charged with First-Degree Murder in Brantford homicide News Home Page News Story Local News Main News Story Ontario News Top News Story Seven people charged with First-Degree Murder in Brantford homicide By Sylvie Lendvay - June 24, 2021, 12:06 pm Brantford along with Provincial Police (OPP) have charged seven people with first-degree murder after a joint investigation called “Project Grantham.” The investigation was created after the homicides of 22 year-old Coby “Kareem” Carter of Hamilton, 62 year-old Dorothy Lynn Vanevery, and 64 year-old Larry Reynolds both of Brantford. On July 8, 2019 officers responded to a home on Colborne St West in Brantford and located a man, deceased. On July 18, 2019, police were called to a home on Park Road South, also in Brantford, and located a man and a woman, both dead. Brantford Police and the OPP have arrested and charged 24 year-old Abdelaziz Faiz Ibrahim of Hamilton with First-Degree Murder in connection with the death of Coby “Kareem” Carter. Six more people were arrested and charged with two counts each of First-Degree Murder and one count of Conspiracy to Commit Murder in the deaths of Lynn Vanvery and Larry Reynolds. That includes: Malik MBUYI, 20 years old of Toronto, Nathan HOWES, 31 years old of Brantford, Dylan ALRIDGE, 24 years old of North York, Terrell PHILBERT, 22 years old of York, Thomy BAEZ-EUSEBIO, 23 years old of Toronto, and Salloum JASSEM, 32 years old of Brant County. All individuals remain in custody. Investigators have determined that Vanvery and Reynolds were not the intended target. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Hamilton announces road closure for maintenance at Tim Hortons Field Canada News WATCH LIVE: Prime Minister Trudeau to provide COVID-19 update at 11:15… Ontario News Ontario reports 484 COVID-19 cases, 28 deaths over two days News All Ontario youth eligible to move up second COVID vaccine doses… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Canada & The World 751 unmarked graves discovered at former residential school in Saskatchewan News Canada & The World Home Page News Story Top News Story 751 unmarked graves discovered at former residential school in Saskatchewan By Sylvie Lendvay - June 24, 2021, 11:32 am Cowessess First Nation say at least 751 unmarked graves have been discovered on the former site of the Marieval Indian Residential School. They could not confirm the bodies discovered were all children “This could be triggering for many…we always knew there were graves here.” Chief Cadmus Delorme said headstones were once there, but they were removed by the Catholic church and never put back. The Cowessess First Nation says they are treating it as a crime scene. The discovery comes less than a month after 215 bodies were found on the site of a former residential school in Kamloops, B.C. Radar searches continue around each residential school in Canada. Kerry Schmidt says one transport truck and six passenger vehicles crashed around 7 this morning on Highway 400 South of Finch Avenue. Schmidt says one of those cars was consumed by fire and the person inside was pronounced dead on scene. All other occupants sustained minor injuries. “Witnesses reported hearing screeching tires and saw the transport truck plowing in the back of slowing or stopped traffic. The collision resulted in a chain reaction.” Fatal collision: #Hwy400 SB south of Finch. Loaded transport truck collided into slowing/stopped traffic causing a 7 vehicle wreck. Investigation and cleanup will take hours. Expect delays and avoid the area. pic.twitter.com/1wD16nn3RW — OPP Highway Safety Division (@OPP_HSD) June 24, 2021 Expect delays in the southbound lanes of Highway 400 at Finch until this afternoon as it will be closed for the investigation.
