CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Canada & The World A major evacuation is underway in BC as wildfires continue Hamilton Two new COVID19 outbreaks are hitting long term care homes in… Hamilton AirBnB guests refuse to leave, Hamilton police say owner could be… Local News Hamilton announces road closure for maintenance at Tim Hortons Field WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility Local News Halton Hamilton News Home Page News Story Ontario News Top News Story Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility By Sylvie Lendvay - May 10, 2021, 11:08 am The province says the eligibility to receive a COVID-19 vaccine will expand the week of May 10th to include people with “at-risk” health conditions, people who cannot work from home (Group 2), and people 40 and older. Starting Tuesday May 11 at 8 a.m, people with “at-risk” health conditions such as immune deficiencies, cancer, diabetes, and asthma will be able to book an appointment either through the provincial portal or their region’s website. Also Tuesday morning, people in Group 2 who cannot work from home including those who work in essential retail, courts and banks can book. Social workers, veterinarians and miners are also apart of the list that can be found here. Thursday May 13 at 8 a.m, people turning 40 in 2021 and older in non-hot spot communities can book a vaccine appointment at a mass immunization clinic. Halton Region has expanded its’ vaccination program to allow residents 16 and older who cannot work from home to book an appointment through the regions online portal. Halton residents 50 and older living in non-hot spot communities can also book. Wednesday May 12 eligibility opens to those 40 and older, Friday May 14 to those 30 and older, and by next week all Halton adults over the age of 16 will be eligible to book an appointment. Halton residents 16+ who cannot work from home can now book a COVID vaccine appointment… as well as anyone 50+. May 12 – 40+. May 14 – 30+. May 19 – 16+. They are following provincial criteria for expanding program based on risk… have enough supply to do it early. @CHCHNews pic.twitter.com/VYwEmaGKLO — Sylvie Lendvay (@sylvie_lendvay) May 10, 2021 Halton region says they are following provincial criteria for expanding eligibility based on who is most at risk, but they have enough supply to do it early. There are several pilot clinics across the province vaccinating residents 18 and older. Four pharmacies in Hamilton are approved to administer Moderna. Each location will receive about 150 shots a week. Adults 40 and older can still book an AstraZeneca vaccine at a participating pharmacy. All booking availability will depend on supply. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Canada & The World A major evacuation is underway in BC as wildfires continue Hamilton Two new COVID19 outbreaks are hitting long term care homes in… Hamilton AirBnB guests refuse to leave, Hamilton police say owner could be… Local News Hamilton announces road closure for maintenance at Tim Hortons Field WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton Halton Police are trying to prevent bicycle theft Local News Halton News Halton Police are trying to prevent bicycle theft By Sylvie Lendvay - April 19, 2021, 9:27 am Police Services across Ontario are trying to get ahead of bike thefts. Constable Frank Trasmundi with Halton Police says sometimes when people report their bicycle stolen, the owner won’t have the serial number. If that’s the case, police can’t return it or lay charges. He says downloading the app ‘529 Garage’ can help people file a report. “We will have picture of your bike, the serial number, and any distinguishing features so it will be easier for us to recover it if we find it.” says Trasmundi. Halton Police recovers 200 bikes per year on average. Only about 10-15 of them are returned. If you don't live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 18.3 C Hamilton Friday, July 2, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Hamilton announces road closure for maintenance at Tim Hortons Field Canada News WATCH LIVE: Prime Minister Trudeau to provide COVID-19 update at 11:15… Ontario News Ontario reports 484 COVID-19 cases, 28 deaths over two days News All Ontario youth eligible to move up second COVID vaccine doses… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton If you don’t live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor Local News Halton Main News Story News If you don’t live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor By Sylvie Lendvay - December 9, 2020, 10:11 am With cases on the rise in Halton Region, Burlington’s Mayor Marianne Meed Ward residents should be concerned. “The simplest message I could give to residents is this: If you don’t live with somebody, assume that they have COVID and conduct yourself accordingly.” Even with the temptation to gather this holiday season, she is urging residents to follow public health guidelines. “Our [Burlington] numbers are going up again, a little bit. There’s been a lot of talk about a vaccine coming; we know we’re getting that but that’s not the silver bullet. That’s not the only solution. We are going to continue, for at least a year, to need to be keeping physical distance, hand washing, wearing a mask when out in public. Those measures are going to be critically important throughout 2021.” Halton reported 92 new cases of COVID-19 Tuesday. St. Anne Catholic Elementary school in Burlington has had to close down one classroom after 4 cases were reported Tuesday night. There are currently active 14 outbreaks in Halton region. The region’s Medical Officer of Health says the region continues to see community transmission. She is asking residents to avoid carpooling, and having coffee and play dates. Local News Halton News Is Halton heading back to a modified Stage 2? By Laura Brody - October 23, 2020, 8:52 pm Premier Doug Ford is concerned about Halton region’s rising case numbers and says a decision will be made by Monday whether or not to send the region back to modified Stage 2. Halton region is approaching 2,000 total COVID-19 cases; half of which have been recorded in the last two months. “We’re going to have to discuss that over the weekend and we’ll have that answer on Monday. But folks in Halton, I know they’re doing a great job. It’s concerning right now. I’ve seen the numbers go up.” said Premier Doug Ford. “The premier has been terrific to work with throughout this. We recorded 16 new cases today. That’s like 1 in 35,000 people here. I think curves on small numbers are very unreliable ways to judge the future.” said Oakville Mayor Rob Burton. Oakville has already restricted indoor group fitness classes and team sports. The modified Stage 2 would prohibit indoor dining, and close gyms, fitness centres, cinemas and performance venues. The Niagara Falls location will no longer operate on weekends. New hours will be Monday to Friday 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. Welland’s assessment centre is cutting back to Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Hours at the St. Catharines assessment centre remain the same 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. seven days a week. COVID-19 testing at these centres, which are run by Niagara Health, are by-appointment only. Home News Local News Hamilton girl, 15, struck while skateboarding dies from injuries News Local News Top News Story Hamilton girl, 15, struck while skateboarding dies from injuries By Shayla Vize - July 9, 2021, 1:08 pm A 15-year-old Hamilton girl who was hit by a car while skateboarding has died from her injuries. The teen was struck by a 2008 Honda being driven by a 21-year-old Hamilton man on Old Mohawk Rd. on April 25. Emergency crews responded to the scene shortly before 9 p.m. and transported the girl to hospital with life-threatening injuries. The driver of the car remained on scene and tried to help the girl before paramedics arrived. In a tweet posted Friday, Hamilton police said they are “saddened to announce” the girl’s death and their “thoughts are with her family at this time.” Police say the investigation into the collision is complete and no charges are being laid. This is the city’s sixth traffic fatality of 2021. Ontario moving to Step 3 of reopening plan on July 16 - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 17.8 C Hamilton Friday, July 9, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Hamilton girl, 15, struck while skateboarding dies from injuries Ontario News Ontario moving to Step 3 of reopening plan on July 16 Ontario News Ontario reports 183 new cases of COVID-19, 9 more deaths Local News Hamilton police say missing teen left home after argument with family WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Ontario News Ontario moving to Step 3 of reopening plan on July 16 News Ontario News Top News Story Ontario moving to Step 3 of reopening plan on July 16 By Shayla Vize - July 9, 2021, 12:13 pm Ontario will be moving to the next phase of its reopening plan on July 16, several days ahead of schedule. The government made the announcement in a news release issued Friday morning. Ontario says it has met its vaccination targets for Step 3, and other health indicators have improved enough to allow for the early move. Step 3 will focus on the resumption of indoor services with larger numbers of people. This includes, but is not limited to: Outdoor social gatherings and organized public events with up to 100 people with limited exceptions; Indoor social gatherings and organized public events with up to 25 people; Indoor religious services, rites or ceremonies, including wedding services and funeral services permitted with physical distancing; Indoor dining permitted with no limits on the number of patrons per table with physical distancing and other restrictions still in effect; Indoor sports and recreational fitness facilities to open subject to a maximum 50 per cent capacity of the indoor space. capacity for indoor spectators is 50 per cent of the usual seating capacity or 1,000 people, whichever is less. Capacity for outdoor spectators is 75 per cent of the usual seating capacity or 15,000 people, whichever is less; Indoor meeting and event spaces permitted to operate with physical distancing and other restrictions still in effect and capacity limited to not exceed 50 per cent capacity or 1,000 people, (whichever is less); Essential and non-essential retail with capacity limited to the number of people that can maintain a physical distance of two metres; Personal care services, including services requiring the removal of a face covering, with capacity limited to the number of people that can maintain a physical distance of two metres; Museums, galleries, historic sites, aquariums, zoos, landmarks, botanical gardens, science centres, casinos/bingo halls, amusement parks, fairs and rural exhibitions, festivals, with capacity limited to not exceed 50 per cent capacity indoors and 75 per cent capacity outdoors; Concert venues, cinemas, and theatres permitted to operate at: up to 50 per cent capacity indoors or a maximum limit of 1,000 people for seated events (whichever is less) up to 75 per cent capacity outdoors or a maximum limit of 5,000 people for unseated events (whichever is less); and up to 75 per cent capacity outdoors or a maximum of 15,000 people for events with fixed seating (whichever is less) Real estate open houses with capacity limited to the number of people that can maintain a physical distance of two metres; and Indoor food or drink establishments where dance facilities are provided, including nightclubs and restobars, permitted up to 25 per cent capacity or up to a maximum limit of 250 people (whichever is less). Face coverings in indoor public settings and physical distancing requirements remain in place. “Ontario has continued to see improvements in key health indicators, allowing the province to move to Step Three of the Roadmap and safely resume more of the activities we’ve missed,” said Christine Elliott, Deputy Premier and Minister of Health in the news release. “While this is exciting news, we must still remain vigilant and continue to follow the public health measure we know work and keep us safe. Vaccines remain our ticket out of the pandemic so if you haven’t booked your appointment yet, please do so today.” The province will stay in Step 3 for at least 21 days and until 80 per cent of the eligible population aged 12 and over has received one dose of a COVID-19 vaccine and 75 per cent have received their second. The data is based on more than 26,100 completed tests. The test positivity rate is 0.7 per cent — the lowest test positivity rate since Sept. 6, 2020. Health Minister Christine Elliott says there are 50 new cases in the Region of Waterloo, 24 in Peel Region, 24 in Grey Bruce, 22 in Toronto, and 10 in Halton Region. The Ministry of Health says 202 people are in intensive care because of COVID-19 and 112 are on a ventilator. Elliott says as of 8 p.m. Thursday, 16.6 million doses of the COVID-19 vaccine have been administered, including 224,864 doses administered yesterday. Here are the COVID-19 numbers for our region: Hamilton 21,372 total cases — up 9 from previous 20,410 resolved cases 93 active cases 400 deaths 24 in hospital Niagara Region 16,269 total cases — up 3 from previous 15,765 resolved cases 89 active cases 415 deaths 8 in hospital Halton Region Halton Region has not yet updated data from July 8 18,049 total cases — up 11 from previous (July 8) 17,751 resolved cases (July 8) 67 active cases (July 8) 231 deaths (July 8) 7 in hospital (July 8) Brant 3,409 total cases 3,382 resolved cases 7 active cases 20 deaths 1 in hospital Haldimand-Norfolk 2,714 total cases — no change from previous 2,651 resolved cases 10 active cases 47 deaths TAGS brant COVID-19 haldimand halton hamilton niagara norfolk Share Facebook Twitter Pinterest Linkedin Email Print Previous articleHamilton police say missing teen left home after argument with family Next articleA “paw”sitive team Shayla Vize RELATED ARTICLESMORE FROM AUTHOR Local News Hamilton girl, 15, struck while skateboarding dies from injuries Ontario News Ontario moving to Step 3 of reopening plan on July 16 Local News Hamilton police say missing teen left home after argument with family Ontario News RCMP seizes $14M worth of cocaine at Peace Bridge in Fort Erie Local News Hamilton police search for rightful owners of stolen property Canada & The World More than half of Ontario adults are double-vaxxed LEAVE A REPLY Cancel reply Please enter your comment! Police say Yared Kidane was last seen at his home on Queen St. North around 6:30 a.m. Investigators say the teen was involved in an argument with his family prior to leaving his residence. Police say the boy was not carrying his cell phone at the time. Kidane is described as having a shaved head and police say he was wearing a grey jacket, black sweatpants, and black Nike shoes. Police are hoping members of the community can help locate the teen as they are growing increasingly worried for his safety. Anyone with information on his whereabouts is asked to contact investigators at 905-546-4725. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Hamilton girl, 15, struck while skateboarding dies from injuries Ontario News Ontario moving to Step 3 of reopening plan on July 16 Ontario News Ontario reports 183 new cases of COVID-19, 9 more deaths Local News Hamilton police say missing teen left home after argument with family WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Canada News Border restrictions begin to ease for fully vaccinated Canadian travellers News Canada News Top News Story Border restrictions begin to ease for fully vaccinated Canadian travellers By Shayla Vize - July 5, 2021, 10:12 am Canada is starting to loosen some travel restrictions for fully vaccinated Canadians and permanent residents. Beginning Monday, residents who have had a full course of an approved COVID-19 vaccine will be able to skip the 14-day quarantine as they return to this country. To be considered fully vaccinated, you must be eligible to enter Canada, have received the full series of an accepted COVID-19 vaccine or a combination of accepted vaccines (Phizer-BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/COVISHIELD, Johnson & Johnson), received your last dose at least 14 days prior to the day you enter Canada, and have uploaded your proof of vaccination and results of a negative COVID-19 test that is less than three days old in the ArriveCAN app. Fully vaccinated Canadians & permanent residents travelling back into the country no longer have to quarantine. Air travellers don’t have to stay 3 days at the government approved hotel. No day 8 test either. @CHCHNews #TravelRestrictions #Canada pic.twitter.com/uxLznJPQjc — Sylvie Lendvay (@sylvie_lendvay) July 5, 2021 Canada Border Services Agency warns would-be travellers still may be denied entry if they were not eligible to travel to Canada before Monday. Residents were previously under rigid travel restrictions which included testing, quarantine and a hotel stopover for travellers arriving by air. For more information from the Government of Canada regarding travel, click here. Trudeau is scheduled to speak at 11:15 a.m. He got his second COVID-19 vaccine dose earlier in the day. He and his wife got their first doses of the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine in late April. Trudeau’s wife got her shot of Moderna yesterday. Trudeau says vaccinations are a path out of the pandemic and praised Canadians in his Canada Day message for getting their shots to help life return to normal. News Canada News Top News Story Wildfire leads to evacuation order in B.C. village that set Canadian heat wave record By Andrea Lawson - July 1, 2021, 7:03 am A fast-spreading wildfire led to an immediate evacuation order Wednesday night for residents of Lytton, B.C. Mayor Jan Polderman issued the evacuation order at 6 p.m. local time. It said the wildfire was threatening structures and the safety of residents. Lytton is about a two-hour drive southwest of Kamloops. The village, which lists its population at about 250 people as of 2016, smashed a Canadian record for high temperatures three days in a row this week during an ongoing historic heat wave. Temperatures reached 49.6 Celsius. Most of Western Canada is still baking in extreme heat from that weather system. Conditions remain dangerously hot from southern and central B.C. and east through Alberta, Saskatchewan and Manitoba. B.C.’s chief coroner Lisa Lapointe says at least 486 sudden deaths have been reported to the B.C. Coroners Service since last Friday amid temperatures in the 30’s and 40’s. The Grace Anglican Church started the planning process on the centre four years ago. They are calling it “Bobby’s Place”, named after local Bobby Smylie who died from the flu in 2018 at the age of 10. The church says the centre will provide a meeting space to learn, socialize, and grow. Construction on “Bobby’s Place” will begin in a few weeks and they hope to have it finished by the Fall. Macdonald is staying at Gore Park Hamilton Owners of Glen Abbey scrap development plans after reaching an agreement… Local News Step 3 of Ontario’s Roadmap to reopen is coming 5 days… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Evening News Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen News Evening News Local News Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen By Laura Brody - December 24, 2019, 4:59 pm Hamilton police have arrested a man in connection with a two-month long investigation into stolen, high-end bikes worth more than $40 000. Police say they executed a search warrant at a home in the east end last Thursday and found 26 mountain bikes, along with bike parts, high-end skis and prohibited weapons. They believe the bikes were stolen from residential and commercial properties in Ancaster, Aldershot and Dundas. They say most of the bikes had been taken apart and the parts had been swapped, to try to disguise them. So far, police have returned 3 of the 26 bikes to their owners, and hope to return the rest of them in the next two weeks. Jason Kane, 43, of Hamilton, is facing a number of charges including two counts of possession of a prohibited weapon, and three counts of possession of stolen property. Police say the investigation is ongoing and more charges could be laid. They recommend that you record the serial number on your bike, and call police if it’s been stolen. Macdonald is staying at Gore Park Hamilton Owners of Glen Abbey scrap development plans after reaching an agreement… Local News Step 3 of Ontario’s Roadmap to reopen is coming 5 days… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Evening News Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed News Evening News Local News Hamilton Home Page News Story Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed By Laura Brody - October 21, 2019, 6:27 pm Hamilton police have identified the suspect in the city’s tenth homicide of the year, and have issued a warrant for his arrest. Twenty-nine year old Obsa Junedi Mohamed was gunned down outside of Boulevard Billiards on York Boulevard at around 1:30 Saturday morning. Police say his killer was his friend, 26-year-old Ibrahim Issak Hussen. The two men were hanging out with a group of other men for awhile before the shooting. About 10 minutes before the shooting detectives say Junedi Mohamed and Issak Hussen got into a physical altercation. Hussen goes by the street name “Seemo.” Junedi Mohamed’s street name was Nanny or Chappel. Detectives say Hussen shot Mohamed point blank in the head. The whole incident was caught on surveillance video. Surveillance images released in the media led to the driver of the getaway vehicle turning himself in to police on Saturday. That man was arrested for first degree murder and accessory after the fact to murder. Police say he participated in a lengthy interview and was released unconditionally later Saturday. But another man was also in the car and police want to speak to him. They are looking for an Asian male wearing a dark parka with fur trim on the hood. The victim was known to police. He was found by officers hiding after another shooting in the same area back in 2015. At the time he was charged with failing to comply and possession of cocaine. Issak Hussen is also known to police and investigators believe drugs are involved in this incident as well. News Evening News Local News Two Hamilton women were invited to meet Taylor Swift at the star’s Nashville mansion By Laura Brody - August 22, 2019, 5:23 pm Two young women from Hamilton were treated to an experience of a lifetime by their ultra-famous idol- Taylor Swift. The multi-grammy award winning pop star hand selected about 100 mega fans from around the world to attend a secret album preview party at her Nashville mansion and 25-year-old Nichole Ridehalgh and 17-year-old Isabella Rose both got a phone call from Swifts team. Ridehalgh was shocked when she called the call inviting her to a special event. She was asked if she could make it to Nashville in less than a week. Without being told, Ridehalgh knew she had just been invited to an event that is the pinnacle of every Taylor Swift fan’s dream- a secret session album preview at the star’s Nashville mansion. Swift has held secret sessions before the releases of several of her previous albums. Fans are picked up at a secret location and driven to her mansion. Those who attend are always mega fans who the star keeps a close eye on on social media. Getting a one on one chat with the star is something Ridehalgh will never forget. “Its 4:30 in the morning, I’m exhausted but, this is my moment. I walk into the room and I turn to my left and I see her and she says hey your Nichole right?Aand in that moment my whole world was made. Without me mentioning Canada at all, she said have a safe flight back to Canada” Swift even shared secret details about her personal life with fans. Isabella Rose is also on a first name basis with Swift. She posted on social media saying “I have loved her for nine years and I will never stop talking about how much I love her but I would not be where I am today without her.” Tonight is the release of Swift’s newest album, Lover. Ridehalgh and Rose were two of 113 fans in the world, that have already heard it. “She was lip syncing and dancing. She was just having a blast.” And that night is a night these young women will replay over and over again. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Hamilton girl, 15, struck while skateboarding dies from injuries Ontario News Ontario moving to Step 3 of reopening plan on July 16 Ontario News Ontario reports 183 new cases of COVID-19, 9 more deaths Local News Hamilton police say missing teen left home after argument with family WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Hamilton Indigenous activists are asking people to pause and reflect this Canada Day Local News Hamilton News Home Page News Story Indigenous activists are asking people to pause and reflect this Canada Day By Sylvie Lendvay - July 1, 2021, 10:02 am There will be many ceremonies across the Golden Horseshoe this Canada Day, to mourn the hundreds of children discovered in unmarked graves in residential schools across the country this past month. Indigenous activists are asking people to take some time today to reflect. Sherlene Bomberry went to the Mohawk Institute in Brantford, a former residential school, in the 1960’s. She says she never told anyone about her experience for years, but now she is speaking out. “When I heard about the 215, that’s when my body remembered. I was sitting there watching TV and started crying. I was never able to share how I really felt.” She says she has since taken back her power by going to indigenous ceremonies, using her language, and wearing traditional clothing. “I’m proud,” says Bomberry. One of the ceremonies will be held at Bayfront Park in Hamilton this afternoon. Jordan Carrier who is organizing the event says today is about coming together for healing. “It’s a tough day being Canada Day. I know a lot of proud Canadians are coming to this truth and they are not too sure where they sit with that. For myself, I’m not saying don’t ever celebrate Canada Day again, I’m just saying for this year pause and stand with us.” Carrier says non-indigenous people are welcome to come the ceremony to listen, hear and see indigenous culture. Macdonald is staying at Gore Park Hamilton Owners of Glen Abbey scrap development plans after reaching an agreement… Local News Step 3 of Ontario’s Roadmap to reopen is coming 5 days… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Home Page News Story Seven people charged with First-Degree Murder in Brantford homicide News Home Page News Story Local News Main News Story Ontario News Top News Story Seven people charged with First-Degree Murder in Brantford homicide By Sylvie Lendvay - June 24, 2021, 12:06 pm Brantford along with Provincial Police (OPP) have charged seven people with first-degree murder after a joint investigation called “Project Grantham.” The investigation was created after the homicides of 22 year-old Coby “Kareem” Carter of Hamilton, 62 year-old Dorothy Lynn Vanevery, and 64 year-old Larry Reynolds both of Brantford. On July 8, 2019 officers responded to a home on Colborne St West in Brantford and located a man, deceased. On July 18, 2019, police were called to a home on Park Road South, also in Brantford, and located a man and a woman, both dead. Brantford Police and the OPP have arrested and charged 24 year-old Abdelaziz Faiz Ibrahim of Hamilton with First-Degree Murder in connection with the death of Coby “Kareem” Carter. Six more people were arrested and charged with two counts each of First-Degree Murder and one count of Conspiracy to Commit Murder in the deaths of Lynn Vanvery and Larry Reynolds. That includes: Malik MBUYI, 20 years old of Toronto, Nathan HOWES, 31 years old of Brantford, Dylan ALRIDGE, 24 years old of North York, Terrell PHILBERT, 22 years old of York, Thomy BAEZ-EUSEBIO, 23 years old of Toronto, and Salloum JASSEM, 32 years old of Brant County. All individuals remain in custody. Investigators have determined that Vanvery and Reynolds were not the intended target. They could not confirm the bodies discovered were all children “This could be triggering for many…we always knew there were graves here.” Chief Cadmus Delorme said headstones were once there, but they were removed by the Catholic church and never put back. The Cowessess First Nation says they are treating it as a crime scene. The discovery comes less than a month after 215 bodies were found on the site of a former residential school in Kamloops, B.C. Radar searches continue around each residential school in Canada. Kerry Schmidt says one transport truck and six passenger vehicles crashed around 7 this morning on Highway 400 South of Finch Avenue. Schmidt says one of those cars was consumed by fire and the person inside was pronounced dead on scene. All other occupants sustained minor injuries. “Witnesses reported hearing screeching tires and saw the transport truck plowing in the back of slowing or stopped traffic. The collision resulted in a chain reaction.” Fatal collision: #Hwy400 SB south of Finch. Loaded transport truck collided into slowing/stopped traffic causing a 7 vehicle wreck. Investigation and cleanup will take hours. Expect delays and avoid the area. pic.twitter.com/1wD16nn3RW — OPP Highway Safety Division (@OPP_HSD) June 24, 2021 Expect delays in the southbound lanes of Highway 400 at Finch until this afternoon as it will be closed for the investigation. Macdonald is staying at Gore Park Hamilton Owners of Glen Abbey scrap development plans after reaching an agreement… Local News Step 3 of Ontario’s Roadmap to reopen is coming 5 days… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Local News Hamilton police search for rightful owners of stolen property News Local News Top News Story Hamilton police search for rightful owners of stolen property By Shayla Vize - July 9, 2021, 5:42 am Hamilton police are hoping to reconnect a large amount of stolen property with its rightful owners. Police say the goods were discovered Wednesday afternoon during a raid on a downtown home that was allegedly being used as a storage locker for stolen property. Officers seized the following items while executing a search warrant: 27 laptops 13 computer tablets 6 bicycles 3 E-bikes 3 cell phones Hamilton police say multiple charges have been laid in connection with the stolen property. Investigators say they were tipped off to the home by neighbours in the area. Residents are being reminded, ‘if you see something, say something.’ “Information is collected and resources are deployed accordingly to better serve the community,” said Hamilton police in a news release. “It is important to recognize that criminals find it difficult to operate in neighbourhoods where citizens take an active role in preventing crime.” Anyone who believes they are the rightful owner of property in the images is asked to contact Acting Sgt. David Wright by e-mail at dwright@hamiltonpolice.on.ca or by phone at 905-540-5093. Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 17.8 C Hamilton Friday, July 9, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Hamilton girl, 15, struck while skateboarding dies from injuries Ontario News Ontario moving to Step 3 of reopening plan on July 16 Ontario News Ontario reports 183 new cases of COVID-19, 9 more deaths Local News Hamilton police say missing teen left home after argument with family WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility Local News Halton Hamilton News Home Page News Story Ontario News Top News Story Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility By Sylvie Lendvay - May 10, 2021, 11:08 am The province says the eligibility to receive a COVID-19 vaccine will expand the week of May 10th to include people with “at-risk” health conditions, people who cannot work from home (Group 2), and people 40 and older. Starting Tuesday May 11 at 8 a.m, people with “at-risk” health conditions such as immune deficiencies, cancer, diabetes, and asthma will be able to book an appointment either through the provincial portal or their region’s website. Also Tuesday morning, people in Group 2 who cannot work from home including those who work in essential retail, courts and banks can book. Social workers, veterinarians and miners are also apart of the list that can be found here. Thursday May 13 at 8 a.m, people turning 40 in 2021 and older in non-hot spot communities can book a vaccine appointment at a mass immunization clinic. Halton Region has expanded its’ vaccination program to allow residents 16 and older who cannot work from home to book an appointment through the regions online portal. Halton residents 50 and older living in non-hot spot communities can also book. Wednesday May 12 eligibility opens to those 40 and older, Friday May 14 to those 30 and older, and by next week all Halton adults over the age of 16 will be eligible to book an appointment. Halton residents 16+ who cannot work from home can now book a COVID vaccine appointment… as well as anyone 50+. May 12 – 40+. May 14 – 30+. May 19 – 16+. They are following provincial criteria for expanding program based on risk… have enough supply to do it early. @CHCHNews pic.twitter.com/VYwEmaGKLO — Sylvie Lendvay (@sylvie_lendvay) May 10, 2021 Halton region says they are following provincial criteria for expanding eligibility based on who is most at risk, but they have enough supply to do it early. There are several pilot clinics across the province vaccinating residents 18 and older. Four pharmacies in Hamilton are approved to administer Moderna. Each location will receive about 150 shots a week. Adults 40 and older can still book an AstraZeneca vaccine at a participating pharmacy. All booking availability will depend on supply. Constable Frank Trasmundi with Halton Police says sometimes when people report their bicycle stolen, the owner won’t have the serial number. If that’s the case, police can’t return it or lay charges. He says downloading the app ‘529 Garage’ can help people file a report. “We will have picture of your bike, the serial number, and any distinguishing features so it will be easier for us to recover it if we find it.” says Trasmundi. Halton Police recovers 200 bikes per year on average. Only about 10-15 of them are returned. Macdonald is staying at Gore Park Hamilton Owners of Glen Abbey scrap development plans after reaching an agreement… Local News Step 3 of Ontario’s Roadmap to reopen is coming 5 days… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton If you don’t live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor Local News Halton Main News Story News If you don’t live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor By Sylvie Lendvay - December 9, 2020, 10:11 am With cases on the rise in Halton Region, Burlington’s Mayor Marianne Meed Ward residents should be concerned. “The simplest message I could give to residents is this: If you don’t live with somebody, assume that they have COVID and conduct yourself accordingly.” Even with the temptation to gather this holiday season, she is urging residents to follow public health guidelines. “Our [Burlington] numbers are going up again, a little bit. There’s been a lot of talk about a vaccine coming; we know we’re getting that but that’s not the silver bullet. That’s not the only solution. We are going to continue, for at least a year, to need to be keeping physical distance, hand washing, wearing a mask when out in public. Those measures are going to be critically important throughout 2021.” Halton reported 92 new cases of COVID-19 Tuesday. St. Anne Catholic Elementary school in Burlington has had to close down one classroom after 4 cases were reported Tuesday night. There are currently active 14 outbreaks in Halton region. The region’s Medical Officer of Health says the region continues to see community transmission. She is asking residents to avoid carpooling, and having coffee and play dates. Local News Halton News Is Halton heading back to a modified Stage 2? By Laura Brody - October 23, 2020, 8:52 pm Premier Doug Ford is concerned about Halton region’s rising case numbers and says a decision will be made by Monday whether or not to send the region back to modified Stage 2. Halton region is approaching 2,000 total COVID-19 cases; half of which have been recorded in the last two months. “We’re going to have to discuss that over the weekend and we’ll have that answer on Monday. But folks in Halton, I know they’re doing a great job. It’s concerning right now. I’ve seen the numbers go up.” said Premier Doug Ford. “The premier has been terrific to work with throughout this. We recorded 16 new cases today. That’s like 1 in 35,000 people here. I think curves on small numbers are very unreliable ways to judge the future.” said Oakville Mayor Rob Burton. Oakville has already restricted indoor group fitness classes and team sports. The modified Stage 2 would prohibit indoor dining, and close gyms, fitness centres, cinemas and performance venues. The Niagara Falls location will no longer operate on weekends. New hours will be Monday to Friday 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. Welland’s assessment centre is cutting back to Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Hours at the St. Catharines assessment centre remain the same 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. seven days a week. COVID-19 testing at these centres, which are run by Niagara Health, are by-appointment only. Here's what you should do if a tornado strikes - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 22.8 C Hamilton Friday, July 16, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Here’s what you should do if a tornado strikes Local News St. Catharines man, 21, charged with sexual assault: Niagara police Ontario News WATCH NOW: Ontario Premier surveys damage caused by tornado in Barrie Local News Hamilton man, 22, pleads guilty to manslaughter in death of Brock… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Local News Here’s what you should do if a tornado strikes News Local News Here’s what you should do if a tornado strikes By Shayla Vize - July 16, 2021, 1:27 pm Environment Canada has confirmed a tornado touched down in Barrie Thursday afternoon. The twister uprooted trees, toppled fences, ripped roofs off houses, and sent several people to hospital with injuries. Residents in the neighbourhood where the tornado cut its path were forced to make quick decisions about what to do as the twister made its way toward their homes. While this wasn’t the first time a tornado wreaked havoc in the province, residents should reacquaint themselves with what to do if a tornado hits. The Government of Canada has compiled the following safety tips to follow during a tornado. If you are in a house Go to the basement or take shelter in a small interior ground floor room such as a bathroom, closet or hallway. If you have no basement, protect yourself by taking shelter under a heavy table or desk. In all cases, stay away from windows, outside walls and doors. If you live on a farm Livestock hear and sense impending tornadoes. If your family or home is at risk, the livestock will be a non-issue. If your personal safety is not an issue, you may only have time to open routes of escape for your livestock. Open the gate, if you must, and then exit the area in a tangent direction away from the expected path of the twister. If you are in an office or apartment building Take shelter in an inner hallway or room, ideally in the basement or on the ground floor. Do not use the elevator. Stay away from windows. If you are in a gymnasium, church or auditorium Large buildings with wide-span roofs may collapse if a tornado hits. If possible, find shelter in another building. If you are in one of these buildings and cannot leave, take cover under a sturdy structure such as a table or desk. Avoid cars and mobile homes More than half of all deaths from tornadoes happen in mobile homes. Find shelter elsewhere, preferably in a building with a strong foundation. If no shelter is available, lie down in a ditch away from the car or mobile home. Beware of flooding from downpours and be prepared to move. If you are driving If you spot a tornado in the distance go to the nearest solid shelter. If the tornado is close, get out of your car and take cover in a low-lying area, such as a ditch. In all cases Get as close to the ground as possible, protect your head and watch for flying debris. Do not chase tornadoes – they are unpredictable and can change course abruptly. A tornado is deceptive. It may appear to be standing still but is, in fact, moving toward you. Khalid Ali, of St. Catharines, has been charged with three counts of sexual assault. Police say the alleged assaults took place in 2018 and 2020 in Niagara Falls and St. Catharines. Investigators say the investigation involved two female victims in separate incidents. Ali was scheduled to appear in court Friday. Police believe there may be more victims. Anyone with information regarding this investigation is asked to contact detectives at 905-688-4111, ext. 1009450. Home News Local News Hamilton man, 22, pleads guilty to manslaughter in death of Brock Beck News Local News Top News Story Hamilton man, 22, pleads guilty to manslaughter in death of Brock Beck By Shayla Vize - July 16, 2021, 12:24 pm A Hamilton man has pleaded guilty to manslaughter in the stabbing death of 20-year-old Brock Beck last year. Beck was found suffering from multiple stab wounds outside a home in Binbrook just before 2 a.m. on July 26, 2020. He was rushed to hospital where he later died. RELATED STORY Hamilton Police searching for white sedan in connection with Brock Beck murder Last November, Hamilton police charged four Hamilton-area men with second-degree murder in connection with Beck’s death. On Friday, the men appeared virtually in a Hamilton courtroom where 22-year-old Thomas Vasquez, of Hamilton, pleaded guilty to a lesser charge of manslaughter. Nineteen-year-old Petar Kunic, of Stoney Creek, also pleaded guilty to assault causing bodily harm. Charges against 18-year-old Albin Gashi, of Stoney Creek, and 18-year-old Cam-Thai Khath, of Stoney Creek, were withdrawn. Police say the murder was fueled by a road rage incident that happened earlier in the night at the intersection of Binbrook Rd. and Highway 56. According to the agreed statement of facts, Gashi, Khath, Kunic, Vasquez and another friend were travelling west on Binbrook Rd. after leaving a house party. While stopped at the intersection, the group engaged in a verbal confrontation with Beck and his friend who were in a separate vehicle. The groups initially went their separate ways, however, a short time later, Beck and his friend were confronted in the driveway of a home on Binbrook Rd. by the group of men and a fight ensued. Vasquez and Kunic will appear in court on September 14 for sentencing. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Hamilton Federal NDP leader Jagmeet Singh visits Hamilton Local News Niagara Falls bustling with activity as it moves into stage three Local News Here’s what you should do if a tornado strikes Local News St. Catharines man, 21, charged with sexual assault: Niagara police WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Canada News More than 160 unmarked graves found at another B.C. residential school site News Canada News Top News Story More than 160 unmarked graves found at another B.C. residential school site By Shayla Vize - July 13, 2021, 6:02 am (Image source: Indian Residential School History & Dialogue Centre at the University of British Columbia) More than 160 undocumented and unmarked graves have been found at the site of a former residential school near Vancouver Island. The Penelakut Tribe says the discovery was made at the site of the former Kuper Island Industrial School. The school was dubbed “Canada’s Alcatraz” because of its remote location off the coast of Chemainus, south of Nanaimo and north of Victoria. It was in operation from 1890 to 1975. A statement on behalf of Chief Joan Brown of Penelakut Tribe called for neighbouring tribes and organizations to help raise awareness and face the trauma of these acts of genocide. “We understand that many of our brothers and sisters from neighboring communities attended the Kuper Island Industrial School. We also recognize with a tremendous amount of grief and loss, that too many did not return home. It is impossible to get over acts of genocide and human rights violations. Healing is an ongoing process, and sometimes it goes well, and sometimes we lose more people because the burden is too great,” said Brown. According to the Indian Residential School History & Dialogue Centre at the University of British Columbia, two sisters drowned while trying to escape the school in 1959 and another student committed suicide in 1966. The federal government took over the administration of the school in 1969 and closed it in 1975. In 1995, a former employee pled guilty to three charges of indecent assault and gross indecency. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Here’s what you should do if a tornado strikes Local News St. Catharines man, 21, charged with sexual assault: Niagara police Ontario News WATCH NOW: Ontario Premier surveys damage caused by tornado in Barrie Local News Hamilton man, 22, pleads guilty to manslaughter in death of Brock… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Canada News Border restrictions begin to ease for fully vaccinated Canadian travellers News Canada News Top News Story Border restrictions begin to ease for fully vaccinated Canadian travellers By Shayla Vize - July 5, 2021, 10:12 am Canada is starting to loosen some travel restrictions for fully vaccinated Canadians and permanent residents. Beginning Monday, residents who have had a full course of an approved COVID-19 vaccine will be able to skip the 14-day quarantine as they return to this country. To be considered fully vaccinated, you must be eligible to enter Canada, have received the full series of an accepted COVID-19 vaccine or a combination of accepted vaccines (Phizer-BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/COVISHIELD, Johnson & Johnson), received your last dose at least 14 days prior to the day you enter Canada, and have uploaded your proof of vaccination and results of a negative COVID-19 test that is less than three days old in the ArriveCAN app. Fully vaccinated Canadians & permanent residents travelling back into the country no longer have to quarantine. Air travellers don’t have to stay 3 days at the government approved hotel. No day 8 test either. @CHCHNews #TravelRestrictions #Canada pic.twitter.com/uxLznJPQjc — Sylvie Lendvay (@sylvie_lendvay) July 5, 2021 Canada Border Services Agency warns would-be travellers still may be denied entry if they were not eligible to travel to Canada before Monday. Residents were previously under rigid travel restrictions which included testing, quarantine and a hotel stopover for travellers arriving by air. For more information from the Government of Canada regarding travel, click here. The Grace Anglican Church started the planning process on the centre four years ago. They are calling it “Bobby’s Place”, named after local Bobby Smylie who died from the flu in 2018 at the age of 10. The church says the centre will provide a meeting space to learn, socialize, and grow. Construction on “Bobby’s Place” will begin in a few weeks and they hope to have it finished by the Fall. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Here’s what you should do if a tornado strikes Local News St. Catharines man, 21, charged with sexual assault: Niagara police Ontario News WATCH NOW: Ontario Premier surveys damage caused by tornado in Barrie Local News Hamilton man, 22, pleads guilty to manslaughter in death of Brock… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Evening News Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen News Evening News Local News Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen By Laura Brody - December 24, 2019, 4:59 pm Hamilton police have arrested a man in connection with a two-month long investigation into stolen, high-end bikes worth more than $40 000. Police say they executed a search warrant at a home in the east end last Thursday and found 26 mountain bikes, along with bike parts, high-end skis and prohibited weapons. They believe the bikes were stolen from residential and commercial properties in Ancaster, Aldershot and Dundas. They say most of the bikes had been taken apart and the parts had been swapped, to try to disguise them. So far, police have returned 3 of the 26 bikes to their owners, and hope to return the rest of them in the next two weeks. Jason Kane, 43, of Hamilton, is facing a number of charges including two counts of possession of a prohibited weapon, and three counts of possession of stolen property. Police say the investigation is ongoing and more charges could be laid. They recommend that you record the serial number on your bike, and call police if it’s been stolen. Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 19.9 C Hamilton Saturday, July 17, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Hamilton Federal NDP leader Jagmeet Singh visits Hamilton Local News Niagara Falls bustling with activity as it moves into stage three Local News Here’s what you should do if a tornado strikes Local News St. Catharines man, 21, charged with sexual assault: Niagara police WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Evening News Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed News Evening News Local News Hamilton Home Page News Story Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed By Laura Brody - October 21, 2019, 6:27 pm Hamilton police have identified the suspect in the city’s tenth homicide of the year, and have issued a warrant for his arrest. Twenty-nine year old Obsa Junedi Mohamed was gunned down outside of Boulevard Billiards on York Boulevard at around 1:30 Saturday morning. Police say his killer was his friend, 26-year-old Ibrahim Issak Hussen. The two men were hanging out with a group of other men for awhile before the shooting. About 10 minutes before the shooting detectives say Junedi Mohamed and Issak Hussen got into a physical altercation. Hussen goes by the street name “Seemo.” Junedi Mohamed’s street name was Nanny or Chappel. Detectives say Hussen shot Mohamed point blank in the head. The whole incident was caught on surveillance video. Surveillance images released in the media led to the driver of the getaway vehicle turning himself in to police on Saturday. That man was arrested for first degree murder and accessory after the fact to murder. Police say he participated in a lengthy interview and was released unconditionally later Saturday. But another man was also in the car and police want to speak to him. They are looking for an Asian male wearing a dark parka with fur trim on the hood. The victim was known to police. He was found by officers hiding after another shooting in the same area back in 2015. At the time he was charged with failing to comply and possession of cocaine. Issak Hussen is also known to police and investigators believe drugs are involved in this incident as well. News Evening News Local News Two Hamilton women were invited to meet Taylor Swift at the star’s Nashville mansion By Laura Brody - August 22, 2019, 5:23 pm Two young women from Hamilton were treated to an experience of a lifetime by their ultra-famous idol- Taylor Swift. The multi-grammy award winning pop star hand selected about 100 mega fans from around the world to attend a secret album preview party at her Nashville mansion and 25-year-old Nichole Ridehalgh and 17-year-old Isabella Rose both got a phone call from Swifts team. Ridehalgh was shocked when she called the call inviting her to a special event. She was asked if she could make it to Nashville in less than a week. Without being told, Ridehalgh knew she had just been invited to an event that is the pinnacle of every Taylor Swift fan’s dream- a secret session album preview at the star’s Nashville mansion. Swift has held secret sessions before the releases of several of her previous albums. Fans are picked up at a secret location and driven to her mansion. Those who attend are always mega fans who the star keeps a close eye on on social media. Getting a one on one chat with the star is something Ridehalgh will never forget. “Its 4:30 in the morning, I’m exhausted but, this is my moment. I walk into the room and I turn to my left and I see her and she says hey your Nichole right?Aand in that moment my whole world was made. Without me mentioning Canada at all, she said have a safe flight back to Canada” Swift even shared secret details about her personal life with fans. Isabella Rose is also on a first name basis with Swift. She posted on social media saying “I have loved her for nine years and I will never stop talking about how much I love her but I would not be where I am today without her.” Tonight is the release of Swift’s newest album, Lover. Ridehalgh and Rose were two of 113 fans in the world, that have already heard it. “She was lip syncing and dancing. She was just having a blast.” And that night is a night these young women will replay over and over again. Morning Live’s Sylvie Lendvay spoke with the owner of F45 in Downtown Hamilton who cites the importance of being active during a health crisis. “Preventative health is real. What we do here is essential. We have tight protocols, we’re safe. COVID can happen anywhere so we need to make ourselves strong and fortify us against the odds of getting it.” says Justin Baker. Gyms have been closed on and off since March 2020 due to COVID-19 pandemic restrictions. Indigenous activists are asking people to pause and reflect this Canada Day - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 19.9 C Hamilton Saturday, July 17, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Hamilton Federal NDP leader Jagmeet Singh visits Hamilton Local News Niagara Falls bustling with activity as it moves into stage three Local News Here’s what you should do if a tornado strikes Local News St. Catharines man, 21, charged with sexual assault: Niagara police WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Hamilton Indigenous activists are asking people to pause and reflect this Canada Day Local News Hamilton News Home Page News Story Indigenous activists are asking people to pause and reflect this Canada Day By Sylvie Lendvay - July 1, 2021, 10:02 am There will be many ceremonies across the Golden Horseshoe this Canada Day, to mourn the hundreds of children discovered in unmarked graves in residential schools across the country this past month. Indigenous activists are asking people to take some time today to reflect. Sherlene Bomberry went to the Mohawk Institute in Brantford, a former residential school, in the 1960’s. She says she never told anyone about her experience for years, but now she is speaking out. “When I heard about the 215, that’s when my body remembered. I was sitting there watching TV and started crying. I was never able to share how I really felt.” She says she has since taken back her power by going to indigenous ceremonies, using her language, and wearing traditional clothing. “I’m proud,” says Bomberry. One of the ceremonies will be held at Bayfront Park in Hamilton this afternoon. Jordan Carrier who is organizing the event says today is about coming together for healing. “It’s a tough day being Canada Day. I know a lot of proud Canadians are coming to this truth and they are not too sure where they sit with that. For myself, I’m not saying don’t ever celebrate Canada Day again, I’m just saying for this year pause and stand with us.” Carrier says non-indigenous people are welcome to come the ceremony to listen, hear and see indigenous culture. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Here’s what you should do if a tornado strikes Local News St. Catharines man, 21, charged with sexual assault: Niagara police Ontario News WATCH NOW: Ontario Premier surveys damage caused by tornado in Barrie Local News Hamilton man, 22, pleads guilty to manslaughter in death of Brock… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Home Page News Story Seven people charged with First-Degree Murder in Brantford homicide News Home Page News Story Local News Main News Story Ontario News Top News Story Seven people charged with First-Degree Murder in Brantford homicide By Sylvie Lendvay - June 24, 2021, 12:06 pm Brantford along with Provincial Police (OPP) have charged seven people with first-degree murder after a joint investigation called “Project Grantham.” The investigation was created after the homicides of 22 year-old Coby “Kareem” Carter of Hamilton, 62 year-old Dorothy Lynn Vanevery, and 64 year-old Larry Reynolds both of Brantford. On July 8, 2019 officers responded to a home on Colborne St West in Brantford and located a man, deceased. On July 18, 2019, police were called to a home on Park Road South, also in Brantford, and located a man and a woman, both dead. Brantford Police and the OPP have arrested and charged 24 year-old Abdelaziz Faiz Ibrahim of Hamilton with First-Degree Murder in connection with the death of Coby “Kareem” Carter. Six more people were arrested and charged with two counts each of First-Degree Murder and one count of Conspiracy to Commit Murder in the deaths of Lynn Vanvery and Larry Reynolds. That includes: Malik MBUYI, 20 years old of Toronto, Nathan HOWES, 31 years old of Brantford, Dylan ALRIDGE, 24 years old of North York, Terrell PHILBERT, 22 years old of York, Thomy BAEZ-EUSEBIO, 23 years old of Toronto, and Salloum JASSEM, 32 years old of Brant County. All individuals remain in custody. Investigators have determined that Vanvery and Reynolds were not the intended target. Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 20.8 C Hamilton Friday, July 16, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Here’s what you should do if a tornado strikes Local News St. Catharines man, 21, charged with sexual assault: Niagara police Ontario News WATCH NOW: Ontario Premier surveys damage caused by tornado in Barrie Local News Hamilton man, 22, pleads guilty to manslaughter in death of Brock… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility Local News Halton Hamilton News Home Page News Story Ontario News Top News Story Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility By Sylvie Lendvay - May 10, 2021, 11:08 am The province says the eligibility to receive a COVID-19 vaccine will expand the week of May 10th to include people with “at-risk” health conditions, people who cannot work from home (Group 2), and people 40 and older. Starting Tuesday May 11 at 8 a.m, people with “at-risk” health conditions such as immune deficiencies, cancer, diabetes, and asthma will be able to book an appointment either through the provincial portal or their region’s website. Also Tuesday morning, people in Group 2 who cannot work from home including those who work in essential retail, courts and banks can book. Social workers, veterinarians and miners are also apart of the list that can be found here. Thursday May 13 at 8 a.m, people turning 40 in 2021 and older in non-hot spot communities can book a vaccine appointment at a mass immunization clinic. Halton Region has expanded its’ vaccination program to allow residents 16 and older who cannot work from home to book an appointment through the regions online portal. Halton residents 50 and older living in non-hot spot communities can also book. Wednesday May 12 eligibility opens to those 40 and older, Friday May 14 to those 30 and older, and by next week all Halton adults over the age of 16 will be eligible to book an appointment. Halton residents 16+ who cannot work from home can now book a COVID vaccine appointment… as well as anyone 50+. May 12 – 40+. May 14 – 30+. May 19 – 16+. They are following provincial criteria for expanding program based on risk… have enough supply to do it early. @CHCHNews pic.twitter.com/VYwEmaGKLO — Sylvie Lendvay (@sylvie_lendvay) May 10, 2021 Halton region says they are following provincial criteria for expanding eligibility based on who is most at risk, but they have enough supply to do it early. There are several pilot clinics across the province vaccinating residents 18 and older. Four pharmacies in Hamilton are approved to administer Moderna. Each location will receive about 150 shots a week. Adults 40 and older can still book an AstraZeneca vaccine at a participating pharmacy. All booking availability will depend on supply. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Here’s what you should do if a tornado strikes Local News St. Catharines man, 21, charged with sexual assault: Niagara police Ontario News WATCH NOW: Ontario Premier surveys damage caused by tornado in Barrie Local News Hamilton man, 22, pleads guilty to manslaughter in death of Brock… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton Halton Police are trying to prevent bicycle theft Local News Halton News Halton Police are trying to prevent bicycle theft By Sylvie Lendvay - April 19, 2021, 9:27 am Police Services across Ontario are trying to get ahead of bike thefts. Constable Frank Trasmundi with Halton Police says sometimes when people report their bicycle stolen, the owner won’t have the serial number. If that’s the case, police can’t return it or lay charges. He says downloading the app ‘529 Garage’ can help people file a report. “We will have picture of your bike, the serial number, and any distinguishing features so it will be easier for us to recover it if we find it.” says Trasmundi. Halton Police recovers 200 bikes per year on average. Only about 10-15 of them are returned. If you don't live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 22.8 C Hamilton Friday, July 16, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Here’s what you should do if a tornado strikes Local News St. Catharines man, 21, charged with sexual assault: Niagara police Ontario News WATCH NOW: Ontario Premier surveys damage caused by tornado in Barrie Local News Hamilton man, 22, pleads guilty to manslaughter in death of Brock… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton If you don’t live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor Local News Halton Main News Story News If you don’t live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor By Sylvie Lendvay - December 9, 2020, 10:11 am With cases on the rise in Halton Region, Burlington’s Mayor Marianne Meed Ward residents should be concerned. “The simplest message I could give to residents is this: If you don’t live with somebody, assume that they have COVID and conduct yourself accordingly.” Even with the temptation to gather this holiday season, she is urging residents to follow public health guidelines. “Our [Burlington] numbers are going up again, a little bit. There’s been a lot of talk about a vaccine coming; we know we’re getting that but that’s not the silver bullet. That’s not the only solution. We are going to continue, for at least a year, to need to be keeping physical distance, hand washing, wearing a mask when out in public. Those measures are going to be critically important throughout 2021.” Halton reported 92 new cases of COVID-19 Tuesday. St. Anne Catholic Elementary school in Burlington has had to close down one classroom after 4 cases were reported Tuesday night. There are currently active 14 outbreaks in Halton region. The region’s Medical Officer of Health says the region continues to see community transmission. She is asking residents to avoid carpooling, and having coffee and play dates. Local News Halton News Is Halton heading back to a modified Stage 2? By Laura Brody - October 23, 2020, 8:52 pm Premier Doug Ford is concerned about Halton region’s rising case numbers and says a decision will be made by Monday whether or not to send the region back to modified Stage 2. Halton region is approaching 2,000 total COVID-19 cases; half of which have been recorded in the last two months. “We’re going to have to discuss that over the weekend and we’ll have that answer on Monday. But folks in Halton, I know they’re doing a great job. It’s concerning right now. I’ve seen the numbers go up.” said Premier Doug Ford. “The premier has been terrific to work with throughout this. We recorded 16 new cases today. That’s like 1 in 35,000 people here. I think curves on small numbers are very unreliable ways to judge the future.” said Oakville Mayor Rob Burton. Oakville has already restricted indoor group fitness classes and team sports. The modified Stage 2 would prohibit indoor dining, and close gyms, fitness centres, cinemas and performance venues. The Niagara Falls location will no longer operate on weekends. New hours will be Monday to Friday 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. Welland’s assessment centre is cutting back to Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Hours at the St. Catharines assessment centre remain the same 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. seven days a week. COVID-19 testing at these centres, which are run by Niagara Health, are by-appointment only. Health Minister Christine Elliott says there are 43 new cases in Toronto, 25 in Peel Region, 18 in York Region, 18 in the Region of Waterloo, and 11 in Durham Region. There are currently 136 patients in intensive care with COVID-related critical illness and 84 on ventilators. The province says 120,231 doses of a COVID-19 vaccine were administered Thursday for a total of more than 18.7 million. Of the province’s 626 long-term care homes, at least five are in an outbreak including Arbour Creek Long-Term Care Centre in Hamilton, St. Joseph’s Villa in Dundas, and The Village of Tansley Woods in Burlington. An active COVID-19 outbreak indicates that the home has at least one lab-confirmed case of COVID-19 (in resident or staff) and the local public health unit or the home has declared an outbreak. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Canada & The World Canadian government announces additional funding for Hamilton affordable housing Hamilton Two Niagara casinos open for the first time in 16 months Hamilton Impacts of COVID-19 result in a short supply of student housing Hamilton A B.C. man voices outrage after a Hamilton hotel cancels his… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Local News Serial fraudster arrested in international pro wrestling scam in Hamilton News Local News Top News Story Serial fraudster arrested in international pro wrestling scam in Hamilton By Shayla Vize - July 23, 2021, 12:04 pm A serial fraudster has been arrested by Hamilton police in connection with a pro wrestling memorabilia scam. Jacob Miranda, of Hamilton, has been charged with two counts of fraud over $5,000, and one count each of fraud under $5,000 and fail to comply probation. The 29-year-old was arrested Monday following a five-month-long investigation into a number of frauds involving the online sale of pro wrestling collectibles. Investigators say the victims were from outside of Canada. “Miranda is active on pro wrestling social media sites and uses his picture when conducting business but has been known to use multiple aliases,” said Hamilton police in a news release. In 2012, Miranda was convicted on 27 charges including fraud in a nationwide concert and sporting ticket scam. In 2015, he served roughly 18 months in jail for selling fake concert tickets online and two years later, he was charged in an alleged sports memorabilia scam. Investigators believe there may be more victims. and are asking anyone with information that could help police with the investigation to contact the Hamilton Police Major Fraud Unit at 905-546-3840. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Ontario News Ontario reports 192 new cases of COVID-19 Friday Local News Serial fraudster arrested in international pro wrestling scam in Hamilton Top News Story Canadians take part in Opening Ceremony of Tokyo Olympics Local News WATCH NOW: Federal officials to make ‘major’ housing announcement in Hamilton… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Top News Story Canadians take part in Opening Ceremony of Tokyo Olympics Top News Story News World News Canadians take part in Opening Ceremony of Tokyo Olympics By Shayla Vize - July 23, 2021, 11:18 am The Opening Ceremony of the Tokyo Olympics was filled with fireworks, dancing, and a medley of songs from iconic Japanese video games. A stark difference at this year’s celebration was the lack of fans and only a limited number of athletes participated in the parade due to COVID-19 restrictions. Flag-bearers Miranda Ayim and Nathan Hirayama led a group of about 30 to 40 Canadian athletes in the parade of more than 200 nations. #TeamCanada is here 🤩🇨🇦👋#OpeningCeremony pic.twitter.com/xGYdrMZCB1 — Team Canada (@TeamCanada) July 23, 2021 Ayim is set to make her third straight Olympic appearance in women’s basketball and Hirayama will be making his Olympic debut as co-captain of the men’s rugby team. The duo’s entrance makes history as this was the first time that two athletes from different sports led Team Canada together. Canadian athletes were donning outfits by Hudson Bay which included a lightweight and water-resistant jacket, and a t-shirt made of fast-dry, lightweight jersey. In total, about 5,700 athletes took part in the parade. A wooden set of Olympic rings was the centrepiece of the stadium. They were crafted from pine and spruce trees that grew from seeds that athletes were asked to bring to the 1964 Tokyo Games. Some of the seeds came from Canada. Time for some fireworks to celebrate the athletes after all countries have entered the Olympic Stadium 🎇🎆#OpeningCeremony pic.twitter.com/KtArD673QT — Team Canada (@TeamCanada) July 23, 2021 TAGS canada olympics sports Tokyo Tokyo 2020 Share Facebook Twitter Pinterest Linkedin Email Print Previous articleHelping families in need at The Baby Depot Next articleSerial fraudster arrested in international pro wrestling scam in Hamilton Shayla Vize RELATED ARTICLESMORE FROM AUTHOR Ontario News Ontario reports 192 new cases of COVID-19 Friday Local News Serial fraudster arrested in international pro wrestling scam in Hamilton Local News GO trains resume after pedestrian struck and killed by train in Burlington Ontario News London man drowns after falling off boat: OPP Local News Niagara police investigate after man exposes himself to teen girl Local News ‘Stop the Sprawl’ protestors fight to save farmland in Hamilton from further expansion LEAVE A REPLY Cancel reply Please enter your comment! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Hamilton 50 local artists take part in a city-wide fundraiser for Joseph… Hamilton Two Row on the Grand Summer Camp Canada & The World Canadian government announces additional funding for Hamilton affordable housing Hamilton Two Niagara casinos open for the first time in 16 months WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Canada News Veteran athletes named Team Canada flag-bearers News Canada News Top News Story Veteran athletes named Team Canada flag-bearers By Shayla Vize - July 19, 2021, 9:28 am Two veteran athletes have been named Team Canada flag-bearers for the Tokyo Olympics. Miranda Ayim and Nathan Hirayama will carry the country’s flag at the opening ceremony on July 23. Ayim is set to make her third straight Olympic appearance in women’s basketball and Hirayama will be making his Olympic debut as co-captain of the men’s rugby team. The announcement was made by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau on Team Canada’s social media accounts. Ready to see who will be holding the #TeamCanada flag at the #Tokyo2020 Opening Ceremony? 👀 Here is Prime Minister @JustinTrudeau with the reveal ⤵️ pic.twitter.com/YExmszcKio — Team Canada (@TeamCanada) July 19, 2021 Tessa Virtue and Scott Moir were the first duo to share the honour of carrying the maple leaf at an Olympic Opening Ceremony at PyeongChang 2018. However, this will be the first time that two athletes from different sports will lead Team Canada together. The Grace Anglican Church started the planning process on the centre four years ago. They are calling it “Bobby’s Place”, named after local Bobby Smylie who died from the flu in 2018 at the age of 10. The church says the centre will provide a meeting space to learn, socialize, and grow. Construction on “Bobby’s Place” will begin in a few weeks and they hope to have it finished by the Fall.
