Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 20.9 C Hamilton Friday, August 13, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Canada & The World NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh outlines pre-campaign platform ahead of a looming… News Gunfire sends one of the GTA’s biggest mall into lockdown Canada & The World Hamilton City Councillor Chad Collins announces he’s running for the Federal… Ontario News Ontario reports 510 new COVID-19 cases Friday WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Evening News Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed News Evening News Local News Hamilton Home Page News Story Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed By Laura Brody - October 21, 2019, 6:27 pm Hamilton police have identified the suspect in the city’s tenth homicide of the year, and have issued a warrant for his arrest. Twenty-nine year old Obsa Junedi Mohamed was gunned down outside of Boulevard Billiards on York Boulevard at around 1:30 Saturday morning. Police say his killer was his friend, 26-year-old Ibrahim Issak Hussen. The two men were hanging out with a group of other men for awhile before the shooting. About 10 minutes before the shooting detectives say Junedi Mohamed and Issak Hussen got into a physical altercation. Hussen goes by the street name “Seemo.” Junedi Mohamed’s street name was Nanny or Chappel. Detectives say Hussen shot Mohamed point blank in the head. The whole incident was caught on surveillance video. Surveillance images released in the media led to the driver of the getaway vehicle turning himself in to police on Saturday. That man was arrested for first degree murder and accessory after the fact to murder. Police say he participated in a lengthy interview and was released unconditionally later Saturday. But another man was also in the car and police want to speak to him. They are looking for an Asian male wearing a dark parka with fur trim on the hood. The victim was known to police. He was found by officers hiding after another shooting in the same area back in 2015. At the time he was charged with failing to comply and possession of cocaine. Issak Hussen is also known to police and investigators believe drugs are involved in this incident as well. News Evening News Local News Two Hamilton women were invited to meet Taylor Swift at the star’s Nashville mansion By Laura Brody - August 22, 2019, 5:23 pm Two young women from Hamilton were treated to an experience of a lifetime by their ultra-famous idol- Taylor Swift. The multi-grammy award winning pop star hand selected about 100 mega fans from around the world to attend a secret album preview party at her Nashville mansion and 25-year-old Nichole Ridehalgh and 17-year-old Isabella Rose both got a phone call from Swifts team. Ridehalgh was shocked when she called the call inviting her to a special event. She was asked if she could make it to Nashville in less than a week. Without being told, Ridehalgh knew she had just been invited to an event that is the pinnacle of every Taylor Swift fan’s dream- a secret session album preview at the star’s Nashville mansion. Swift has held secret sessions before the releases of several of her previous albums. Fans are picked up at a secret location and driven to her mansion. Those who attend are always mega fans who the star keeps a close eye on on social media. Getting a one on one chat with the star is something Ridehalgh will never forget. “Its 4:30 in the morning, I’m exhausted but, this is my moment. I walk into the room and I turn to my left and I see her and she says hey your Nichole right?Aand in that moment my whole world was made. Without me mentioning Canada at all, she said have a safe flight back to Canada” Swift even shared secret details about her personal life with fans. Isabella Rose is also on a first name basis with Swift. She posted on social media saying “I have loved her for nine years and I will never stop talking about how much I love her but I would not be where I am today without her.” Tonight is the release of Swift’s newest album, Lover. Ridehalgh and Rose were two of 113 fans in the world, that have already heard it. “She was lip syncing and dancing. She was just having a blast.” And that night is a night these young women will replay over and over again. Police launched an investigation back in July into the distribution of illegal drugs in Port Colborne. Detectives executed two search warrants in the area of King and Union streets and seized roughly $2,100 worth of blue fentanyl and $700 worth of cocaine. Shane Beauregard, 47, Kelly Flowers, 42, and Jason Nagy, 43, were arrested and all face drug trafficking charges. Anyone with further information that could help police with the investigation is asked to contact detectives at 905-688-4111, ext. 1023300. Earlier this month, police launched an investigation into the theft of motor vehicles throughout the city. Police say a coordinated effort between officers and detectives led to the recovery of five vehicles valued at roughly $92,500. Bradley Walsom, 34, was arrested and charged with theft of motor vehicle and possession of stolen property. He appeared for a bail hearing on Wednesday and was remanded into custody pending his next court appearance on Friday. Anyone with additional information that could help police with the investigation is asked to contact Const. Cody Cole at 905-688-4111, ext. 1008894. Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 20.9 C Hamilton Saturday, August 14, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Canada & The World NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh outlines pre-campaign platform ahead of a looming… News Gunfire sends one of the GTA’s biggest mall into lockdown Canada & The World Hamilton City Councillor Chad Collins announces he’s running for the Federal… Ontario News Ontario reports 510 new COVID-19 cases Friday WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility Local News Halton Hamilton News Home Page News Story Ontario News Top News Story Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility By Sylvie Lendvay - May 10, 2021, 11:08 am The province says the eligibility to receive a COVID-19 vaccine will expand the week of May 10th to include people with “at-risk” health conditions, people who cannot work from home (Group 2), and people 40 and older. Starting Tuesday May 11 at 8 a.m, people with “at-risk” health conditions such as immune deficiencies, cancer, diabetes, and asthma will be able to book an appointment either through the provincial portal or their region’s website. Also Tuesday morning, people in Group 2 who cannot work from home including those who work in essential retail, courts and banks can book. Social workers, veterinarians and miners are also apart of the list that can be found here. Thursday May 13 at 8 a.m, people turning 40 in 2021 and older in non-hot spot communities can book a vaccine appointment at a mass immunization clinic. Halton Region has expanded its’ vaccination program to allow residents 16 and older who cannot work from home to book an appointment through the regions online portal. Halton residents 50 and older living in non-hot spot communities can also book. Wednesday May 12 eligibility opens to those 40 and older, Friday May 14 to those 30 and older, and by next week all Halton adults over the age of 16 will be eligible to book an appointment. Halton residents 16+ who cannot work from home can now book a COVID vaccine appointment… as well as anyone 50+. May 12 – 40+. May 14 – 30+. May 19 – 16+. They are following provincial criteria for expanding program based on risk… have enough supply to do it early. @CHCHNews pic.twitter.com/VYwEmaGKLO — Sylvie Lendvay (@sylvie_lendvay) May 10, 2021 Halton region says they are following provincial criteria for expanding eligibility based on who is most at risk, but they have enough supply to do it early. There are several pilot clinics across the province vaccinating residents 18 and older. Four pharmacies in Hamilton are approved to administer Moderna. Each location will receive about 150 shots a week. Adults 40 and older can still book an AstraZeneca vaccine at a participating pharmacy. All booking availability will depend on supply. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Canada & The World NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh outlines pre-campaign platform ahead of a looming… News Gunfire sends one of the GTA’s biggest mall into lockdown Canada & The World Hamilton City Councillor Chad Collins announces he’s running for the Federal… Ontario News Ontario reports 510 new COVID-19 cases Friday WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton Halton Police are trying to prevent bicycle theft Local News Halton News Halton Police are trying to prevent bicycle theft By Sylvie Lendvay - April 19, 2021, 9:27 am Police Services across Ontario are trying to get ahead of bike thefts. Constable Frank Trasmundi with Halton Police says sometimes when people report their bicycle stolen, the owner won’t have the serial number. If that’s the case, police can’t return it or lay charges. He says downloading the app ‘529 Garage’ can help people file a report. “We will have picture of your bike, the serial number, and any distinguishing features so it will be easier for us to recover it if we find it.” says Trasmundi. Halton Police recovers 200 bikes per year on average. Only about 10-15 of them are returned. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Canada & The World NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh outlines pre-campaign platform ahead of a looming… News Gunfire sends one of the GTA’s biggest mall into lockdown Canada & The World Hamilton City Councillor Chad Collins announces he’s running for the Federal… Ontario News Ontario reports 510 new COVID-19 cases Friday WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton If you don’t live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor Local News Halton Main News Story News If you don’t live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor By Sylvie Lendvay - December 9, 2020, 10:11 am With cases on the rise in Halton Region, Burlington’s Mayor Marianne Meed Ward residents should be concerned. “The simplest message I could give to residents is this: If you don’t live with somebody, assume that they have COVID and conduct yourself accordingly.” Even with the temptation to gather this holiday season, she is urging residents to follow public health guidelines. “Our [Burlington] numbers are going up again, a little bit. There’s been a lot of talk about a vaccine coming; we know we’re getting that but that’s not the silver bullet. That’s not the only solution. We are going to continue, for at least a year, to need to be keeping physical distance, hand washing, wearing a mask when out in public. Those measures are going to be critically important throughout 2021.” Halton reported 92 new cases of COVID-19 Tuesday. St. Anne Catholic Elementary school in Burlington has had to close down one classroom after 4 cases were reported Tuesday night. There are currently active 14 outbreaks in Halton region. The region’s Medical Officer of Health says the region continues to see community transmission. She is asking residents to avoid carpooling, and having coffee and play dates. Local News Halton News Is Halton heading back to a modified Stage 2? By Laura Brody - October 23, 2020, 8:52 pm Premier Doug Ford is concerned about Halton region’s rising case numbers and says a decision will be made by Monday whether or not to send the region back to modified Stage 2. Halton region is approaching 2,000 total COVID-19 cases; half of which have been recorded in the last two months. “We’re going to have to discuss that over the weekend and we’ll have that answer on Monday. But folks in Halton, I know they’re doing a great job. It’s concerning right now. I’ve seen the numbers go up.” said Premier Doug Ford. “The premier has been terrific to work with throughout this. We recorded 16 new cases today. That’s like 1 in 35,000 people here. I think curves on small numbers are very unreliable ways to judge the future.” said Oakville Mayor Rob Burton. Oakville has already restricted indoor group fitness classes and team sports. The modified Stage 2 would prohibit indoor dining, and close gyms, fitness centres, cinemas and performance venues. Local News Hamilton News Top News Story City Planning Committee approves rental housing license pilot program in parts of Hamilton By Dominick Nagy - August 10, 2021, 9:25 pm Hamilton’s planning committee has voted to move forward with a pilot project that will see rental housing units licensed in wards near McMaster and Mohawk College. It comes as the local real estate association told city councilors today that Hamilton is unfortunately on track to becoming the best place to build illegal rental units. Nicole Martin reports. The Niagara Falls location will no longer operate on weekends. New hours will be Monday to Friday 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. Welland’s assessment centre is cutting back to Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Hours at the St. Catharines assessment centre remain the same 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. seven days a week. COVID-19 testing at these centres, which are run by Niagara Health, are by-appointment only. Police say they executed a search warrant on Aug. 17 at an East End business where they uncovered the facility. Investigators found over 30,000 packages of edibles valued over $700,000, oil hash and shatter products valued over $100,000, cannabis valued over $175,000, and unpackaged edibles valued over $70,000. Two people were arrested on site and have been released to wait for their court date. Cannabis manufacturing facilities are required to be government regulated to ensure safety of consumers. Police ask anyone with more information to contact them. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Hamilton man to bike ride over 1,000 km for mental illness Local News Back to school shopping Local News Hamilton city council considering mandatory vaccines for all city employees Local News Hamilton Police shut down illegal cannabis edible manufacturing facility WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Local News Man arrested after reprogramming car theft in Oakville News Local News Man arrested after reprogramming car theft in Oakville By Anastasia Anokye - August 20, 2021, 12:52 pm Halton Police have arrested a man after a reprogramming car theft in Oakville. Police say they observed a Nissan Rogue travelling beside a Lexus RX350 near Trafalgar Rd. and Dundas St. around 2:50 a.m. yesterday. The cars split up after a short time. Officers conducted a traffic stop on the Nissan due to recent reports of Lexus RX350 thefts in the area. Investigations revealed that the driver had seven blank Lexus key fobs known to facilitate car thefts. Officers were able to locate the Lexus RX350 in an Oakville residential area and return it to its owner. 42-year-old Luis Ahumada Prieto of Quebec has been charged with seven counts of possession of an automobile master key and possession of a substance. Preito was released on an Undertaking. Police are asking residents to take extra caution to avoid their car being stolen: Park your vehicle in a locked and secured garage Install an on-board diagnostic blocker Install a steering wheel lock device Combine the above measures with an aftermarket GPS tracking device Place vehicle key fob inside a radio frequency shielding bag when not in use Lock your vehicle at all times Equip your vehicle with an alarm Install home security cameras that capture the exterior of your residence, including the driveway Take steps to conceal the Vehicle Identification Number (V.I.N.) It is the highest daily-tally reported since June 6. The data is based on more than 28,600 tests completed on the previous day with an approximate positivity rate of 2.2 per cent. The province says 426 of the positive cases were in unvaccinated individuals, 64 were in partially vaccinated and 103 were fully vaccinated. There are currently 135 patients in intensive care with COVID-related critical illness and 77 on ventilators. The province says 45,748 doses of a COVID-19 vaccine were administered Thursday for a total of more than 20 million. There are 9,700,285 fully vaccinated people in Ontario. Here are the COVID-19 numbers for our region: Hamilton 22,322 total cases – up 57 from previous 20,982 resolved cases 381 active cases 404 deaths 51 in hospital Niagara Region 16,507 total cases – up 17 from previous 15,942 resolved cases 144 active cases 420 deaths 5 in hospital Halton Region 18,492 total cases – up 23 from previous 18,131 resolved cases 124 active cases 237 deaths 3 in hospital Brant 3,545 total cases – up 14 from previous 3,467 resolved cases 58 active cases 20 deaths 15 in hospital Haldimand-Norfolk 2,781 total cases – up 1 from previous 2,704 resolved cases 23 active cases 48 deaths TAGS brant COVID-19 haldimand halton hamilton niagara norfolk ontario Share Facebook Twitter Pinterest Linkedin Email Print Previous articleEverything Mickey Mouse Exhibition at The Grimsby Museum Next articleMan arrested after reprogramming car theft in Oakville Anastasia Anokye RELATED ARTICLESMORE FROM AUTHOR Local News Hamilton man to bike ride over 1,000 km for mental illness Local News Back to school shopping Local News Hamilton city council considering mandatory vaccines for all city employees Local News Hamilton Police shut down illegal cannabis edible manufacturing facility Canada U.S. extends non-essential border travel restrictions Local News Oakville cyclist seriously injured after hit-and-run LEAVE A REPLY Cancel reply Please enter your comment! The Department of Homeland Security tweeted about the travel extensions this morning. They cited the Delta variant as a deciding factor. Restrictions were originally set to expire Aug. 21. To minimize the spread of #COVID19, including the Delta variant, the United States is extending restrictions on non-essential travel at our land and ferry crossings with Canada and Mexico through September 21, while continuing to ensure the flow of essential trade and travel. — Homeland Security (@DHSgov) August 20, 2021 DHS says travel for essential purposes will continue. The restriction on non-essential travel has been in place since March 21. Canada opened its border to non-essential travellers from the U.S. with full vaccination status. The Grace Anglican Church started the planning process on the centre four years ago. They are calling it “Bobby’s Place”, named after local Bobby Smylie who died from the flu in 2018 at the age of 10. The church says the centre will provide a meeting space to learn, socialize, and grow. Construction on “Bobby’s Place” will begin in a few weeks and they hope to have it finished by the Fall. Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 22.6 C Hamilton Saturday, August 21, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Hamilton man to bike ride over 1,000 km for mental illness Local News Back to school shopping Local News Hamilton city council considering mandatory vaccines for all city employees Local News Hamilton Police shut down illegal cannabis edible manufacturing facility WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Evening News Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen News Evening News Local News Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen By Laura Brody - December 24, 2019, 4:59 pm Hamilton police have arrested a man in connection with a two-month long investigation into stolen, high-end bikes worth more than $40 000. Police say they executed a search warrant at a home in the east end last Thursday and found 26 mountain bikes, along with bike parts, high-end skis and prohibited weapons. They believe the bikes were stolen from residential and commercial properties in Ancaster, Aldershot and Dundas. They say most of the bikes had been taken apart and the parts had been swapped, to try to disguise them. So far, police have returned 3 of the 26 bikes to their owners, and hope to return the rest of them in the next two weeks. Jason Kane, 43, of Hamilton, is facing a number of charges including two counts of possession of a prohibited weapon, and three counts of possession of stolen property. Police say the investigation is ongoing and more charges could be laid. They recommend that you record the serial number on your bike, and call police if it’s been stolen. Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 22.6 C Hamilton Saturday, August 21, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Hamilton man to bike ride over 1,000 km for mental illness Local News Back to school shopping Local News Hamilton city council considering mandatory vaccines for all city employees Local News Hamilton Police shut down illegal cannabis edible manufacturing facility WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Evening News Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed News Evening News Local News Hamilton Home Page News Story Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed By Laura Brody - October 21, 2019, 6:27 pm Hamilton police have identified the suspect in the city’s tenth homicide of the year, and have issued a warrant for his arrest. Twenty-nine year old Obsa Junedi Mohamed was gunned down outside of Boulevard Billiards on York Boulevard at around 1:30 Saturday morning. Police say his killer was his friend, 26-year-old Ibrahim Issak Hussen. The two men were hanging out with a group of other men for awhile before the shooting. About 10 minutes before the shooting detectives say Junedi Mohamed and Issak Hussen got into a physical altercation. Hussen goes by the street name “Seemo.” Junedi Mohamed’s street name was Nanny or Chappel. Detectives say Hussen shot Mohamed point blank in the head. The whole incident was caught on surveillance video. Surveillance images released in the media led to the driver of the getaway vehicle turning himself in to police on Saturday. That man was arrested for first degree murder and accessory after the fact to murder. Police say he participated in a lengthy interview and was released unconditionally later Saturday. But another man was also in the car and police want to speak to him. They are looking for an Asian male wearing a dark parka with fur trim on the hood. The victim was known to police. He was found by officers hiding after another shooting in the same area back in 2015. At the time he was charged with failing to comply and possession of cocaine. Issak Hussen is also known to police and investigators believe drugs are involved in this incident as well. News Evening News Local News Two Hamilton women were invited to meet Taylor Swift at the star’s Nashville mansion By Laura Brody - August 22, 2019, 5:23 pm Two young women from Hamilton were treated to an experience of a lifetime by their ultra-famous idol- Taylor Swift. The multi-grammy award winning pop star hand selected about 100 mega fans from around the world to attend a secret album preview party at her Nashville mansion and 25-year-old Nichole Ridehalgh and 17-year-old Isabella Rose both got a phone call from Swifts team. Ridehalgh was shocked when she called the call inviting her to a special event. She was asked if she could make it to Nashville in less than a week. Without being told, Ridehalgh knew she had just been invited to an event that is the pinnacle of every Taylor Swift fan’s dream- a secret session album preview at the star’s Nashville mansion. Swift has held secret sessions before the releases of several of her previous albums. Fans are picked up at a secret location and driven to her mansion. Those who attend are always mega fans who the star keeps a close eye on on social media. Getting a one on one chat with the star is something Ridehalgh will never forget. “Its 4:30 in the morning, I’m exhausted but, this is my moment. I walk into the room and I turn to my left and I see her and she says hey your Nichole right?Aand in that moment my whole world was made. Without me mentioning Canada at all, she said have a safe flight back to Canada” Swift even shared secret details about her personal life with fans. Isabella Rose is also on a first name basis with Swift. She posted on social media saying “I have loved her for nine years and I will never stop talking about how much I love her but I would not be where I am today without her.” Tonight is the release of Swift’s newest album, Lover. Ridehalgh and Rose were two of 113 fans in the world, that have already heard it. “She was lip syncing and dancing. She was just having a blast.” And that night is a night these young women will replay over and over again. The Ontario Life Saving Society says not wearing a life jacket was a factor in 88% of boat-related deaths. Alcohol played a part in 40% of boat-related deaths. There were 50 search and rescue calls in the Niagara Region in the year 2020. There have been 33 calls in 2021 so far. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Hamilton man to bike ride over 1,000 km for mental illness Local News Back to school shopping Local News Hamilton city council considering mandatory vaccines for all city employees Local News Hamilton Police shut down illegal cannabis edible manufacturing facility WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Local News Oakville cyclist seriously injured after hit-and-run News Local News Top News Story Oakville cyclist seriously injured after hit-and-run By Anastasia Anokye - August 20, 2021, 7:24 am Halton Police have charged the driver involved in an Oakville hit-and-run resulting in serious injuries last night. Halton Police responded to the incident around 9 p.m. on Strathcona Ave. and Lakeshore Rd. Police say a cyclist was hit by a Jeep that fled the scene. The 42-year-old man was transported to Hamilton General for head trauma. 60-year-old Mary Stefanac of Burlington has been charged with impaired driving offences, including having a blood concentration of 80 mg/100ml and above. She has also has charged with failure to stop after an accident causing bodily harm. Anyone with more information is asked to contact the police. Police responded to reports of an assault at an address on Colborne St. on Wednesday. Investigators learned a man had entered the garage of a resident and stated he was looking for his cat. When he was asked to leave, the man allegedly punched the homeowner before leaving the area on foot. Officers arrived on scene and told the man he was under arrest. However, police say the 51-year-old man would not comply with officers and resisted arrest. He was taken into custody and has been charged with assault and resist arrest. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Hamilton man to bike ride over 1,000 km for mental illness Local News Back to school shopping Local News Hamilton city council considering mandatory vaccines for all city employees Local News Hamilton Police shut down illegal cannabis edible manufacturing facility WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility Local News Halton Hamilton News Home Page News Story Ontario News Top News Story Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility By Sylvie Lendvay - May 10, 2021, 11:08 am The province says the eligibility to receive a COVID-19 vaccine will expand the week of May 10th to include people with “at-risk” health conditions, people who cannot work from home (Group 2), and people 40 and older. Starting Tuesday May 11 at 8 a.m, people with “at-risk” health conditions such as immune deficiencies, cancer, diabetes, and asthma will be able to book an appointment either through the provincial portal or their region’s website. Also Tuesday morning, people in Group 2 who cannot work from home including those who work in essential retail, courts and banks can book. Social workers, veterinarians and miners are also apart of the list that can be found here. Thursday May 13 at 8 a.m, people turning 40 in 2021 and older in non-hot spot communities can book a vaccine appointment at a mass immunization clinic. Halton Region has expanded its’ vaccination program to allow residents 16 and older who cannot work from home to book an appointment through the regions online portal. Halton residents 50 and older living in non-hot spot communities can also book. Wednesday May 12 eligibility opens to those 40 and older, Friday May 14 to those 30 and older, and by next week all Halton adults over the age of 16 will be eligible to book an appointment. Halton residents 16+ who cannot work from home can now book a COVID vaccine appointment… as well as anyone 50+. May 12 – 40+. May 14 – 30+. May 19 – 16+. They are following provincial criteria for expanding program based on risk… have enough supply to do it early. @CHCHNews pic.twitter.com/VYwEmaGKLO — Sylvie Lendvay (@sylvie_lendvay) May 10, 2021 Halton region says they are following provincial criteria for expanding eligibility based on who is most at risk, but they have enough supply to do it early. There are several pilot clinics across the province vaccinating residents 18 and older. Four pharmacies in Hamilton are approved to administer Moderna. Each location will receive about 150 shots a week. Adults 40 and older can still book an AstraZeneca vaccine at a participating pharmacy. All booking availability will depend on supply. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Hamilton man to bike ride over 1,000 km for mental illness Local News Back to school shopping Local News Hamilton city council considering mandatory vaccines for all city employees Local News Hamilton Police shut down illegal cannabis edible manufacturing facility WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton Halton Police are trying to prevent bicycle theft Local News Halton News Halton Police are trying to prevent bicycle theft By Sylvie Lendvay - April 19, 2021, 9:27 am Police Services across Ontario are trying to get ahead of bike thefts. Constable Frank Trasmundi with Halton Police says sometimes when people report their bicycle stolen, the owner won’t have the serial number. If that’s the case, police can’t return it or lay charges. He says downloading the app ‘529 Garage’ can help people file a report. “We will have picture of your bike, the serial number, and any distinguishing features so it will be easier for us to recover it if we find it.” says Trasmundi. Halton Police recovers 200 bikes per year on average. Only about 10-15 of them are returned. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Hamilton man to bike ride over 1,000 km for mental illness Local News Back to school shopping Local News Hamilton city council considering mandatory vaccines for all city employees Local News Hamilton Police shut down illegal cannabis edible manufacturing facility WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton If you don’t live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor Local News Halton Main News Story News If you don’t live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor By Sylvie Lendvay - December 9, 2020, 10:11 am With cases on the rise in Halton Region, Burlington’s Mayor Marianne Meed Ward residents should be concerned. “The simplest message I could give to residents is this: If you don’t live with somebody, assume that they have COVID and conduct yourself accordingly.” Even with the temptation to gather this holiday season, she is urging residents to follow public health guidelines. “Our [Burlington] numbers are going up again, a little bit. There’s been a lot of talk about a vaccine coming; we know we’re getting that but that’s not the silver bullet. That’s not the only solution. We are going to continue, for at least a year, to need to be keeping physical distance, hand washing, wearing a mask when out in public. Those measures are going to be critically important throughout 2021.” Halton reported 92 new cases of COVID-19 Tuesday. St. Anne Catholic Elementary school in Burlington has had to close down one classroom after 4 cases were reported Tuesday night. There are currently active 14 outbreaks in Halton region. The region’s Medical Officer of Health says the region continues to see community transmission. She is asking residents to avoid carpooling, and having coffee and play dates. Local News Halton News Is Halton heading back to a modified Stage 2? By Laura Brody - October 23, 2020, 8:52 pm Premier Doug Ford is concerned about Halton region’s rising case numbers and says a decision will be made by Monday whether or not to send the region back to modified Stage 2. Halton region is approaching 2,000 total COVID-19 cases; half of which have been recorded in the last two months. “We’re going to have to discuss that over the weekend and we’ll have that answer on Monday. But folks in Halton, I know they’re doing a great job. It’s concerning right now. I’ve seen the numbers go up.” said Premier Doug Ford. “The premier has been terrific to work with throughout this. We recorded 16 new cases today. That’s like 1 in 35,000 people here. I think curves on small numbers are very unreliable ways to judge the future.” said Oakville Mayor Rob Burton. Oakville has already restricted indoor group fitness classes and team sports. The modified Stage 2 would prohibit indoor dining, and close gyms, fitness centres, cinemas and performance venues. Local News Hamilton News Police are looking for a driver after a near head-on collision in Brant County By Dominick Nagy - August 12, 2021, 9:10 pm The jaw dropping near head on collision caught on camera in Brant county has police searching for the reckless driver, and safety experts sounding the alarm. While the dash cam footage is shocking, those who live near Cockshutt road just outside Norfolk county say it’s not surprising considering the dangerous driving they see regularly. Kelly Botelho has the details. The Niagara Falls location will no longer operate on weekends. New hours will be Monday to Friday 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. Welland’s assessment centre is cutting back to Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Hours at the St. Catharines assessment centre remain the same 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. seven days a week. COVID-19 testing at these centres, which are run by Niagara Health, are by-appointment only. Home Local 75 year-old women dead after being found unresponsive at Sunset Beach Local News Local News Main News Story Ontario News Top News Story 75 year-old women dead after being found unresponsive at Sunset Beach By Manesa Dhanabalan - August 27, 2021, 10:02 am Niagara Police say a 75 year-old St. Catharines women is dead after she was found unresponsive in the water at Sunset beach yesterday. Officers arrived to Sunset Beach on Lombardy Avenue around 3:50 pm. Members of the public called police after finding the women just off the beach. By-standers and crews performed life-saving efforts before the women was taken to a local hospital in critical condition. She later died in hospital. After investigating police say there is reason to believe the women suffered a medical event just before entering the water. Police say foul play is not suspected. The coroner is continuing to investigate the incident. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Trudeau takes a shot at Premier Ford over vaccine passports Local News Moving day at McMaster, students are back in residence for the… Local News Ontario reports 781 new COVID-19 cases today Local News 40 year-old man charged with sexual assault WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Canada & The World Evacuation flights resume in Afghanistan News Canada & The World Top News Story World World News Evacuation flights resume in Afghanistan By Manesa Dhanabalan - August 27, 2021, 8:16 am Evacuation flights from Afghanistan have resumed with new urgency, a day after two suicide bombings targeted thousands of desperate people fleeing the Taliban’s takeover. The United States says further attempted attacks are expected ahead of the August 31st deadline for foreign troops to leave, ending America’s longest war. Kabul residents say several flights took off Friday morning. Thursday’s bombings near Kabul’s international airport killed at least 95 afghans and 13 u-s troop members. Officials say the actual death toll is even higher because others were involved in evacuating bodies. Ottawa officials confirm no Canadian military members were hurt. Acting chief of defence staff general Wayne Eyre says it is heartbreaking that Canadian soldiers could not stay longer in Afghanistan to rescue everyone who was so desperate to leave the war-torn country. An unknown number of Canadians and their families remain trapped in Afghanistan, after the federal government announced the end of its evacuation mission yesterday. Canada boarded around 37-hundred Canadian nationals and afghan refugees onto evacuation flights in recent weeks. But starting on Monday, they will no longer have to quarantine upon arrival, even if they have not been fully vaccinated. Many British Canadians were frustrated after being snubbed by the plan to ease quarantine restrictions for entry to England and Scotland last month. The United Kingdom announced on July 28th that fully vaccinated travelers from the United States or Europe would not have to quarantine upon arrival. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Ontario reports 781 new COVID-19 cases today Local News 40 year-old man charged with sexual assault News Kale salad blends and Chopped Salad Kits recall in Ontario Local 75 year-old women dead after being found unresponsive at Sunset Beach WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Canada News Last Canadian military aircraft has left Kabul News Canada News Top News Story World News Last Canadian military aircraft has left Kabul By Anastasia Anokye - August 26, 2021, 9:16 am Acting Chief of the Defence Staff General Wayne Eyre says the last Canadian military aircraft flew out of Kabul today. Canada evacuated around 3,700 people from Afghanistan, which fell to the Taliban earlier this month. At a briefing this morning, Eyre said Canada stayed in Afghanistan as long as it could. He added that it is heartbreaking the military could not stay longer and rescue more Afghans. The majority of Canadian personnel left Kabul airport around 12:00 a.m. Eastern time. The White House reports 13,400 people were evacuated in 24 hours from early this morning on Washington time. That included 5,100 people aboard U-S military planes and 8,300 on coalition and partner aircraft. The Grace Anglican Church started the planning process on the centre four years ago. They are calling it “Bobby’s Place”, named after local Bobby Smylie who died from the flu in 2018 at the age of 10. The church says the centre will provide a meeting space to learn, socialize, and grow. Construction on “Bobby’s Place” will begin in a few weeks and they hope to have it finished by the Fall. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Trudeau takes a shot at Premier Ford over vaccine passports Local News Moving day at McMaster, students are back in residence for the… Local News Ontario reports 781 new COVID-19 cases today Local News 40 year-old man charged with sexual assault WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Evening News Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen News Evening News Local News Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen By Laura Brody - December 24, 2019, 4:59 pm Hamilton police have arrested a man in connection with a two-month long investigation into stolen, high-end bikes worth more than $40 000. Police say they executed a search warrant at a home in the east end last Thursday and found 26 mountain bikes, along with bike parts, high-end skis and prohibited weapons. They believe the bikes were stolen from residential and commercial properties in Ancaster, Aldershot and Dundas. They say most of the bikes had been taken apart and the parts had been swapped, to try to disguise them. So far, police have returned 3 of the 26 bikes to their owners, and hope to return the rest of them in the next two weeks. Jason Kane, 43, of Hamilton, is facing a number of charges including two counts of possession of a prohibited weapon, and three counts of possession of stolen property. Police say the investigation is ongoing and more charges could be laid. They recommend that you record the serial number on your bike, and call police if it’s been stolen. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Trudeau takes a shot at Premier Ford over vaccine passports Local News Moving day at McMaster, students are back in residence for the… Local News Ontario reports 781 new COVID-19 cases today Local News 40 year-old man charged with sexual assault WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Evening News Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed News Evening News Local News Hamilton Home Page News Story Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed By Laura Brody - October 21, 2019, 6:27 pm Hamilton police have identified the suspect in the city’s tenth homicide of the year, and have issued a warrant for his arrest. Twenty-nine year old Obsa Junedi Mohamed was gunned down outside of Boulevard Billiards on York Boulevard at around 1:30 Saturday morning. Police say his killer was his friend, 26-year-old Ibrahim Issak Hussen. The two men were hanging out with a group of other men for awhile before the shooting. About 10 minutes before the shooting detectives say Junedi Mohamed and Issak Hussen got into a physical altercation. Hussen goes by the street name “Seemo.” Junedi Mohamed’s street name was Nanny or Chappel. Detectives say Hussen shot Mohamed point blank in the head. The whole incident was caught on surveillance video. Surveillance images released in the media led to the driver of the getaway vehicle turning himself in to police on Saturday. That man was arrested for first degree murder and accessory after the fact to murder. Police say he participated in a lengthy interview and was released unconditionally later Saturday. But another man was also in the car and police want to speak to him. They are looking for an Asian male wearing a dark parka with fur trim on the hood. The victim was known to police. He was found by officers hiding after another shooting in the same area back in 2015. At the time he was charged with failing to comply and possession of cocaine. Issak Hussen is also known to police and investigators believe drugs are involved in this incident as well. News Evening News Local News Two Hamilton women were invited to meet Taylor Swift at the star’s Nashville mansion By Laura Brody - August 22, 2019, 5:23 pm Two young women from Hamilton were treated to an experience of a lifetime by their ultra-famous idol- Taylor Swift. The multi-grammy award winning pop star hand selected about 100 mega fans from around the world to attend a secret album preview party at her Nashville mansion and 25-year-old Nichole Ridehalgh and 17-year-old Isabella Rose both got a phone call from Swifts team. Ridehalgh was shocked when she called the call inviting her to a special event. She was asked if she could make it to Nashville in less than a week. Without being told, Ridehalgh knew she had just been invited to an event that is the pinnacle of every Taylor Swift fan’s dream- a secret session album preview at the star’s Nashville mansion. Swift has held secret sessions before the releases of several of her previous albums. Fans are picked up at a secret location and driven to her mansion. Those who attend are always mega fans who the star keeps a close eye on on social media. Getting a one on one chat with the star is something Ridehalgh will never forget. “Its 4:30 in the morning, I’m exhausted but, this is my moment. I walk into the room and I turn to my left and I see her and she says hey your Nichole right?Aand in that moment my whole world was made. Without me mentioning Canada at all, she said have a safe flight back to Canada” Swift even shared secret details about her personal life with fans. Isabella Rose is also on a first name basis with Swift. She posted on social media saying “I have loved her for nine years and I will never stop talking about how much I love her but I would not be where I am today without her.” Tonight is the release of Swift’s newest album, Lover. Ridehalgh and Rose were two of 113 fans in the world, that have already heard it. “She was lip syncing and dancing. She was just having a blast.” And that night is a night these young women will replay over and over again. Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 22.1 C Hamilton Saturday, August 28, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Trudeau takes a shot at Premier Ford over vaccine passports Local News Moving day at McMaster, students are back in residence for the… Local News Ontario reports 781 new COVID-19 cases today Local News 40 year-old man charged with sexual assault WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility Local News Halton Hamilton News Home Page News Story Ontario News Top News Story Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility By Sylvie Lendvay - May 10, 2021, 11:08 am The province says the eligibility to receive a COVID-19 vaccine will expand the week of May 10th to include people with “at-risk” health conditions, people who cannot work from home (Group 2), and people 40 and older. Starting Tuesday May 11 at 8 a.m, people with “at-risk” health conditions such as immune deficiencies, cancer, diabetes, and asthma will be able to book an appointment either through the provincial portal or their region’s website. Also Tuesday morning, people in Group 2 who cannot work from home including those who work in essential retail, courts and banks can book. Social workers, veterinarians and miners are also apart of the list that can be found here. Thursday May 13 at 8 a.m, people turning 40 in 2021 and older in non-hot spot communities can book a vaccine appointment at a mass immunization clinic. Halton Region has expanded its’ vaccination program to allow residents 16 and older who cannot work from home to book an appointment through the regions online portal. Halton residents 50 and older living in non-hot spot communities can also book. Wednesday May 12 eligibility opens to those 40 and older, Friday May 14 to those 30 and older, and by next week all Halton adults over the age of 16 will be eligible to book an appointment. Halton residents 16+ who cannot work from home can now book a COVID vaccine appointment… as well as anyone 50+. May 12 – 40+. May 14 – 30+. May 19 – 16+. They are following provincial criteria for expanding program based on risk… have enough supply to do it early. @CHCHNews pic.twitter.com/VYwEmaGKLO — Sylvie Lendvay (@sylvie_lendvay) May 10, 2021 Halton region says they are following provincial criteria for expanding eligibility based on who is most at risk, but they have enough supply to do it early. There are several pilot clinics across the province vaccinating residents 18 and older. Four pharmacies in Hamilton are approved to administer Moderna. Each location will receive about 150 shots a week. Adults 40 and older can still book an AstraZeneca vaccine at a participating pharmacy. All booking availability will depend on supply. Halton Police are trying to prevent bicycle theft - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 24.9 C Hamilton Friday, August 27, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Ontario reports 781 new COVID-19 cases today Local News 40 year-old man charged with sexual assault News Kale salad blends and Chopped Salad Kits recall in Ontario Local 75 year-old women dead after being found unresponsive at Sunset Beach WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton Halton Police are trying to prevent bicycle theft Local News Halton News Halton Police are trying to prevent bicycle theft By Sylvie Lendvay - April 19, 2021, 9:27 am Police Services across Ontario are trying to get ahead of bike thefts. Constable Frank Trasmundi with Halton Police says sometimes when people report their bicycle stolen, the owner won’t have the serial number. If that’s the case, police can’t return it or lay charges. He says downloading the app ‘529 Garage’ can help people file a report. “We will have picture of your bike, the serial number, and any distinguishing features so it will be easier for us to recover it if we find it.” says Trasmundi. Halton Police recovers 200 bikes per year on average. Only about 10-15 of them are returned. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Ontario reports 781 new COVID-19 cases today Local News 40 year-old man charged with sexual assault News Kale salad blends and Chopped Salad Kits recall in Ontario Local 75 year-old women dead after being found unresponsive at Sunset Beach WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton If you don’t live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor Local News Halton Main News Story News If you don’t live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor By Sylvie Lendvay - December 9, 2020, 10:11 am With cases on the rise in Halton Region, Burlington’s Mayor Marianne Meed Ward residents should be concerned. “The simplest message I could give to residents is this: If you don’t live with somebody, assume that they have COVID and conduct yourself accordingly.” Even with the temptation to gather this holiday season, she is urging residents to follow public health guidelines. “Our [Burlington] numbers are going up again, a little bit. There’s been a lot of talk about a vaccine coming; we know we’re getting that but that’s not the silver bullet. That’s not the only solution. We are going to continue, for at least a year, to need to be keeping physical distance, hand washing, wearing a mask when out in public. Those measures are going to be critically important throughout 2021.” Halton reported 92 new cases of COVID-19 Tuesday. St. Anne Catholic Elementary school in Burlington has had to close down one classroom after 4 cases were reported Tuesday night. There are currently active 14 outbreaks in Halton region. The region’s Medical Officer of Health says the region continues to see community transmission. She is asking residents to avoid carpooling, and having coffee and play dates. Local News Halton News Is Halton heading back to a modified Stage 2? By Laura Brody - October 23, 2020, 8:52 pm Premier Doug Ford is concerned about Halton region’s rising case numbers and says a decision will be made by Monday whether or not to send the region back to modified Stage 2. Halton region is approaching 2,000 total COVID-19 cases; half of which have been recorded in the last two months. “We’re going to have to discuss that over the weekend and we’ll have that answer on Monday. But folks in Halton, I know they’re doing a great job. It’s concerning right now. I’ve seen the numbers go up.” said Premier Doug Ford. “The premier has been terrific to work with throughout this. We recorded 16 new cases today. That’s like 1 in 35,000 people here. I think curves on small numbers are very unreliable ways to judge the future.” said Oakville Mayor Rob Burton. Oakville has already restricted indoor group fitness classes and team sports. The modified Stage 2 would prohibit indoor dining, and close gyms, fitness centres, cinemas and performance venues. The Niagara Falls location will no longer operate on weekends. New hours will be Monday to Friday 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. Welland’s assessment centre is cutting back to Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Hours at the St. Catharines assessment centre remain the same 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. seven days a week. COVID-19 testing at these centres, which are run by Niagara Health, are by-appointment only. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News GO Transit adding more trips between Toronto, Hamilton and Niagara Ontario News Ontario reports 807 new COVID-19 cases Friday Local News Police search for 84-year-old man after empty sail boat found in… Local News Festival of Friends announces one-day ‘Concert in the Park’ in Hamilton WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Ontario News OPP investigates fatal two-vehicle crash News Ontario News Top News Story OPP investigates fatal two-vehicle crash By Shayla Vize - September 3, 2021, 6:22 am Ontario Provincial Police say one person is dead following a two-vehicle collision in Norfolk County. Emergency crews were called to Cockshutt Rd. and Concession 3 of Townsend, just outside Waterford, Ont., around 6:30 p.m. Thursday night. Police say two vehicles collided at the intersection. One of the vehicles ended up on its side in a nearby cornfield while the other sustained extensive damage to the windshield and front bumper. Acting Sgt. Ed Sanchuk said one person was pronounced dead at the scene. “Our thoughts and prayers are going out to everyone affected by this tragedy,” said Sanchuk in a video posted on Twitter. Sanchuk said some passersby stopped to help those involved in the crash. Police have not released the identity of the victim. There were several road closures in the area as police investigated the collision but they have since reopened. Fatal collision closes Cockshutt Rd at Concession 3 of Townsend. Roadway closed between Norfolk County Rd 19 East and Concession 2 of Townsend. #OPP continuing to investigate. @NorfolkCoFire @NorfolkCountyCA @NorfolkEMS #NorfolkOPP ^es pic.twitter.com/ifMCnEwp4g — OPP West Region (@OPP_WR) September 3, 2021 TAGS collision fatal collision ontario provincial police opp police waterford Share Facebook Twitter Pinterest Linkedin Email Print Previous articleSix nations police investigating a shooting in Ohsweken Next articlePolice investigate death of 17-year-old girl: OPP Shayla Vize RELATED ARTICLESMORE FROM AUTHOR Local News GO Transit adding more trips between Toronto, Hamilton and Niagara Ontario News Ontario reports 807 new COVID-19 cases Friday Local News Police search for 84-year-old man after empty sail boat found in Burlington Local News Festival of Friends announces one-day ‘Concert in the Park’ in Hamilton Local News Man facing firearm charges following investigation in Welland Ontario News Police investigate death of 17-year-old girl: OPP LEAVE A REPLY Cancel reply Please enter your comment! Police held a scene on Mohawk road — blocking off the the area from 3rd line to 4th line. It’s unclear if anyone was hurt — but police confirm it was a targeted shooting. They add the public is not in danger, OPP was on the scene to assist the investigation. Authorities from Six Nations of the Grand River are asking anyone with information to contact police. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News GO Transit adding more trips between Toronto, Hamilton and Niagara Ontario News Ontario reports 807 new COVID-19 cases Friday Local News Police search for 84-year-old man after empty sail boat found in… Local News Festival of Friends announces one-day ‘Concert in the Park’ in Hamilton WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Canada & The World Evacuation flights resume in Afghanistan News Canada & The World Top News Story World World News Evacuation flights resume in Afghanistan By Manesa Dhanabalan - August 27, 2021, 8:16 am Evacuation flights from Afghanistan have resumed with new urgency, a day after two suicide bombings targeted thousands of desperate people fleeing the Taliban’s takeover. The United States says further attempted attacks are expected ahead of the August 31st deadline for foreign troops to leave, ending America’s longest war. Kabul residents say several flights took off Friday morning. Thursday’s bombings near Kabul’s international airport killed at least 95 afghans and 13 u-s troop members. Officials say the actual death toll is even higher because others were involved in evacuating bodies. Ottawa officials confirm no Canadian military members were hurt. Acting chief of defence staff general Wayne Eyre says it is heartbreaking that Canadian soldiers could not stay longer in Afghanistan to rescue everyone who was so desperate to leave the war-torn country. An unknown number of Canadians and their families remain trapped in Afghanistan, after the federal government announced the end of its evacuation mission yesterday. Canada boarded around 37-hundred Canadian nationals and afghan refugees onto evacuation flights in recent weeks. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News GO Transit adding more trips between Toronto, Hamilton and Niagara Ontario News Ontario reports 807 new COVID-19 cases Friday Local News Police search for 84-year-old man after empty sail boat found in… Local News Festival of Friends announces one-day ‘Concert in the Park’ in Hamilton WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Canada No quarantine for Canadians travelling to the U.K. starting Monday Canada News Canada & The World Canada News World No quarantine for Canadians travelling to the U.K. starting Monday By Manesa Dhanabalan - August 27, 2021, 7:44 am Canadians travelling to the United Kingdom still need to take a COVID-19 test within three days before leaving for the U.K. and another two days after arriving. But starting on Monday, they will no longer have to quarantine upon arrival, even if they have not been fully vaccinated. Many British Canadians were frustrated after being snubbed by the plan to ease quarantine restrictions for entry to England and Scotland last month. The United Kingdom announced on July 28th that fully vaccinated travelers from the United States or Europe would not have to quarantine upon arrival. The Grace Anglican Church started the planning process on the centre four years ago. They are calling it “Bobby’s Place”, named after local Bobby Smylie who died from the flu in 2018 at the age of 10. The church says the centre will provide a meeting space to learn, socialize, and grow. Construction on “Bobby’s Place” will begin in a few weeks and they hope to have it finished by the Fall. Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 18.9 C Hamilton Friday, September 3, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News GO Transit adding more trips between Toronto, Hamilton and Niagara Ontario News Ontario reports 807 new COVID-19 cases Friday Local News Police search for 84-year-old man after empty sail boat found in… Local News Festival of Friends announces one-day ‘Concert in the Park’ in Hamilton WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Evening News Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen News Evening News Local News Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen By Laura Brody - December 24, 2019, 4:59 pm Hamilton police have arrested a man in connection with a two-month long investigation into stolen, high-end bikes worth more than $40 000. Police say they executed a search warrant at a home in the east end last Thursday and found 26 mountain bikes, along with bike parts, high-end skis and prohibited weapons. They believe the bikes were stolen from residential and commercial properties in Ancaster, Aldershot and Dundas. They say most of the bikes had been taken apart and the parts had been swapped, to try to disguise them. So far, police have returned 3 of the 26 bikes to their owners, and hope to return the rest of them in the next two weeks. Jason Kane, 43, of Hamilton, is facing a number of charges including two counts of possession of a prohibited weapon, and three counts of possession of stolen property. Police say the investigation is ongoing and more charges could be laid. They recommend that you record the serial number on your bike, and call police if it’s been stolen. Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 20.2 C Hamilton Friday, September 3, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News GO Transit adding more trips between Toronto, Hamilton and Niagara Ontario News Ontario reports 807 new COVID-19 cases Friday Local News Police search for 84-year-old man after empty sail boat found in… Local News Festival of Friends announces one-day ‘Concert in the Park’ in Hamilton WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Evening News Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed News Evening News Local News Hamilton Home Page News Story Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed By Laura Brody - October 21, 2019, 6:27 pm Hamilton police have identified the suspect in the city’s tenth homicide of the year, and have issued a warrant for his arrest. Twenty-nine year old Obsa Junedi Mohamed was gunned down outside of Boulevard Billiards on York Boulevard at around 1:30 Saturday morning. Police say his killer was his friend, 26-year-old Ibrahim Issak Hussen. The two men were hanging out with a group of other men for awhile before the shooting. About 10 minutes before the shooting detectives say Junedi Mohamed and Issak Hussen got into a physical altercation. Hussen goes by the street name “Seemo.” Junedi Mohamed’s street name was Nanny or Chappel. Detectives say Hussen shot Mohamed point blank in the head. The whole incident was caught on surveillance video. Surveillance images released in the media led to the driver of the getaway vehicle turning himself in to police on Saturday. That man was arrested for first degree murder and accessory after the fact to murder. Police say he participated in a lengthy interview and was released unconditionally later Saturday. But another man was also in the car and police want to speak to him. They are looking for an Asian male wearing a dark parka with fur trim on the hood. The victim was known to police. He was found by officers hiding after another shooting in the same area back in 2015. At the time he was charged with failing to comply and possession of cocaine. Issak Hussen is also known to police and investigators believe drugs are involved in this incident as well. News Evening News Local News Two Hamilton women were invited to meet Taylor Swift at the star’s Nashville mansion By Laura Brody - August 22, 2019, 5:23 pm Two young women from Hamilton were treated to an experience of a lifetime by their ultra-famous idol- Taylor Swift. The multi-grammy award winning pop star hand selected about 100 mega fans from around the world to attend a secret album preview party at her Nashville mansion and 25-year-old Nichole Ridehalgh and 17-year-old Isabella Rose both got a phone call from Swifts team. Ridehalgh was shocked when she called the call inviting her to a special event. She was asked if she could make it to Nashville in less than a week. Without being told, Ridehalgh knew she had just been invited to an event that is the pinnacle of every Taylor Swift fan’s dream- a secret session album preview at the star’s Nashville mansion. Swift has held secret sessions before the releases of several of her previous albums. Fans are picked up at a secret location and driven to her mansion. Those who attend are always mega fans who the star keeps a close eye on on social media. Getting a one on one chat with the star is something Ridehalgh will never forget. “Its 4:30 in the morning, I’m exhausted but, this is my moment. I walk into the room and I turn to my left and I see her and she says hey your Nichole right?Aand in that moment my whole world was made. Without me mentioning Canada at all, she said have a safe flight back to Canada” Swift even shared secret details about her personal life with fans. Isabella Rose is also on a first name basis with Swift. She posted on social media saying “I have loved her for nine years and I will never stop talking about how much I love her but I would not be where I am today without her.” Tonight is the release of Swift’s newest album, Lover. Ridehalgh and Rose were two of 113 fans in the world, that have already heard it. “She was lip syncing and dancing. She was just having a blast.” And that night is a night these young women will replay over and over again. The Ontario Life Saving Society says not wearing a life jacket was a factor in 88% of boat-related deaths. Alcohol played a part in 40% of boat-related deaths. There were 50 search and rescue calls in the Niagara Region in the year 2020. There have been 33 calls in 2021 so far. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News GO Transit adding more trips between Toronto, Hamilton and Niagara Ontario News Ontario reports 807 new COVID-19 cases Friday Local News Police search for 84-year-old man after empty sail boat found in… Local News Festival of Friends announces one-day ‘Concert in the Park’ in Hamilton WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Local News Man seriously injured in collision with Halton police cruiser, SIU investigates News Local News Top News Story Man seriously injured in collision with Halton police cruiser, SIU investigates By Shayla Vize - September 2, 2021, 12:57 pm Ontario’s police watchdog is investigating a crash that sent a driver to hospital and injured a Halton police officer. The crash happened on Wednesday on Steeles Ave., just east of James Snow Parkway in Halton Hills. The Special Investigations Unit (SIU) says a Halton police cruiser and another vehicle collided shortly before 9 p.m. The SIU says the driver of the vehicle was rushed to hospital with serious injuries. The police officer was also injured but was not taken to hospital. The SIU has assigned five investigators, including one forensic investigator and one collision reconstructionist, to the case. The SIU is urging anyone who may have information about this collision to contact the lead investigator at 1-800-787-8529. Steeles Ave. East between James Snow Parkway and Fifth Line is closed and motorists are being asked to avoid the area. Video surveillance captured someone walking up the driveway of the home shortly after 10:30 p.m. on Aug. 16. Police say the suspect removed a 2S&LGBTQIA+ pride flag that was hanging above the garage and proceeded to throw it to the ground and stomp on it. The youth eventually left the area with the flag in their possession. READ MORE: Community rallies around a Waterdown woman after pride flag stolen twice A 15-year-old boy has been arrested and charged with theft under $5,000. Hamilton police say the incident is being investigated as a hate crime. Anyone with information that could help police with the investigation is asked to contact Det. Fabiano Mendes at 905-546-5678. Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 15.2 C Hamilton Saturday, September 4, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News GO Transit adding more trips between Toronto, Hamilton and Niagara Ontario News Ontario reports 807 new COVID-19 cases Friday Local News Police search for 84-year-old man after empty sail boat found in… Local News Festival of Friends announces one-day ‘Concert in the Park’ in Hamilton WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility Local News Halton Hamilton News Home Page News Story Ontario News Top News Story Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility By Sylvie Lendvay - May 10, 2021, 11:08 am The province says the eligibility to receive a COVID-19 vaccine will expand the week of May 10th to include people with “at-risk” health conditions, people who cannot work from home (Group 2), and people 40 and older. Starting Tuesday May 11 at 8 a.m, people with “at-risk” health conditions such as immune deficiencies, cancer, diabetes, and asthma will be able to book an appointment either through the provincial portal or their region’s website. Also Tuesday morning, people in Group 2 who cannot work from home including those who work in essential retail, courts and banks can book. Social workers, veterinarians and miners are also apart of the list that can be found here. Thursday May 13 at 8 a.m, people turning 40 in 2021 and older in non-hot spot communities can book a vaccine appointment at a mass immunization clinic. Halton Region has expanded its’ vaccination program to allow residents 16 and older who cannot work from home to book an appointment through the regions online portal. Halton residents 50 and older living in non-hot spot communities can also book. Wednesday May 12 eligibility opens to those 40 and older, Friday May 14 to those 30 and older, and by next week all Halton adults over the age of 16 will be eligible to book an appointment. Halton residents 16+ who cannot work from home can now book a COVID vaccine appointment… as well as anyone 50+. May 12 – 40+. May 14 – 30+. May 19 – 16+. They are following provincial criteria for expanding program based on risk… have enough supply to do it early. @CHCHNews pic.twitter.com/VYwEmaGKLO — Sylvie Lendvay (@sylvie_lendvay) May 10, 2021 Halton region says they are following provincial criteria for expanding eligibility based on who is most at risk, but they have enough supply to do it early. There are several pilot clinics across the province vaccinating residents 18 and older. Four pharmacies in Hamilton are approved to administer Moderna. Each location will receive about 150 shots a week. Adults 40 and older can still book an AstraZeneca vaccine at a participating pharmacy. All booking availability will depend on supply. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News GO Transit adding more trips between Toronto, Hamilton and Niagara Ontario News Ontario reports 807 new COVID-19 cases Friday Local News Police search for 84-year-old man after empty sail boat found in… Local News Festival of Friends announces one-day ‘Concert in the Park’ in Hamilton WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton Halton Police are trying to prevent bicycle theft Local News Halton News Halton Police are trying to prevent bicycle theft By Sylvie Lendvay - April 19, 2021, 9:27 am Police Services across Ontario are trying to get ahead of bike thefts. Constable Frank Trasmundi with Halton Police says sometimes when people report their bicycle stolen, the owner won’t have the serial number. If that’s the case, police can’t return it or lay charges. He says downloading the app ‘529 Garage’ can help people file a report. “We will have picture of your bike, the serial number, and any distinguishing features so it will be easier for us to recover it if we find it.” says Trasmundi. Halton Police recovers 200 bikes per year on average. Only about 10-15 of them are returned.
