CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News GO Transit adding more trips between Toronto, Hamilton and Niagara Ontario News Ontario reports 807 new COVID-19 cases Friday Local News Police search for 84-year-old man after empty sail boat found in… Local News Festival of Friends announces one-day ‘Concert in the Park’ in Hamilton WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton If you don’t live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor Local News Halton Main News Story News If you don’t live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor By Sylvie Lendvay - December 9, 2020, 10:11 am With cases on the rise in Halton Region, Burlington’s Mayor Marianne Meed Ward residents should be concerned. “The simplest message I could give to residents is this: If you don’t live with somebody, assume that they have COVID and conduct yourself accordingly.” Even with the temptation to gather this holiday season, she is urging residents to follow public health guidelines. “Our [Burlington] numbers are going up again, a little bit. There’s been a lot of talk about a vaccine coming; we know we’re getting that but that’s not the silver bullet. That’s not the only solution. We are going to continue, for at least a year, to need to be keeping physical distance, hand washing, wearing a mask when out in public. Those measures are going to be critically important throughout 2021.” Halton reported 92 new cases of COVID-19 Tuesday. St. Anne Catholic Elementary school in Burlington has had to close down one classroom after 4 cases were reported Tuesday night. There are currently active 14 outbreaks in Halton region. The region’s Medical Officer of Health says the region continues to see community transmission. She is asking residents to avoid carpooling, and having coffee and play dates. Local News Halton News Is Halton heading back to a modified Stage 2? By Laura Brody - October 23, 2020, 8:52 pm Premier Doug Ford is concerned about Halton region’s rising case numbers and says a decision will be made by Monday whether or not to send the region back to modified Stage 2. Halton region is approaching 2,000 total COVID-19 cases; half of which have been recorded in the last two months. “We’re going to have to discuss that over the weekend and we’ll have that answer on Monday. But folks in Halton, I know they’re doing a great job. It’s concerning right now. I’ve seen the numbers go up.” said Premier Doug Ford. “The premier has been terrific to work with throughout this. We recorded 16 new cases today. That’s like 1 in 35,000 people here. I think curves on small numbers are very unreliable ways to judge the future.” said Oakville Mayor Rob Burton. Oakville has already restricted indoor group fitness classes and team sports. The modified Stage 2 would prohibit indoor dining, and close gyms, fitness centres, cinemas and performance venues. The Niagara Falls location will no longer operate on weekends. New hours will be Monday to Friday 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. Welland’s assessment centre is cutting back to Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Hours at the St. Catharines assessment centre remain the same 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. seven days a week. COVID-19 testing at these centres, which are run by Niagara Health, are by-appointment only. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Ontario News Ontario reports 848 new cases of COVID-19 Friday Local News Mother and her 2-year-old toddler escape house fire in Hamilton News Brantford woman accused of breaking into home, assaulting resident inside Local News WATCH NOW: Justin Trudeau to make announcement in Hamilton at 10:30… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Ontario News Ontario reports 848 new cases of COVID-19 Friday News Ontario News Top News Story Ontario reports 848 new cases of COVID-19 Friday By Shayla Vize - September 10, 2021, 12:20 pm Ontario is reporting 848 new COVID-19 cases Friday and 11 more deaths related to the virus. The province said six of the deaths occurred more than a month ago. The data is based on more than 28,247 tests completed on the previous day. The province says 35,844 doses of a COVID-19 vaccine were administered in the last 24-hour period for a total of more than 21 million. Health Minister Christine Elliott says 84.1 per cent of Ontarians aged 12 and older have received one dose and nearly 77.7 per cent have two doses. There are currently 177 patients in intensive care with COVID-related critical illnesses and 113 on ventilators. The province says of those in hospital, 264 are unvaccinated individuals, 25 are partially vaccinated and 44 are fully vaccinated. Of the province’s 626 long-term care homes, at least seven are in an outbreak including R. H. Lawson Eventide Home in Niagara Falls and Hampton Terrace Care Centre in Burlington. An active COVID-19 outbreak indicates that the home has at least one lab-confirmed case of COVID-19 (in resident or staff) and the local public health unit or the home has declared an outbreak. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Ontario News Ontario reports 848 new cases of COVID-19 Friday Local News Mother and her 2-year-old toddler escape house fire in Hamilton News Brantford woman accused of breaking into home, assaulting resident inside Local News WATCH NOW: Justin Trudeau to make announcement in Hamilton at 10:30… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Local News Mother and her 2-year-old toddler escape house fire in Hamilton News Local News Top News Story Mother and her 2-year-old toddler escape house fire in Hamilton By Shayla Vize - September 10, 2021, 11:37 am A mother and her two-year-old son are safe after a fire broke out at a townhome in Hamilton Friday morning. The Hamilton Fire Department received multiple calls about a structure fire at 525 Stone Church Rd. East around 8:36 a.m. Crews arrived to find heavy smoke and a well-involved fire on the first floor of the middle unit townhouse. A mother inside the home managed to grab her two-year-old son and carry him out of the house before firefighters arrived on scene. Everyone safe after a townhouse fire on Stone Church Road. The woman who lives inside tells me she ran upstairs grabbed her two-year-old son threw him on her shoulders and ran out. @CHCHNews pic.twitter.com/B6Tjv1yTBK — Sean_Cowan (@seancowantv) September 10, 2021 The fire was upgraded to a multiple alarm and additional units were called in to assist. Firefighters went inside and were able to quickly get the blaze under control. Hamilton fire officials say the fire did not spread to neighbouring homes. The unit sustained significant fire and smoke damage. Crews continue to put out hotspots at the scene. Officials believe the fire started in the kitchen area of the home. A GoFundMe page has been set up for the family. Police received reports of a break and enter at a home on Bruce St. around 4 a.m. on Tuesday. Investigators were told a woman had smashed the front window of the home before crawling through to get inside. She allegedly caused “a disturbance” and then physically assaulted the resident before fleeing the home. Officers arrived on scene and attempted to take the woman into custody but she resisted and attempted to hit the officers. Police eventually arrested a 33-year-old woman. She has been charged with mischief under $5,000, assault, break and enter, and resist arrest. Police say the woman and victim are known to each other and this was not a random incident. The Grace Anglican Church started the planning process on the centre four years ago. They are calling it “Bobby’s Place”, named after local Bobby Smylie who died from the flu in 2018 at the age of 10. The church says the centre will provide a meeting space to learn, socialize, and grow. Construction on “Bobby’s Place” will begin in a few weeks and they hope to have it finished by the Fall. Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 14 C Hamilton Saturday, September 11, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Hamilton 7-year-old girl wins the job of singing the national anthem at… Canada & The World Federal leaders back on the campaign trail hours after the heated… Ontario News Ontario reports 848 new cases of COVID-19 Friday Local News Mother and her 2-year-old toddler escape house fire in Hamilton WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Evening News Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen News Evening News Local News Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen By Laura Brody - December 24, 2019, 4:59 pm Hamilton police have arrested a man in connection with a two-month long investigation into stolen, high-end bikes worth more than $40 000. Police say they executed a search warrant at a home in the east end last Thursday and found 26 mountain bikes, along with bike parts, high-end skis and prohibited weapons. They believe the bikes were stolen from residential and commercial properties in Ancaster, Aldershot and Dundas. They say most of the bikes had been taken apart and the parts had been swapped, to try to disguise them. So far, police have returned 3 of the 26 bikes to their owners, and hope to return the rest of them in the next two weeks. Jason Kane, 43, of Hamilton, is facing a number of charges including two counts of possession of a prohibited weapon, and three counts of possession of stolen property. Police say the investigation is ongoing and more charges could be laid. They recommend that you record the serial number on your bike, and call police if it’s been stolen. Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 14 C Hamilton Saturday, September 11, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Hamilton 7-year-old girl wins the job of singing the national anthem at… Canada & The World Federal leaders back on the campaign trail hours after the heated… Ontario News Ontario reports 848 new cases of COVID-19 Friday Local News Mother and her 2-year-old toddler escape house fire in Hamilton WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Evening News Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed News Evening News Local News Hamilton Home Page News Story Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed By Laura Brody - October 21, 2019, 6:27 pm Hamilton police have identified the suspect in the city’s tenth homicide of the year, and have issued a warrant for his arrest. Twenty-nine year old Obsa Junedi Mohamed was gunned down outside of Boulevard Billiards on York Boulevard at around 1:30 Saturday morning. Police say his killer was his friend, 26-year-old Ibrahim Issak Hussen. The two men were hanging out with a group of other men for awhile before the shooting. About 10 minutes before the shooting detectives say Junedi Mohamed and Issak Hussen got into a physical altercation. Hussen goes by the street name “Seemo.” Junedi Mohamed’s street name was Nanny or Chappel. Detectives say Hussen shot Mohamed point blank in the head. The whole incident was caught on surveillance video. Surveillance images released in the media led to the driver of the getaway vehicle turning himself in to police on Saturday. That man was arrested for first degree murder and accessory after the fact to murder. Police say he participated in a lengthy interview and was released unconditionally later Saturday. But another man was also in the car and police want to speak to him. They are looking for an Asian male wearing a dark parka with fur trim on the hood. The victim was known to police. He was found by officers hiding after another shooting in the same area back in 2015. At the time he was charged with failing to comply and possession of cocaine. Issak Hussen is also known to police and investigators believe drugs are involved in this incident as well. Two Hamilton women were invited to meet Taylor Swift at the star's Nashville mansion - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 14 C Hamilton Saturday, September 11, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! News Evening News Local News Two Hamilton women were invited to meet Taylor Swift at the star’s Nashville mansion By Laura Brody - August 22, 2019, 5:23 pm Two young women from Hamilton were treated to an experience of a lifetime by their ultra-famous idol- Taylor Swift. The multi-grammy award winning pop star hand selected about 100 mega fans from around the world to attend a secret album preview party at her Nashville mansion and 25-year-old Nichole Ridehalgh and 17-year-old Isabella Rose both got a phone call from Swifts team. Ridehalgh was shocked when she called the call inviting her to a special event. She was asked if she could make it to Nashville in less than a week. Without being told, Ridehalgh knew she had just been invited to an event that is the pinnacle of every Taylor Swift fan’s dream- a secret session album preview at the star’s Nashville mansion. Swift has held secret sessions before the releases of several of her previous albums. Fans are picked up at a secret location and driven to her mansion. Those who attend are always mega fans who the star keeps a close eye on on social media. Getting a one on one chat with the star is something Ridehalgh will never forget. “Its 4:30 in the morning, I’m exhausted but, this is my moment. I walk into the room and I turn to my left and I see her and she says hey your Nichole right?Aand in that moment my whole world was made. Without me mentioning Canada at all, she said have a safe flight back to Canada” Swift even shared secret details about her personal life with fans. Isabella Rose is also on a first name basis with Swift. She posted on social media saying “I have loved her for nine years and I will never stop talking about how much I love her but I would not be where I am today without her.” Tonight is the release of Swift’s newest album, Lover. Ridehalgh and Rose were two of 113 fans in the world, that have already heard it. “She was lip syncing and dancing. She was just having a blast.” And that night is a night these young women will replay over and over again. Officers were called to a single-vehicle collision on Queen St. near Dalhousie St. just before 4 a.m. on Sept. 5. Police say officers spoke with the driver and observed signs of impairment. They say the driver initially lied to police about how the collision occurred. Investigators learned that while the man was driving, he collided with an unoccupied vehicle that was parked at the side of the roadway and then left the scene. He was arrested and given a breath test which showed he had over twice the legal alcohol limit in his system. A Burford, Ont. man has been charged with operation while impaired, 80 and over, obstruct peace officer, and fail to stop after accident. The man’s license was suspended and his vehicle was impounded. Police warn residents after spike in vehicle thefts in Brantford - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 14 C Hamilton Saturday, September 11, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Hamilton 7-year-old girl wins the job of singing the national anthem at… Canada & The World Federal leaders back on the campaign trail hours after the heated… Ontario News Ontario reports 848 new cases of COVID-19 Friday Local News Mother and her 2-year-old toddler escape house fire in Hamilton WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Local News Police warn residents after spike in vehicle thefts in Brantford News Local News Top News Story Police warn residents after spike in vehicle thefts in Brantford By Shayla Vize - September 10, 2021, 8:38 am Brantford police are warning residents about a new trend involving vehicle thefts in the city. Police say thieves have used relay and reprogramming technology to steal six vehicles in Brantford in the last week. In a relay theft, the thief will approach a residence and use technology to find a key fob signal from inside a home. The technology allows the suspects to remain outside the residence to amplify and transfer the key fob signal in order to unlock, start and steal the vehicle. In a reprogramming theft, the criminal will break into a vehicle and once inside, use an electronic device to access the vehicle’s diagnostics. The suspects then reprogram a blank key fob so the vehicle can be started. Brantford police say all six vehicles stolen this week were newer model, high-end vehicles with keyless entry and push start technology. They say four addresses were targeted during the overnight hours of Sept. 4 and 5. Two Lexus RX5’s were stolen from Tom Thompson Crt. and Warner Lane and three Toyota 4Runner’s were stolen from Varley Crescent and from a Toyota dealership at 5 Woodyatt Dr. A Toyota Highlander was also stolen from the dealership. Police are asking anyone with information about these incidents to contact investigators. Police have also offered the following tips to help keep your vehicles safe. Park your vehicle inside a locked and secure garage. Block access to the onboard diagnostic port to prevent thieves from reprograming the vehicle’s key fob. (A simple device can be purchased online). Use a steering wheel locking device to deter theft. Place the vehicle key fob inside a radio frequency shielding bag/pouch to block cell signals when not in use. Inside your residence and in a purse or pocket. Consider equipping your vehicle with an aftermarket global positioning system (GPS) tracker. The tracker may assist police in locating the vehicle and/or suspects. Ensure all keys are accounted for and never left in the vehicle or unattended. Lock your vehicle at all times. Never leave your vehicle running and unattended. Consider purchasing a surveillance system and ensure the quality and function will capture any suspicious activity for a 24 hour period. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Hamilton 7-year-old girl wins the job of singing the national anthem at… Canada & The World Federal leaders back on the campaign trail hours after the heated… Ontario News Ontario reports 848 new cases of COVID-19 Friday Local News Mother and her 2-year-old toddler escape house fire in Hamilton WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility Local News Halton Hamilton News Home Page News Story Ontario News Top News Story Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility By Sylvie Lendvay - May 10, 2021, 11:08 am The province says the eligibility to receive a COVID-19 vaccine will expand the week of May 10th to include people with “at-risk” health conditions, people who cannot work from home (Group 2), and people 40 and older. Starting Tuesday May 11 at 8 a.m, people with “at-risk” health conditions such as immune deficiencies, cancer, diabetes, and asthma will be able to book an appointment either through the provincial portal or their region’s website. Also Tuesday morning, people in Group 2 who cannot work from home including those who work in essential retail, courts and banks can book. Social workers, veterinarians and miners are also apart of the list that can be found here. Thursday May 13 at 8 a.m, people turning 40 in 2021 and older in non-hot spot communities can book a vaccine appointment at a mass immunization clinic. Halton Region has expanded its’ vaccination program to allow residents 16 and older who cannot work from home to book an appointment through the regions online portal. Halton residents 50 and older living in non-hot spot communities can also book. Wednesday May 12 eligibility opens to those 40 and older, Friday May 14 to those 30 and older, and by next week all Halton adults over the age of 16 will be eligible to book an appointment. Halton residents 16+ who cannot work from home can now book a COVID vaccine appointment… as well as anyone 50+. May 12 – 40+. May 14 – 30+. May 19 – 16+. They are following provincial criteria for expanding program based on risk… have enough supply to do it early. @CHCHNews pic.twitter.com/VYwEmaGKLO — Sylvie Lendvay (@sylvie_lendvay) May 10, 2021 Halton region says they are following provincial criteria for expanding eligibility based on who is most at risk, but they have enough supply to do it early. There are several pilot clinics across the province vaccinating residents 18 and older. Four pharmacies in Hamilton are approved to administer Moderna. Each location will receive about 150 shots a week. Adults 40 and older can still book an AstraZeneca vaccine at a participating pharmacy. All booking availability will depend on supply. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Hamilton 7-year-old girl wins the job of singing the national anthem at… Canada & The World Federal leaders back on the campaign trail hours after the heated… Ontario News Ontario reports 848 new cases of COVID-19 Friday Local News Mother and her 2-year-old toddler escape house fire in Hamilton WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton Halton Police are trying to prevent bicycle theft Local News Halton News Halton Police are trying to prevent bicycle theft By Sylvie Lendvay - April 19, 2021, 9:27 am Police Services across Ontario are trying to get ahead of bike thefts. Constable Frank Trasmundi with Halton Police says sometimes when people report their bicycle stolen, the owner won’t have the serial number. If that’s the case, police can’t return it or lay charges. He says downloading the app ‘529 Garage’ can help people file a report. “We will have picture of your bike, the serial number, and any distinguishing features so it will be easier for us to recover it if we find it.” says Trasmundi. Halton Police recovers 200 bikes per year on average. Only about 10-15 of them are returned. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Hamilton 7-year-old girl wins the job of singing the national anthem at… Canada & The World Federal leaders back on the campaign trail hours after the heated… Ontario News Ontario reports 848 new cases of COVID-19 Friday Local News Mother and her 2-year-old toddler escape house fire in Hamilton WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 Shows Inside The Story SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton If you don’t live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor Local News Halton Main News Story News If you don’t live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor By Sylvie Lendvay - December 9, 2020, 10:11 am With cases on the rise in Halton Region, Burlington’s Mayor Marianne Meed Ward residents should be concerned. “The simplest message I could give to residents is this: If you don’t live with somebody, assume that they have COVID and conduct yourself accordingly.” Even with the temptation to gather this holiday season, she is urging residents to follow public health guidelines. “Our [Burlington] numbers are going up again, a little bit. There’s been a lot of talk about a vaccine coming; we know we’re getting that but that’s not the silver bullet. That’s not the only solution. We are going to continue, for at least a year, to need to be keeping physical distance, hand washing, wearing a mask when out in public. Those measures are going to be critically important throughout 2021.” Halton reported 92 new cases of COVID-19 Tuesday. St. Anne Catholic Elementary school in Burlington has had to close down one classroom after 4 cases were reported Tuesday night. There are currently active 14 outbreaks in Halton region. The region’s Medical Officer of Health says the region continues to see community transmission. She is asking residents to avoid carpooling, and having coffee and play dates. Local News Halton News Is Halton heading back to a modified Stage 2? By Laura Brody - October 23, 2020, 8:52 pm Premier Doug Ford is concerned about Halton region’s rising case numbers and says a decision will be made by Monday whether or not to send the region back to modified Stage 2. Halton region is approaching 2,000 total COVID-19 cases; half of which have been recorded in the last two months. “We’re going to have to discuss that over the weekend and we’ll have that answer on Monday. But folks in Halton, I know they’re doing a great job. It’s concerning right now. I’ve seen the numbers go up.” said Premier Doug Ford. “The premier has been terrific to work with throughout this. We recorded 16 new cases today. That’s like 1 in 35,000 people here. I think curves on small numbers are very unreliable ways to judge the future.” said Oakville Mayor Rob Burton. Oakville has already restricted indoor group fitness classes and team sports. The modified Stage 2 would prohibit indoor dining, and close gyms, fitness centres, cinemas and performance venues. The Niagara Falls location will no longer operate on weekends. New hours will be Monday to Friday 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. Welland’s assessment centre is cutting back to Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Hours at the St. Catharines assessment centre remain the same 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. seven days a week. COVID-19 testing at these centres, which are run by Niagara Health, are by-appointment only. News Local News Top News Story WATCH NOW: Police to provide update on kidnapping, double shooting at 11:30 a.m. By Shayla Vize - September 17, 2021, 10:16 am VIDEO: Hamilton police will be providing an update on Thursday’s fatal double shooting and kidnapping investigation at 11:30 a.m. Emergency crews responded to reports of a shooting at a home in the area of Glancaster Rd. and Dickenson Rd. West in Mount Hope shortly before 3 a.m. READ MORE: Man killed, another kidnapped, third shot in violent home invasion: Hamilton police Officers located two brothers suffering from gunshot wounds. They were taken to hospital with life-threatening injuries where one of the men later died. The victims’ father, 63-year-old Faqir Ali, was forcibly taken from his home in a dark coloured SUV. Several hours later, Hamilton police located a man suffering from life-threatening injuries near Beach Blvd. Police say they believe the man was Ali. Western University students set to walk out amid sexual assault allegations - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 22.1 C Hamilton Friday, September 17, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Investigators say the father was the target of the home invasion,… Local News Billy Mason’s killer sentenced Local News One weekend left before Canadians cast their ballots Ontario News Ontario to support students WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Ontario News Western University students set to walk out amid sexual assault allegations News Ontario News Top News Story Western University students set to walk out amid sexual assault allegations By Shayla Vize - September 17, 2021, 7:00 am Students at Western University in London are set to walk out of class Friday to protest what they call a “culture of misogyny.” The protest comes after a series of sexual assault allegations surfaced online. London police say four women have come forward with formal complaints about being sexually assaulted on campus recently. Police are also investigating allegations made on social media of mass drugging and sexual assaults at the Medway-Sydenham Hall residence on campus during orientation week. However, no formal complaints have been received regarding those allegations. READ MORE: Reports of sexual violence at Western University during orientation week One of the protest organizers said the walkout will also protest the University’s response to the allegations. Several sexual assault survivors are expected to speak to students who leave their classes at noon. Western says it has created a new action plan that will increase safety and security. The plan includes the hiring of new special constables, enhancing security patrols, and implementing in-person sexual violence training for all students in residence. “This has been a tremendously difficult time for our students and the entire Western community. We clearly have a culture problem that we need to address. We let our students and their families down,” said President Alan Shepard in a message posted on the University’s website on Thursday. “The measures announced today are the first step in a journey to deeply examine the prevailing culture on our campus and identify what more we can do to ensure the safety and security of every member of our community.” Shepard says these actions are just the beginning steps to ensuring students feel safe. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Ontario News Ontario to support students Local News WATCH NOW: Police to provide update on kidnapping, double shooting at… Ontario News Western University students set to walk out amid sexual assault allegations Local News Police seek witnesses after boy, 12, sexually assaulted on trail in… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Local News Police seek witnesses after boy, 12, sexually assaulted on trail in Thorold News Local News Top News Story Police seek witnesses after boy, 12, sexually assaulted on trail in Thorold By Shayla Vize - September 17, 2021, 6:10 am Niagara police are hoping to track down members of the public who were out on a trail around the same time a young boy was sexually assaulted by a stranger earlier this month. Officers were called to the area of Ormond St. South and Lyndon St. East around 7:48 p.m. on Sept. 7. Police say a 12-year-old boy was walking with four friends on a trail in the area of Ormond St. South and Dock Rd. after the group had gone swimming nearby. A man approached the children and sexually assaulted the 12-year-old boy. The suspect then left the area on foot. Police were quickly notified about the incident and the K9 Unit flooded the area but were not able to locate the man. He is described as being white, between 40 and 50 years of age, with a medium build, grey or black “scruffy” hair, and a “belly.” He was wearing a grey or black shirt, baggy jeans, and a ball cap. Detectives have reason to believe there were members of the public or possible witnesses in the area within minutes after the assault happened. Investigators have released a drone video of where the incident occurred. Police are asking any businesses or residents in the area with closed-circuit security cameras, doorbell video cameras, or dash cameras, to review their footage for any suspicious activity between 6:45 p.m. and 8:45 p.m. on Sept. 7. Anyone with information that could help police with the investigation is asked to contact detectives at 905-688-4111, ext. 1008430. The Grace Anglican Church started the planning process on the centre four years ago. They are calling it “Bobby’s Place”, named after local Bobby Smylie who died from the flu in 2018 at the age of 10. The church says the centre will provide a meeting space to learn, socialize, and grow. Construction on “Bobby’s Place” will begin in a few weeks and they hope to have it finished by the Fall. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Thousands of students walk out at Western University protesting the sexual… Local News Investigators say the father was the target of the home invasion,… Local News Billy Mason’s killer sentenced Local News One weekend left before Canadians cast their ballots WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Evening News Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen News Evening News Local News Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen By Laura Brody - December 24, 2019, 4:59 pm Hamilton police have arrested a man in connection with a two-month long investigation into stolen, high-end bikes worth more than $40 000. Police say they executed a search warrant at a home in the east end last Thursday and found 26 mountain bikes, along with bike parts, high-end skis and prohibited weapons. They believe the bikes were stolen from residential and commercial properties in Ancaster, Aldershot and Dundas. They say most of the bikes had been taken apart and the parts had been swapped, to try to disguise them. So far, police have returned 3 of the 26 bikes to their owners, and hope to return the rest of them in the next two weeks. Jason Kane, 43, of Hamilton, is facing a number of charges including two counts of possession of a prohibited weapon, and three counts of possession of stolen property. Police say the investigation is ongoing and more charges could be laid. They recommend that you record the serial number on your bike, and call police if it’s been stolen. Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 22.1 C Hamilton Friday, September 17, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Investigators say the father was the target of the home invasion,… Local News Billy Mason’s killer sentenced Local News One weekend left before Canadians cast their ballots Ontario News Ontario to support students WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Evening News Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed News Evening News Local News Hamilton Home Page News Story Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed By Laura Brody - October 21, 2019, 6:27 pm Hamilton police have identified the suspect in the city’s tenth homicide of the year, and have issued a warrant for his arrest. Twenty-nine year old Obsa Junedi Mohamed was gunned down outside of Boulevard Billiards on York Boulevard at around 1:30 Saturday morning. Police say his killer was his friend, 26-year-old Ibrahim Issak Hussen. The two men were hanging out with a group of other men for awhile before the shooting. About 10 minutes before the shooting detectives say Junedi Mohamed and Issak Hussen got into a physical altercation. Hussen goes by the street name “Seemo.” Junedi Mohamed’s street name was Nanny or Chappel. Detectives say Hussen shot Mohamed point blank in the head. The whole incident was caught on surveillance video. Surveillance images released in the media led to the driver of the getaway vehicle turning himself in to police on Saturday. That man was arrested for first degree murder and accessory after the fact to murder. Police say he participated in a lengthy interview and was released unconditionally later Saturday. But another man was also in the car and police want to speak to him. They are looking for an Asian male wearing a dark parka with fur trim on the hood. The victim was known to police. He was found by officers hiding after another shooting in the same area back in 2015. At the time he was charged with failing to comply and possession of cocaine. Issak Hussen is also known to police and investigators believe drugs are involved in this incident as well. News Evening News Local News Two Hamilton women were invited to meet Taylor Swift at the star’s Nashville mansion By Laura Brody - August 22, 2019, 5:23 pm Two young women from Hamilton were treated to an experience of a lifetime by their ultra-famous idol- Taylor Swift. The multi-grammy award winning pop star hand selected about 100 mega fans from around the world to attend a secret album preview party at her Nashville mansion and 25-year-old Nichole Ridehalgh and 17-year-old Isabella Rose both got a phone call from Swifts team. Ridehalgh was shocked when she called the call inviting her to a special event. She was asked if she could make it to Nashville in less than a week. Without being told, Ridehalgh knew she had just been invited to an event that is the pinnacle of every Taylor Swift fan’s dream- a secret session album preview at the star’s Nashville mansion. Swift has held secret sessions before the releases of several of her previous albums. Fans are picked up at a secret location and driven to her mansion. Those who attend are always mega fans who the star keeps a close eye on on social media. Getting a one on one chat with the star is something Ridehalgh will never forget. “Its 4:30 in the morning, I’m exhausted but, this is my moment. I walk into the room and I turn to my left and I see her and she says hey your Nichole right?Aand in that moment my whole world was made. Without me mentioning Canada at all, she said have a safe flight back to Canada” Swift even shared secret details about her personal life with fans. Isabella Rose is also on a first name basis with Swift. She posted on social media saying “I have loved her for nine years and I will never stop talking about how much I love her but I would not be where I am today without her.” Tonight is the release of Swift’s newest album, Lover. Ridehalgh and Rose were two of 113 fans in the world, that have already heard it. “She was lip syncing and dancing. She was just having a blast.” And that night is a night these young women will replay over and over again. The Ontario Life Saving Society says not wearing a life jacket was a factor in 88% of boat-related deaths. Alcohol played a part in 40% of boat-related deaths. There were 50 search and rescue calls in the Niagara Region in the year 2020. There have been 33 calls in 2021 so far. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Thousands of students walk out at Western University protesting the sexual… Local News Investigators say the father was the target of the home invasion,… Local News Billy Mason’s killer sentenced Local News One weekend left before Canadians cast their ballots WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Local News 5 people arrested after victim defrauded of $150K in romance scam News Local News Top News Story 5 people arrested after victim defrauded of $150K in romance scam By Shayla Vize - September 17, 2021, 5:49 am Halton police have arrested multiple people in connection with a complex romance scam in Burlington. The scam started nearly a year ago when a senior was contacted by a person claiming to be a man named Darren Michaelson. A romantic relationship began online between the senior and the man they believed was a retired Canadian Army Sergeant. The victim was deceived into sending money with the intent of alleviating “Michaelson’s” legal troubles and helping him return to Canada. Police say the victim was defrauded of more than $150,000. A 21-year-old Oakville woman, a 38-year-old London woman, and three Toronto men, aged 36, 35, and 28, have all been arrested and charged in connection with the scam. Police believe there may be more victims and anticipate more charges will be laid. Police are reminding residents of the dangers and frequency of these types of scams. “Do not send money or gift cards to persons you have not met in person,” said police in a news release. “Do not provide your personal information such as financial documents, identification or passwords when communicating online.” Anyone with information regarding this investigation is asked to contact Det. Const. Derek Gray at 905-825-4747, ext. 2344. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Thousands of students walk out at Western University protesting the sexual… Local News Investigators say the father was the target of the home invasion,… Local News Billy Mason’s killer sentenced Local News One weekend left before Canadians cast their ballots WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility Local News Halton Hamilton News Home Page News Story Ontario News Top News Story Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility By Sylvie Lendvay - May 10, 2021, 11:08 am The province says the eligibility to receive a COVID-19 vaccine will expand the week of May 10th to include people with “at-risk” health conditions, people who cannot work from home (Group 2), and people 40 and older. Starting Tuesday May 11 at 8 a.m, people with “at-risk” health conditions such as immune deficiencies, cancer, diabetes, and asthma will be able to book an appointment either through the provincial portal or their region’s website. Also Tuesday morning, people in Group 2 who cannot work from home including those who work in essential retail, courts and banks can book. Social workers, veterinarians and miners are also apart of the list that can be found here. Thursday May 13 at 8 a.m, people turning 40 in 2021 and older in non-hot spot communities can book a vaccine appointment at a mass immunization clinic. Halton Region has expanded its’ vaccination program to allow residents 16 and older who cannot work from home to book an appointment through the regions online portal. Halton residents 50 and older living in non-hot spot communities can also book. Wednesday May 12 eligibility opens to those 40 and older, Friday May 14 to those 30 and older, and by next week all Halton adults over the age of 16 will be eligible to book an appointment. Halton residents 16+ who cannot work from home can now book a COVID vaccine appointment… as well as anyone 50+. May 12 – 40+. May 14 – 30+. May 19 – 16+. They are following provincial criteria for expanding program based on risk… have enough supply to do it early. @CHCHNews pic.twitter.com/VYwEmaGKLO — Sylvie Lendvay (@sylvie_lendvay) May 10, 2021 Halton region says they are following provincial criteria for expanding eligibility based on who is most at risk, but they have enough supply to do it early. There are several pilot clinics across the province vaccinating residents 18 and older. Four pharmacies in Hamilton are approved to administer Moderna. Each location will receive about 150 shots a week. Adults 40 and older can still book an AstraZeneca vaccine at a participating pharmacy. All booking availability will depend on supply. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Ontario News Ontario to support students Local News WATCH NOW: Police to provide update on kidnapping, double shooting at… Ontario News Western University students set to walk out amid sexual assault alleations Local News Police seek witnesses after boy, 12, sexually assaulted on trail in… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton Halton Police are trying to prevent bicycle theft Local News Halton News Halton Police are trying to prevent bicycle theft By Sylvie Lendvay - April 19, 2021, 9:27 am Police Services across Ontario are trying to get ahead of bike thefts. Constable Frank Trasmundi with Halton Police says sometimes when people report their bicycle stolen, the owner won’t have the serial number. If that’s the case, police can’t return it or lay charges. He says downloading the app ‘529 Garage’ can help people file a report. “We will have picture of your bike, the serial number, and any distinguishing features so it will be easier for us to recover it if we find it.” says Trasmundi. Halton Police recovers 200 bikes per year on average. Only about 10-15 of them are returned. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Thousands of students walk out at Western University protesting the sexual… Local News Investigators say the father was the target of the home invasion,… Local News Billy Mason’s killer sentenced Local News One weekend left before Canadians cast their ballots WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton If you don’t live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor Local News Halton Main News Story News If you don’t live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor By Sylvie Lendvay - December 9, 2020, 10:11 am With cases on the rise in Halton Region, Burlington’s Mayor Marianne Meed Ward residents should be concerned. “The simplest message I could give to residents is this: If you don’t live with somebody, assume that they have COVID and conduct yourself accordingly.” Even with the temptation to gather this holiday season, she is urging residents to follow public health guidelines. “Our [Burlington] numbers are going up again, a little bit. There’s been a lot of talk about a vaccine coming; we know we’re getting that but that’s not the silver bullet. That’s not the only solution. We are going to continue, for at least a year, to need to be keeping physical distance, hand washing, wearing a mask when out in public. Those measures are going to be critically important throughout 2021.” Halton reported 92 new cases of COVID-19 Tuesday. St. Anne Catholic Elementary school in Burlington has had to close down one classroom after 4 cases were reported Tuesday night. There are currently active 14 outbreaks in Halton region. The region’s Medical Officer of Health says the region continues to see community transmission. She is asking residents to avoid carpooling, and having coffee and play dates. Local News Halton News Is Halton heading back to a modified Stage 2? By Laura Brody - October 23, 2020, 8:52 pm Premier Doug Ford is concerned about Halton region’s rising case numbers and says a decision will be made by Monday whether or not to send the region back to modified Stage 2. Halton region is approaching 2,000 total COVID-19 cases; half of which have been recorded in the last two months. “We’re going to have to discuss that over the weekend and we’ll have that answer on Monday. But folks in Halton, I know they’re doing a great job. It’s concerning right now. I’ve seen the numbers go up.” said Premier Doug Ford. “The premier has been terrific to work with throughout this. We recorded 16 new cases today. That’s like 1 in 35,000 people here. I think curves on small numbers are very unreliable ways to judge the future.” said Oakville Mayor Rob Burton. Oakville has already restricted indoor group fitness classes and team sports. The modified Stage 2 would prohibit indoor dining, and close gyms, fitness centres, cinemas and performance venues. The Niagara Falls location will no longer operate on weekends. New hours will be Monday to Friday 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. Welland’s assessment centre is cutting back to Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Hours at the St. Catharines assessment centre remain the same 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. seven days a week. COVID-19 testing at these centres, which are run by Niagara Health, are by-appointment only. Woman hits McDonald’s worker after refusing to show vaccine certificate: Hamilton police - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 13.9 C Hamilton Friday, September 24, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Wife runs from Simcoe to the Hamilton General to thank doctors… Local News Passport backlash Local News Ontario reports highest COVID testing numbers since spring Ontario News London officials urge Western University students to avoid large homecoming parties WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Local News Woman hits McDonald’s worker after refusing to show vaccine certificate: Hamilton police News Local News Top News Story Woman hits McDonald’s worker after refusing to show vaccine certificate: Hamilton police By Shayla Vize - September 24, 2021, 8:34 am Hamilton police are searching for a woman who struck a McDonald’s employee after she refused to leave the restaurant for failing to show her vaccine certificate. Officers were called to the Walmart on Upper James St. around 9:30 p.m. on Wednesday for a “premise disturbance.” Investigators learned a male and female inside the McDonald’s were arguing with staff about the recently implemented proof-of-vaccination system. Police say the woman was not wearing a mask and refused to show her vaccine certificate. She then took a seat in the dining room and would not leave the store. While officers were en route to the scene, police were told the woman struck a staff member in the face before exiting the restaurant. The duo fled the area before police arrived on scene. Police are trying to determine the identity of the woman. She is described as white, between 25 and 30 years of age, roughly five-foot-seven, with a medium build, and blonde shoulder-length hair. Police say she was wearing black pants and a black jacket. Anyone with information that could help with the investigation is asked to contact police. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Ontario News London officials urge Western University students to avoid large homecoming parties Ontario News Ontario eases capacity limits for some sports, event venues Local News St. Catharines man charged after driver found asleep in stolen vehicle Local News Welland duo charged following police chase and collision WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Local News Fort Erie trio charged after stolen property found in driveway of home News Local News Fort Erie trio charged after stolen property found in driveway of home By Shayla Vize - September 24, 2021, 6:44 am Three Fort Erie residents are facing charges after police discovered stolen property parked in the driveway of a home. On Wednesday, a Niagara police detective was driving along Highland Ave. when he noticed a blue garden trailer parked in a driveway. Police say a green John Deere riding lawn mower was sitting inside the trailer. “The detective recognized the trailer and mower as possibly having been recently stolen from a property in the Ridgeway area of Fort Erie,” police said in a news release. The theft happened sometime overnight Tuesday into Wednesday and some power tools were also stolen. Detectives executed a search warrant at the Highland Ave. home and seized the stolen trailer, the John Deer Riding Lawn Mower and other items linked to the Ridgeway break and enter. Richard Ronald Kinsella, 43, Felicia M. Lyrette, 35, and Eric Michael Hagen, 52, have been arrested and charged possession of property obtained by crime. Hagen also faces a charge of fail to comply with probabtion. Anyone who may have information about this investigation is asked to contact detectives at 905-688-4111, ext. 1022300. Officers were called to the area of Wentworth St. North and Cannon St. East on Wednesday. Police say a man approached two city waste collectors and waved a knife in their direction. The employees were able to get away from the situation safely and proceeded to contact police. Police say the victims were not physically injured during the incident. A 36-year-old man was arrested and charged with assault with a weapon, possession of weapon for dangerous purpose, two counts of possession, and three counts of fail to comply with release order. Emergency crews were called to an address on Concession 13 in Townsend around 2:30 p.m. Thursday. Police learned a person was working in a ginseng field when a piece of equipment from a trailer struck them. The worker suffered life-threatening injuries and was pronounced dead at the scene. The Ministry of Labour has been called in to investigate the incident. Police say more information will be released when it becomes available. Trudeau had hoped the election would result in a majority government but the Liberals fell short of the 170 seats needed to make that happen. An official result will not be announced until nearly 800,000 mail-in ballots are counted. Elections Canada says that process will begin Tuesday. The Liberal party was hovering between 155 and 157 seats early Tuesday morning. The Conservatives were sitting with roughly 120 seats. They will remain the official opposition with leader Erin O’Toole at the helm. O’Toole has been re-elected in the Ontario riding of Durham. He delivered a speech in Oshawa and called on Conservatives not to waiver from the party’s commitment to grow and earn the trust of more voters. NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh has won re-election in his riding of Burnaby-South in British Columbia. Singh said Canadians can count on his New Democrats to continue fighting to help people weather the COVID-19 pandemic under a re-elected Liberal minority government. Green Party Leader Annamie Paul lost in the Ontario riding of Toronto Centre. Locally, many ridings had clear winners while others will have to wait until all ballots are counted. The Grace Anglican Church started the planning process on the centre four years ago. They are calling it “Bobby’s Place”, named after local Bobby Smylie who died from the flu in 2018 at the age of 10. The church says the centre will provide a meeting space to learn, socialize, and grow. Construction on “Bobby’s Place” will begin in a few weeks and they hope to have it finished by the Fall. Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 17.1 C Hamilton Friday, September 24, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Ontario News Ontario eases capacity limits for some sports, event venues Local News St. Catharines man charged after driver found asleep in stolen vehicle Local News Welland duo charged following police chase and collision Local News Welland man charged after targeted stabbing: Niagara Police WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Evening News Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen News Evening News Local News Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen By Laura Brody - December 24, 2019, 4:59 pm Hamilton police have arrested a man in connection with a two-month long investigation into stolen, high-end bikes worth more than $40 000. Police say they executed a search warrant at a home in the east end last Thursday and found 26 mountain bikes, along with bike parts, high-end skis and prohibited weapons. They believe the bikes were stolen from residential and commercial properties in Ancaster, Aldershot and Dundas. They say most of the bikes had been taken apart and the parts had been swapped, to try to disguise them. So far, police have returned 3 of the 26 bikes to their owners, and hope to return the rest of them in the next two weeks. Jason Kane, 43, of Hamilton, is facing a number of charges including two counts of possession of a prohibited weapon, and three counts of possession of stolen property. Police say the investigation is ongoing and more charges could be laid. They recommend that you record the serial number on your bike, and call police if it’s been stolen. Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 11.6 C Hamilton Friday, September 24, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Wife runs from Simcoe to the Hamilton General to thank doctors… Local News Passport backlash Local News Ontario reports highest COVID testing numbers since spring Ontario News London officials urge Western University students to avoid large homecoming parties WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Evening News Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed News Evening News Local News Hamilton Home Page News Story Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed By Laura Brody - October 21, 2019, 6:27 pm Hamilton police have identified the suspect in the city’s tenth homicide of the year, and have issued a warrant for his arrest. Twenty-nine year old Obsa Junedi Mohamed was gunned down outside of Boulevard Billiards on York Boulevard at around 1:30 Saturday morning. Police say his killer was his friend, 26-year-old Ibrahim Issak Hussen. The two men were hanging out with a group of other men for awhile before the shooting. About 10 minutes before the shooting detectives say Junedi Mohamed and Issak Hussen got into a physical altercation. Hussen goes by the street name “Seemo.” Junedi Mohamed’s street name was Nanny or Chappel. Detectives say Hussen shot Mohamed point blank in the head. The whole incident was caught on surveillance video. Surveillance images released in the media led to the driver of the getaway vehicle turning himself in to police on Saturday. That man was arrested for first degree murder and accessory after the fact to murder. Police say he participated in a lengthy interview and was released unconditionally later Saturday. But another man was also in the car and police want to speak to him. They are looking for an Asian male wearing a dark parka with fur trim on the hood. The victim was known to police. He was found by officers hiding after another shooting in the same area back in 2015. At the time he was charged with failing to comply and possession of cocaine. Issak Hussen is also known to police and investigators believe drugs are involved in this incident as well. News Evening News Local News Two Hamilton women were invited to meet Taylor Swift at the star’s Nashville mansion By Laura Brody - August 22, 2019, 5:23 pm Two young women from Hamilton were treated to an experience of a lifetime by their ultra-famous idol- Taylor Swift. The multi-grammy award winning pop star hand selected about 100 mega fans from around the world to attend a secret album preview party at her Nashville mansion and 25-year-old Nichole Ridehalgh and 17-year-old Isabella Rose both got a phone call from Swifts team. Ridehalgh was shocked when she called the call inviting her to a special event. She was asked if she could make it to Nashville in less than a week. Without being told, Ridehalgh knew she had just been invited to an event that is the pinnacle of every Taylor Swift fan’s dream- a secret session album preview at the star’s Nashville mansion. Swift has held secret sessions before the releases of several of her previous albums. Fans are picked up at a secret location and driven to her mansion. Those who attend are always mega fans who the star keeps a close eye on on social media. Getting a one on one chat with the star is something Ridehalgh will never forget. “Its 4:30 in the morning, I’m exhausted but, this is my moment. I walk into the room and I turn to my left and I see her and she says hey your Nichole right?Aand in that moment my whole world was made. Without me mentioning Canada at all, she said have a safe flight back to Canada” Swift even shared secret details about her personal life with fans. Isabella Rose is also on a first name basis with Swift. She posted on social media saying “I have loved her for nine years and I will never stop talking about how much I love her but I would not be where I am today without her.” Tonight is the release of Swift’s newest album, Lover. Ridehalgh and Rose were two of 113 fans in the world, that have already heard it. “She was lip syncing and dancing. She was just having a blast.” And that night is a night these young women will replay over and over again. The Ontario Life Saving Society says not wearing a life jacket was a factor in 88% of boat-related deaths. Alcohol played a part in 40% of boat-related deaths. There were 50 search and rescue calls in the Niagara Region in the year 2020. There have been 33 calls in 2021 so far. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Local News Wife runs from Simcoe to the Hamilton General to thank doctors… Local News Passport backlash Local News Ontario reports highest COVID testing numbers since spring Ontario News London officials urge Western University students to avoid large homecoming parties WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility Local News Halton Hamilton News Home Page News Story Ontario News Top News Story Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility By Sylvie Lendvay - May 10, 2021, 11:08 am The province says the eligibility to receive a COVID-19 vaccine will expand the week of May 10th to include people with “at-risk” health conditions, people who cannot work from home (Group 2), and people 40 and older. Starting Tuesday May 11 at 8 a.m, people with “at-risk” health conditions such as immune deficiencies, cancer, diabetes, and asthma will be able to book an appointment either through the provincial portal or their region’s website. Also Tuesday morning, people in Group 2 who cannot work from home including those who work in essential retail, courts and banks can book. Social workers, veterinarians and miners are also apart of the list that can be found here. Thursday May 13 at 8 a.m, people turning 40 in 2021 and older in non-hot spot communities can book a vaccine appointment at a mass immunization clinic. Halton Region has expanded its’ vaccination program to allow residents 16 and older who cannot work from home to book an appointment through the regions online portal. Halton residents 50 and older living in non-hot spot communities can also book. Wednesday May 12 eligibility opens to those 40 and older, Friday May 14 to those 30 and older, and by next week all Halton adults over the age of 16 will be eligible to book an appointment. Halton residents 16+ who cannot work from home can now book a COVID vaccine appointment… as well as anyone 50+. May 12 – 40+. May 14 – 30+. May 19 – 16+. They are following provincial criteria for expanding program based on risk… have enough supply to do it early. @CHCHNews pic.twitter.com/VYwEmaGKLO — Sylvie Lendvay (@sylvie_lendvay) May 10, 2021 Halton region says they are following provincial criteria for expanding eligibility based on who is most at risk, but they have enough supply to do it early. There are several pilot clinics across the province vaccinating residents 18 and older. Four pharmacies in Hamilton are approved to administer Moderna. Each location will receive about 150 shots a week. Adults 40 and older can still book an AstraZeneca vaccine at a participating pharmacy. All booking availability will depend on supply. Constable Frank Trasmundi with Halton Police says sometimes when people report their bicycle stolen, the owner won’t have the serial number. If that’s the case, police can’t return it or lay charges. He says downloading the app ‘529 Garage’ can help people file a report. “We will have picture of your bike, the serial number, and any distinguishing features so it will be easier for us to recover it if we find it.” says Trasmundi. Halton Police recovers 200 bikes per year on average. Only about 10-15 of them are returned. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Ontario News London officials urge Western University students to avoid large homecoming parties Ontario News Ontario eases capacity limits for some sports, event venues Local News St. Catharines man charged after driver found asleep in stolen vehicle Local News Welland duo charged following police chase and collision WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton If you don’t live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor Local News Halton Main News Story News If you don’t live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor By Sylvie Lendvay - December 9, 2020, 10:11 am With cases on the rise in Halton Region, Burlington’s Mayor Marianne Meed Ward residents should be concerned. “The simplest message I could give to residents is this: If you don’t live with somebody, assume that they have COVID and conduct yourself accordingly.” Even with the temptation to gather this holiday season, she is urging residents to follow public health guidelines. “Our [Burlington] numbers are going up again, a little bit. There’s been a lot of talk about a vaccine coming; we know we’re getting that but that’s not the silver bullet. That’s not the only solution. We are going to continue, for at least a year, to need to be keeping physical distance, hand washing, wearing a mask when out in public. Those measures are going to be critically important throughout 2021.” Halton reported 92 new cases of COVID-19 Tuesday. St. Anne Catholic Elementary school in Burlington has had to close down one classroom after 4 cases were reported Tuesday night. There are currently active 14 outbreaks in Halton region. The region’s Medical Officer of Health says the region continues to see community transmission. She is asking residents to avoid carpooling, and having coffee and play dates. Local News Halton News Is Halton heading back to a modified Stage 2? By Laura Brody - October 23, 2020, 8:52 pm Premier Doug Ford is concerned about Halton region’s rising case numbers and says a decision will be made by Monday whether or not to send the region back to modified Stage 2. Halton region is approaching 2,000 total COVID-19 cases; half of which have been recorded in the last two months. “We’re going to have to discuss that over the weekend and we’ll have that answer on Monday. But folks in Halton, I know they’re doing a great job. It’s concerning right now. I’ve seen the numbers go up.” said Premier Doug Ford. “The premier has been terrific to work with throughout this. We recorded 16 new cases today. That’s like 1 in 35,000 people here. I think curves on small numbers are very unreliable ways to judge the future.” said Oakville Mayor Rob Burton. Oakville has already restricted indoor group fitness classes and team sports. The modified Stage 2 would prohibit indoor dining, and close gyms, fitness centres, cinemas and performance venues. The Niagara Falls location will no longer operate on weekends. New hours will be Monday to Friday 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. Welland’s assessment centre is cutting back to Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Hours at the St. Catharines assessment centre remain the same 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. seven days a week. COVID-19 testing at these centres, which are run by Niagara Health, are by-appointment only. Local News Hamilton News Home Page News Story Mix up at Hamilton lab resulted in 14 people given incorrect COVID-19 test results By News Staff - September 30, 2021, 4:17 pm A processing error at Hamilton Regional Laboratory Medicine Program resulted in 14 people receiving incorrect COVID-19 test results. Two of the false-positive tests played a role in outbreaks being declared at two Hamilton schools, Lisgar Elementary school and Bishop Ryan Catholic Secondary school. Hamilton public health has since rescinded the outbreaks. Seven other people who were told they did not have the virus actually did. All individuals who received incorrect test results have been contacted. In January the lab made a similar mistake with 31 people getting the wrong results. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Hamilton Ministry of Labour investigating complaint lodged at Hamilton restaurant Hamilton Pet therapy returns to Burlington retirement home Main News Story Ontario makes COVID-19 vaccines mandatory for long-term care staff Ontario News Ontario mandating COVID-19 vaccinations for staff at long-term care homes WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Local News Two fake cops assault senior, steal SUV in Caledonia: OPP News Local News Two fake cops assault senior, steal SUV in Caledonia: OPP By Shayla Vize - September 30, 2021, 12:15 pm Ontario Provincial Police (OPP) is investigating after two men claiming to be police officers assaulted a senior and stole their vehicle. Officers responded to reports of a robbery on Argyle St. North in Caledonia shortly before 5 a.m. on Wednesday. Police learned a 75-year-old resident was assaulted by two men who had identified themselves as police officers. The duo then stole the victim’s red 2008 Hyundai Tuscon with licence plate AXAM 062. Investigators describe the suspects as white men in their early 20s. They were well-spoken and were wearing dark clothing with their hoods up. Police are asking anyone who may have witnessed the assault or who has seen the stolen vehicle to contact OPP at 1-888-310-1122. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Hamilton Ministry of Labour investigating complaint lodged at Hamilton restaurant Hamilton Pet therapy returns to Burlington retirement home Main News Story Ontario makes COVID-19 vaccines mandatory for long-term care staff Ontario News Ontario mandating COVID-19 vaccinations for staff at long-term care homes WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Canada & The World Annamie Paul is resigning as Green Party leader News Canada & The World Top News Story Annamie Paul is resigning as Green Party leader By Amanda Pope - September 27, 2021, 2:39 pm Annamie Paul was the leader of the Green Party since October 2020 (Twitter/@AnnamiePaul). Green Party Leader Annamie Paul is stepping down just one week after her loss during the federal election. Paul announced her resignation Monday morning in Toronto, saying she does not have the heart to keep this position after learning that a leadership review had been initiated. “I just asked myself whether this is something that I wanted to continue, whether I was willing to continue to put up with the attacks I knew would be coming, whether to continue to have to fight and struggle just to fulfill my democratically elected role as leader of this party,’” Paul said. “I just don’t have the heart for it.” In the 2021 federal election, Paul did not win her seat in the riding of Toronto-Centre and just two seats went to the Greens in the House of Commons. The Greens’ share of the popular vote also decreased as they drew 2.3 per cent, which is less than half of the 6.55 per cent they received in the last election. “The election was very difficult,” Paul said. She attributed it to a lack of funding, campaign staff and a national campaign manager. Following her announcement, leaders of other federal parties responded to the news on Twitter. Thank you @AnnamiePaul for your leadership. For your resilience and perseverance. You made it possible for an entire generation of Canadians to see themselves reflected in politics. On behalf of so many Canadians, thank you. — Jagmeet Singh (@theJagmeetSingh) September 27, 2021 Thank you @annamiepaul for your perseverance & for being a trailblazer for Canadians from all backgrounds interested in public service. I always appreciated our discussions and admire your tenacity. Wishing you and your family well. — Erin O'Toole (@erinotoole) September 27, 2021 Although I completely disagree with her political views, I have great respect for @AnnamiePaul. She is a nice and decent person, something I cannot say about other party leaders. She was viciously attacked by extremists in her party. I wish her good luck in her next endeavours. — Maxime Bernier (@MaximeBernier) September 27, 2021 Paul was the leader of the Green Party since October 2020 and the first Black Jewish woman to lead a major political party in Canada. There is currently no word on who will replace her. Michael Kovrig, Michael Spavor return to Canada after detention in China - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 21.1 C Hamilton Friday, October 1, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Ontario News Ontario mandating COVID-19 vaccinations for staff at long-term care homes Canada & The World Trudeau under fire after spending 1st National Day for Truth and… Local News Ontario reports 1,315 new COVID-19 cases over two days Local News Niagara Falls brings back ‘Spooky Awards’ for second year WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Canada & The World Michael Kovrig, Michael Spavor return to Canada after detention in China News Canada & The World Top News Story Michael Kovrig, Michael Spavor return to Canada after detention in China By Amanda Pope - September 25, 2021, 2:01 pm Canadians Michael Spavor and Michael Kovrig have been detained since December 2018. Two Canadians who spent almost three years detained in Chinese prisons returned to Canada Saturday morning. Michael Kovrig and Michael Spavor arrived at Calgary International Airport around 8 a.m. EDT. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and Global Affairs Minister Marc Garneau welcomed the two Michaels before they reunited with loved ones. Spavor remained in Calgary with family, while Kovrig boarded a plane destined for Toronto. Kovrig arrived just before 1 p.m. at Toronto Pearson International Airport. Kovrig and Spavor departed for Canada late Friday night shortly after Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou flew to China after solving her legal conflict with the U-S. The case came to an end Friday once Meng pleaded not guilty to fraud and conspiracy charges involving American sanctions against Iran. Meng then walked out of a British Columbia Supreme Court after a judge agreed to a discharge order that withdrew a U-S extradition request that led to her 2018 arrest in Vancouver. The two Michaels were arrested in China on espionage charges days later in 2018 but China has always denied accusations it was retaliating for Meng’s arrest. Kovrig and Spavor endured harsh conditions in Chinese prisons where they could barely access the outside world. Meng, however, was kept under house arrest at her Vancouver mansion.
