CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Hamilton Ministry of Labour investigating complaint lodged at Hamilton restaurant Hamilton Pet therapy returns to Burlington retirement home Main News Story Ontario makes COVID-19 vaccines mandatory for long-term care staff Ontario News Ontario mandating COVID-19 vaccinations for staff at long-term care homes WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Canada News Justin Trudeau’s Liberal party wins minority government News Canada News Top News Story Justin Trudeau’s Liberal party wins minority government By Shayla Vize - September 21, 2021, 6:46 am Justin Trudeau will serve a third term as Prime Minister after the Liberal party captured a minority government in the 2021 federal election. Trudeau had hoped the election would result in a majority government but the Liberals fell short of the 170 seats needed to make that happen. An official result will not be announced until nearly 800,000 mail-in ballots are counted. Elections Canada says that process will begin Tuesday. The Liberal party was hovering between 155 and 157 seats early Tuesday morning. The Conservatives were sitting with roughly 120 seats. They will remain the official opposition with leader Erin O’Toole at the helm. O’Toole has been re-elected in the Ontario riding of Durham. He delivered a speech in Oshawa and called on Conservatives not to waiver from the party’s commitment to grow and earn the trust of more voters. NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh has won re-election in his riding of Burnaby-South in British Columbia. Singh said Canadians can count on his New Democrats to continue fighting to help people weather the COVID-19 pandemic under a re-elected Liberal minority government. Green Party Leader Annamie Paul lost in the Ontario riding of Toronto Centre. Locally, many ridings had clear winners while others will have to wait until all ballots are counted. The Grace Anglican Church started the planning process on the centre four years ago. They are calling it “Bobby’s Place”, named after local Bobby Smylie who died from the flu in 2018 at the age of 10. The church says the centre will provide a meeting space to learn, socialize, and grow. Construction on “Bobby’s Place” will begin in a few weeks and they hope to have it finished by the Fall. Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 21.1 C Hamilton Friday, October 1, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Ontario News Ontario mandating COVID-19 vaccinations for staff at long-term care homes Canada & The World Trudeau under fire after spending 1st National Day for Truth and… Local News Ontario reports 1,315 new COVID-19 cases over two days Local News Niagara Falls brings back ‘Spooky Awards’ for second year WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Evening News Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen News Evening News Local News Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen By Laura Brody - December 24, 2019, 4:59 pm Hamilton police have arrested a man in connection with a two-month long investigation into stolen, high-end bikes worth more than $40 000. Police say they executed a search warrant at a home in the east end last Thursday and found 26 mountain bikes, along with bike parts, high-end skis and prohibited weapons. They believe the bikes were stolen from residential and commercial properties in Ancaster, Aldershot and Dundas. They say most of the bikes had been taken apart and the parts had been swapped, to try to disguise them. So far, police have returned 3 of the 26 bikes to their owners, and hope to return the rest of them in the next two weeks. Jason Kane, 43, of Hamilton, is facing a number of charges including two counts of possession of a prohibited weapon, and three counts of possession of stolen property. Police say the investigation is ongoing and more charges could be laid. They recommend that you record the serial number on your bike, and call police if it’s been stolen. Twenty-nine year old Obsa Junedi Mohamed was gunned down outside of Boulevard Billiards on York Boulevard at around 1:30 Saturday morning. Police say his killer was his friend, 26-year-old Ibrahim Issak Hussen. The two men were hanging out with a group of other men for awhile before the shooting. About 10 minutes before the shooting detectives say Junedi Mohamed and Issak Hussen got into a physical altercation. Hussen goes by the street name “Seemo.” Junedi Mohamed’s street name was Nanny or Chappel. Detectives say Hussen shot Mohamed point blank in the head. The whole incident was caught on surveillance video. Surveillance images released in the media led to the driver of the getaway vehicle turning himself in to police on Saturday. That man was arrested for first degree murder and accessory after the fact to murder. Police say he participated in a lengthy interview and was released unconditionally later Saturday. But another man was also in the car and police want to speak to him. They are looking for an Asian male wearing a dark parka with fur trim on the hood. The victim was known to police. He was found by officers hiding after another shooting in the same area back in 2015. At the time he was charged with failing to comply and possession of cocaine. Issak Hussen is also known to police and investigators believe drugs are involved in this incident as well. News Evening News Local News Two Hamilton women were invited to meet Taylor Swift at the star’s Nashville mansion By Laura Brody - August 22, 2019, 5:23 pm Two young women from Hamilton were treated to an experience of a lifetime by their ultra-famous idol- Taylor Swift. The multi-grammy award winning pop star hand selected about 100 mega fans from around the world to attend a secret album preview party at her Nashville mansion and 25-year-old Nichole Ridehalgh and 17-year-old Isabella Rose both got a phone call from Swifts team. Ridehalgh was shocked when she called the call inviting her to a special event. She was asked if she could make it to Nashville in less than a week. Without being told, Ridehalgh knew she had just been invited to an event that is the pinnacle of every Taylor Swift fan’s dream- a secret session album preview at the star’s Nashville mansion. Swift has held secret sessions before the releases of several of her previous albums. Fans are picked up at a secret location and driven to her mansion. Those who attend are always mega fans who the star keeps a close eye on on social media. Getting a one on one chat with the star is something Ridehalgh will never forget. “Its 4:30 in the morning, I’m exhausted but, this is my moment. I walk into the room and I turn to my left and I see her and she says hey your Nichole right?Aand in that moment my whole world was made. Without me mentioning Canada at all, she said have a safe flight back to Canada” Swift even shared secret details about her personal life with fans. Isabella Rose is also on a first name basis with Swift. She posted on social media saying “I have loved her for nine years and I will never stop talking about how much I love her but I would not be where I am today without her.” Tonight is the release of Swift’s newest album, Lover. Ridehalgh and Rose were two of 113 fans in the world, that have already heard it. “She was lip syncing and dancing. She was just having a blast.” And that night is a night these young women will replay over and over again. The Ontario Life Saving Society says not wearing a life jacket was a factor in 88% of boat-related deaths. Alcohol played a part in 40% of boat-related deaths. There were 50 search and rescue calls in the Niagara Region in the year 2020. There have been 33 calls in 2021 so far. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Hamilton Ministry of Labour investigating complaint lodged at Hamilton restaurant Hamilton Pet therapy returns to Burlington retirement home Main News Story Ontario makes COVID-19 vaccines mandatory for long-term care staff Ontario News Ontario mandating COVID-19 vaccinations for staff at long-term care homes WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Local News Police investigate sexual assault of teen at Spencer Smith Park News Local News Top News Story Police investigate sexual assault of teen at Spencer Smith Park By Shayla Vize - September 30, 2021, 8:47 am Halton police are searching for a man after a teen girl was sexually assaulted at Spencer Smith Park. Police say a 17-year-old girl was sitting on a bench along the Waterfront Trail around 6:30 p.m. on Sept. 20. A man in his 50s or 60s was seen taking photos of the girl. Police say he then sat beside the teen and touched her breast before fleeing the area on foot. The suspect is described by police as Asian, roughly five-foot-nine, with a thin build, and noticeable wrinkles. He spoke with a thick accent and was wearing a white t-shirt with red sleeves, and a grey baseball hat with a white design on the front. The man was carrying a cell phone with a bright red case. Investigators are hoping to speak with two young males who may have witnessed the incident on the bench. Police say one of the boys was on a bike and the other was riding a skateboard. Anyone with information that could help police with the investigation is asked to contact detectives at 905-825-4777, ext. 8971. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Hamilton Ministry of Labour investigating complaint lodged at Hamilton restaurant Hamilton Pet therapy returns to Burlington retirement home Main News Story Ontario makes COVID-19 vaccines mandatory for long-term care staff Ontario News Ontario mandating COVID-19 vaccinations for staff at long-term care homes WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility Local News Halton Hamilton News Home Page News Story Ontario News Top News Story Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility By Sylvie Lendvay - May 10, 2021, 11:08 am The province says the eligibility to receive a COVID-19 vaccine will expand the week of May 10th to include people with “at-risk” health conditions, people who cannot work from home (Group 2), and people 40 and older. Starting Tuesday May 11 at 8 a.m, people with “at-risk” health conditions such as immune deficiencies, cancer, diabetes, and asthma will be able to book an appointment either through the provincial portal or their region’s website. Also Tuesday morning, people in Group 2 who cannot work from home including those who work in essential retail, courts and banks can book. Social workers, veterinarians and miners are also apart of the list that can be found here. Thursday May 13 at 8 a.m, people turning 40 in 2021 and older in non-hot spot communities can book a vaccine appointment at a mass immunization clinic. Halton Region has expanded its’ vaccination program to allow residents 16 and older who cannot work from home to book an appointment through the regions online portal. Halton residents 50 and older living in non-hot spot communities can also book. Wednesday May 12 eligibility opens to those 40 and older, Friday May 14 to those 30 and older, and by next week all Halton adults over the age of 16 will be eligible to book an appointment. Halton residents 16+ who cannot work from home can now book a COVID vaccine appointment… as well as anyone 50+. May 12 – 40+. May 14 – 30+. May 19 – 16+. They are following provincial criteria for expanding program based on risk… have enough supply to do it early. @CHCHNews pic.twitter.com/VYwEmaGKLO — Sylvie Lendvay (@sylvie_lendvay) May 10, 2021 Halton region says they are following provincial criteria for expanding eligibility based on who is most at risk, but they have enough supply to do it early. There are several pilot clinics across the province vaccinating residents 18 and older. Four pharmacies in Hamilton are approved to administer Moderna. Each location will receive about 150 shots a week. Adults 40 and older can still book an AstraZeneca vaccine at a participating pharmacy. All booking availability will depend on supply. Constable Frank Trasmundi with Halton Police says sometimes when people report their bicycle stolen, the owner won’t have the serial number. If that’s the case, police can’t return it or lay charges. He says downloading the app ‘529 Garage’ can help people file a report. “We will have picture of your bike, the serial number, and any distinguishing features so it will be easier for us to recover it if we find it.” says Trasmundi. Halton Police recovers 200 bikes per year on average. Only about 10-15 of them are returned. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Hamilton Ministry of Labour investigating complaint lodged at Hamilton restaurant Hamilton Pet therapy returns to Burlington retirement home Main News Story Ontario makes COVID-19 vaccines mandatory for long-term care staff Ontario News Ontario mandating COVID-19 vaccinations for staff at long-term care homes WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton If you don’t live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor Local News Halton Main News Story News If you don’t live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor By Sylvie Lendvay - December 9, 2020, 10:11 am With cases on the rise in Halton Region, Burlington’s Mayor Marianne Meed Ward residents should be concerned. “The simplest message I could give to residents is this: If you don’t live with somebody, assume that they have COVID and conduct yourself accordingly.” Even with the temptation to gather this holiday season, she is urging residents to follow public health guidelines. “Our [Burlington] numbers are going up again, a little bit. There’s been a lot of talk about a vaccine coming; we know we’re getting that but that’s not the silver bullet. That’s not the only solution. We are going to continue, for at least a year, to need to be keeping physical distance, hand washing, wearing a mask when out in public. Those measures are going to be critically important throughout 2021.” Halton reported 92 new cases of COVID-19 Tuesday. St. Anne Catholic Elementary school in Burlington has had to close down one classroom after 4 cases were reported Tuesday night. There are currently active 14 outbreaks in Halton region. The region’s Medical Officer of Health says the region continues to see community transmission. She is asking residents to avoid carpooling, and having coffee and play dates. Local News Halton News Is Halton heading back to a modified Stage 2? By Laura Brody - October 23, 2020, 8:52 pm Premier Doug Ford is concerned about Halton region’s rising case numbers and says a decision will be made by Monday whether or not to send the region back to modified Stage 2. Halton region is approaching 2,000 total COVID-19 cases; half of which have been recorded in the last two months. “We’re going to have to discuss that over the weekend and we’ll have that answer on Monday. But folks in Halton, I know they’re doing a great job. It’s concerning right now. I’ve seen the numbers go up.” said Premier Doug Ford. “The premier has been terrific to work with throughout this. We recorded 16 new cases today. That’s like 1 in 35,000 people here. I think curves on small numbers are very unreliable ways to judge the future.” said Oakville Mayor Rob Burton. Oakville has already restricted indoor group fitness classes and team sports. The modified Stage 2 would prohibit indoor dining, and close gyms, fitness centres, cinemas and performance venues. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Hamilton Ministry of Labour investigating complaint lodged at Hamilton restaurant Hamilton Pet therapy returns to Burlington retirement home Main News Story Ontario makes COVID-19 vaccines mandatory for long-term care staff Ontario News Ontario mandating COVID-19 vaccinations for staff at long-term care homes WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Hamilton Hamilton Police Services Board appoints Paul Hamilton as Deputy Chief Local News Hamilton News Top News Story Hamilton Police Services Board appoints Paul Hamilton as Deputy Chief By Amanda Pope - September 27, 2021, 3:27 pm The Hamilton Police Services Board has appointed Paul Hamilton as the new Deputy Chief of Police. Hamilton Mayor Fred Eisenberger, who is also the chair of the board, made the announcement Monday at Central police station. “This is an exciting day for our service and concludes an extensive recruitment process that involved diverse candidates from both in and outside of Canada, to determine the best individual to support us in fulfilling our mission to serve and protect the citizens of Hamilton,” Eisenberger said. Hamilton, a 31-year member of the service, officially begins his new position today. He has a wide variety of experience within the police force such as holding the position of acting deputy chief of support services and superintendent in the investigative services division. Hamilton was also the leading investigator in several major cases that partnered with domestic and international law enforcement agencies. Hamilton studied sociology and criminology at the University of Ottawa. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Hamilton Ministry of Labour investigating complaint lodged at Hamilton restaurant Hamilton Pet therapy returns to Burlington retirement home Main News Story Ontario makes COVID-19 vaccines mandatory for long-term care staff Ontario News Ontario mandating COVID-19 vaccinations for staff at long-term care homes WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Hamilton Hamilton police investigate city’s 15th homicide of the year Local News Hamilton News Top News Story Hamilton police investigate city’s 15th homicide of the year By Amanda Pope - September 25, 2021, 12:33 pm Hamilton police are investigating after an 18-year-old man was shot in the city’s east end. It happened shortly after 4:30 p.m. Friday in the area of Cannon St. East and Barnesdale Ave. North. The victim was walking when he was approached by a dark-coloured four-door sedan. Multiple shots were fired from the car, hitting the victim. He was transported to hospital where he was pronounced dead. Investigators have identified the shooting victim as 18-year-old Yua Blut Kaw, of Hamilton. At this time, police do not have a description of the suspects. There will be a heavy police presence in the area today in hopes of finding additional witnesses and video surveillance. This is the city’s 15th homicide of the year. Anyone with information that could help police with the investigation is asked to contact Det. David Tsuchida at 905-546-4123. The Niagara Falls location will no longer operate on weekends. New hours will be Monday to Friday 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. Welland’s assessment centre is cutting back to Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Hours at the St. Catharines assessment centre remain the same 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. seven days a week. COVID-19 testing at these centres, which are run by Niagara Health, are by-appointment only. Local News UPDATE: Hamilton police arrest one person in connection with Mount Hope… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Local News Man charged with attempted murder of sex worker in Hamilton News Local News Man charged with attempted murder of sex worker in Hamilton By Shayla Vize - October 8, 2021, 6:03 am Hamilton police have charged 47-year-old Peter Pasco with attempted murder. A 47-year-old man has been arrested in connection with the attempted murder of a sex worker in Hamilton. Shortly after 5 p.m. on Tuesday, officers responded to a home where a woman in her 40s had been sexually assaulted. Peter Pasco, of Woodstock, has been charged with attempted murder. Detectives from the Hamilton Police Sexual Assault Unit have taken over the investigation and believe that there may be more victims. Investigators say Pasco is known to travel “over a large geographical area.” Police are encouraging sexual assault survivors to contact the Sexual Assault Unit at 905-540-5553 to report a crime. Local News UPDATE: Hamilton police arrest one person in connection with Mount Hope… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Canada & The World Canada providing data to countries who do not accept mixed-dose travellers News Canada & The World Top News Story Canada providing data to countries who do not accept mixed-dose travellers By Amanda Pope - October 4, 2021, 7:27 pm Chief public health officer Dr. Theresa Tam says the agency has provided data on the effectiveness of mixed doses to the U.S. and other top-priority destinations. The Public Health Agency of Canada says it’s working with other governments still uncertain about allowing Canadians with mixed vaccines to enter their countries. The United States is one of multiple countries that only recognize people with two identical doses of an approved vaccine as being fully vaccinated. Oxford-AstraZeneca is not an approved vaccine in several places. Chief public health officer Dr. Theresa Tam says the agency has provided data on the effectiveness of mixed doses to the U.S. and other top-priority destinations. She says Canada has been spreading information about the effectiveness of mixing Oxford-AstraZeneca with m-R-N-A vaccines like Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna. At least 3.88 million fully vaccinated Canadians have received two different kinds of shots, not including those from Quebec where data on mixed vaccines is unavailable. Of those, around 1.5 million Canadians received a first dose of Oxford-AstraZeneca or Covishield, which uses the same formula. Facebook and its Instagram and WhatsApp are down for thousands of users around the world. The outage began around 11:45 a.m. EDT on Monday. While the company is aware that many people are having trouble accessing the apps, they did not say what could be causing the outage. According to downdetector.ca, Facebook reported 20,000 outages as of noon Monday, Instagram had over 15,000 reports and WhatsApp reported more than 7,000 issues. Facebook said in a tweet that they are working on restoring access. We’re aware that some people are having trouble accessing our apps and products. News Canada & The World Ontario News Top News Story Ambassador Bridge reopens for Canada to U.S. traffic after possible explosives were found By Amanda Pope - October 4, 2021, 2:02 pm The Ambassador Bridge was closed in both directions Monday morning as police investigated suspected explosives found in a vehicle. The Ambassador Bridge border crossing has reopened to traffic travelling from Canada to the United States as police continue to investigate possible explosives. The bridge that connects Windsor, Ont., and Detroit, Mich., was closed in both directions Monday morning as police investigated suspected explosives found in a vehicle. The neighbourhoods near the bridge have also been evacuated. Windsor, Ont., police are still investigating but note that there were no direct threats made to people or places in connection with the possible explosives. #AmbassadorBridge from Canada to U.S. is now open with access off of Wyandotte Street West only. Case #21-95217 — Windsor Police (@WindsorPolice) October 4, 2021 The Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA) alerted police after the potential explosives were found in a vehicle in the secondary inspection area of the bridge complex. Traffic is being re-routed to the Windsor-Detroit Tunnel and the Blue Water Bridge at Sarnia, Ont. The CBSA says they will depend on emergency and highway officials to indicate when it is safe to resume travel across the bridge. Police are asking the public to avoid the area right now. Local News UPDATE: Hamilton police arrest one person in connection with Mount Hope… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Canada & The World Health Canada recalls Advil’s mislabelled Cold and Sinus Day/Night Convenience Packs News Canada & The World Top News Story Health Canada recalls Advil’s mislabelled Cold and Sinus Day/Night Convenience Packs By Amanda Pope - October 4, 2021, 1:19 pm Two lots of Advil's Cold and Sinus Day/Night Convenience Pack are being recalled due to a labelling mistake (Health Canada). Packages of Advil’s Cold and Sinus Day/Night Convenience Pack are being recalled due to a labelling mistake. The boxes of 18 and 36 caplets were affected as the night-time doses were mislabelled as daytime and vice versa. Health Canada says there are concerns about consumers mixing up the medications. The health agency also says taking a night-time caplet could lead to serious health consequences for the elderly, anyone driving or for those who have taken other sedatives or consumed alcohol. The affected products were distributed in Canada beginning last July. Local News UPDATE: Hamilton police arrest one person in connection with Mount Hope… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Canada News Trudeau ‘regrets’ trip to B.C. on National Day for Truth and Reconciliation News Canada News Top News Story Trudeau ‘regrets’ trip to B.C. on National Day for Truth and Reconciliation By Shayla Vize - October 6, 2021, 12:28 pm Video of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau walking along a beach on National Day for Truth and Reconciliation in B.C. has sparked backlash. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau says he regrets traveling to meet his vacationing family in British Columbia on the country’s inaugural National Day for Truth and Reconciliation. During a COVID-19 news conference being held in Ottawa Wednesday morning, Trudeau acknowledged the trip was an error. “Traveling on September 30 was a mistake and I regret it. The first National Day for Truth and Reconciliation was a time for Indigenous people and non-Indigenous people alike to reflect and connect. To think about the past, but also focus on the future,” said Trudeau. Trudeau was captured on video by a Global News cameraperson walking along a beach in Tofino, B.C. while declining to make any comment. The video came as a shock because the Prime Minister’s itinerary stated he was in Ottawa for private meetings. According to The Canadian Press, a spokesman for Trudeau said he spent several hours on the phone with eight people who lived through residential schools and denied that the prime minister had used the historic day to take a vacation. The trip sparked widespread backlash from Indigenous leaders, who felt it was disrespectful of him not to join other politicians in attending events held to honour the children who never came home. Local News UPDATE: Hamilton police arrest one person in connection with Mount Hope… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Canada News Travelers within Canada, all federal employees must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 News Canada News Top News Story Travelers within Canada, all federal employees must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 By Shayla Vize - October 6, 2021, 12:02 pm All federal employees and anyone wanting to travel by plane, train or sea vessel must be fully vaccinated by the end of the month. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced the new federal policy during a news conference in Ottawa Wednesday morning. There will be a one-month grace period where proof of a negative COVID-19 test will be accepted for travel but by November 30, all travelers in federally regulated air, rail and marine services will need to be fully vaccinated. The government says testing exemptions will only be allowed in extremely limited emergency situations. Air travel operators will be responsible for verifying proof of vaccination which can include paper copies or provincial vaccination passports. The government says it will work with the cruise industry to put in place strict requirements ahead of the 2022 cruise season. Federal employees have until October 29 to provide their vaccine status after which they could have limited access to their workplace or be placed on administrative leave without pay. The policy applies to more than 267,000 workers. It does not apply to employees of crown corporations or members of the Canadian Armed Forces, however, they are asked to enforce similar measures. The Grace Anglican Church started the planning process on the centre four years ago. They are calling it “Bobby’s Place”, named after local Bobby Smylie who died from the flu in 2018 at the age of 10. The church says the centre will provide a meeting space to learn, socialize, and grow. Construction on “Bobby’s Place” will begin in a few weeks and they hope to have it finished by the Fall. WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Evening News Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen News Evening News Local News Hamilton police arrest man after 26 high-end bikes were stolen By Laura Brody - December 24, 2019, 4:59 pm Hamilton police have arrested a man in connection with a two-month long investigation into stolen, high-end bikes worth more than $40 000. Police say they executed a search warrant at a home in the east end last Thursday and found 26 mountain bikes, along with bike parts, high-end skis and prohibited weapons. They believe the bikes were stolen from residential and commercial properties in Ancaster, Aldershot and Dundas. They say most of the bikes had been taken apart and the parts had been swapped, to try to disguise them. So far, police have returned 3 of the 26 bikes to their owners, and hope to return the rest of them in the next two weeks. Jason Kane, 43, of Hamilton, is facing a number of charges including two counts of possession of a prohibited weapon, and three counts of possession of stolen property. Police say the investigation is ongoing and more charges could be laid. They recommend that you record the serial number on your bike, and call police if it’s been stolen. Local News UPDATE: Hamilton police arrest one person in connection with Mount Hope… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home News Evening News Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed News Evening News Local News Hamilton Home Page News Story Suspect identified in the murder of Obsa Junedi Mohamed By Laura Brody - October 21, 2019, 6:27 pm Hamilton police have identified the suspect in the city’s tenth homicide of the year, and have issued a warrant for his arrest. Twenty-nine year old Obsa Junedi Mohamed was gunned down outside of Boulevard Billiards on York Boulevard at around 1:30 Saturday morning. Police say his killer was his friend, 26-year-old Ibrahim Issak Hussen. The two men were hanging out with a group of other men for awhile before the shooting. About 10 minutes before the shooting detectives say Junedi Mohamed and Issak Hussen got into a physical altercation. Hussen goes by the street name “Seemo.” Junedi Mohamed’s street name was Nanny or Chappel. Detectives say Hussen shot Mohamed point blank in the head. The whole incident was caught on surveillance video. Surveillance images released in the media led to the driver of the getaway vehicle turning himself in to police on Saturday. That man was arrested for first degree murder and accessory after the fact to murder. Police say he participated in a lengthy interview and was released unconditionally later Saturday. But another man was also in the car and police want to speak to him. They are looking for an Asian male wearing a dark parka with fur trim on the hood. The victim was known to police. He was found by officers hiding after another shooting in the same area back in 2015. At the time he was charged with failing to comply and possession of cocaine. Issak Hussen is also known to police and investigators believe drugs are involved in this incident as well. News Evening News Local News Two Hamilton women were invited to meet Taylor Swift at the star’s Nashville mansion By Laura Brody - August 22, 2019, 5:23 pm Two young women from Hamilton were treated to an experience of a lifetime by their ultra-famous idol- Taylor Swift. The multi-grammy award winning pop star hand selected about 100 mega fans from around the world to attend a secret album preview party at her Nashville mansion and 25-year-old Nichole Ridehalgh and 17-year-old Isabella Rose both got a phone call from Swifts team. Ridehalgh was shocked when she called the call inviting her to a special event. She was asked if she could make it to Nashville in less than a week. Without being told, Ridehalgh knew she had just been invited to an event that is the pinnacle of every Taylor Swift fan’s dream- a secret session album preview at the star’s Nashville mansion. Swift has held secret sessions before the releases of several of her previous albums. Fans are picked up at a secret location and driven to her mansion. Those who attend are always mega fans who the star keeps a close eye on on social media. Getting a one on one chat with the star is something Ridehalgh will never forget. “Its 4:30 in the morning, I’m exhausted but, this is my moment. I walk into the room and I turn to my left and I see her and she says hey your Nichole right?Aand in that moment my whole world was made. Without me mentioning Canada at all, she said have a safe flight back to Canada” Swift even shared secret details about her personal life with fans. Isabella Rose is also on a first name basis with Swift. She posted on social media saying “I have loved her for nine years and I will never stop talking about how much I love her but I would not be where I am today without her.” Tonight is the release of Swift’s newest album, Lover. Ridehalgh and Rose were two of 113 fans in the world, that have already heard it. “She was lip syncing and dancing. She was just having a blast.” And that night is a night these young women will replay over and over again. Local News Hamilton News Home Page News Story Mix up at Hamilton lab resulted in 14 people given incorrect COVID-19 test results By News Staff - September 30, 2021, 4:17 pm A processing error at Hamilton Regional Laboratory Medicine Program resulted in 14 people receiving incorrect COVID-19 test results. Two of the false-positive tests played a role in outbreaks being declared at two Hamilton schools, Lisgar Elementary school and Bishop Ryan Catholic Secondary school. Hamilton public health has since rescinded the outbreaks. Seven other people who were told they did not have the virus actually did. All individuals who received incorrect test results have been contacted. In January the lab made a similar mistake with 31 people getting the wrong results. The Ontario Life Saving Society says not wearing a life jacket was a factor in 88% of boat-related deaths. Alcohol played a part in 40% of boat-related deaths. There were 50 search and rescue calls in the Niagara Region in the year 2020. There have been 33 calls in 2021 so far. Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility - CHCH News Canada & The World Canada News Evening News Home Page News Story Local News Halton Hamilton Ontario News World News WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Search 19.5 C Hamilton Saturday, October 9, 2021 Personalities Contact Us Watch CHCH Live Now! CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Ontario News Cinemas, theatres, spectator sports venues open at full capacity Saturday Ontario News Ontario reports 654 new COVID-19 cases Saturday Local News 541 Eatery will remain take out only in order to continue… Hamilton Music lovers, Supercrawl is finally here WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility Local News Halton Hamilton News Home Page News Story Ontario News Top News Story Ontario expands COVID vaccine eligibility By Sylvie Lendvay - May 10, 2021, 11:08 am The province says the eligibility to receive a COVID-19 vaccine will expand the week of May 10th to include people with “at-risk” health conditions, people who cannot work from home (Group 2), and people 40 and older. Starting Tuesday May 11 at 8 a.m, people with “at-risk” health conditions such as immune deficiencies, cancer, diabetes, and asthma will be able to book an appointment either through the provincial portal or their region’s website. Also Tuesday morning, people in Group 2 who cannot work from home including those who work in essential retail, courts and banks can book. Social workers, veterinarians and miners are also apart of the list that can be found here. Thursday May 13 at 8 a.m, people turning 40 in 2021 and older in non-hot spot communities can book a vaccine appointment at a mass immunization clinic. Halton Region has expanded its’ vaccination program to allow residents 16 and older who cannot work from home to book an appointment through the regions online portal. Halton residents 50 and older living in non-hot spot communities can also book. Wednesday May 12 eligibility opens to those 40 and older, Friday May 14 to those 30 and older, and by next week all Halton adults over the age of 16 will be eligible to book an appointment. Halton residents 16+ who cannot work from home can now book a COVID vaccine appointment… as well as anyone 50+. May 12 – 40+. May 14 – 30+. May 19 – 16+. They are following provincial criteria for expanding program based on risk… have enough supply to do it early. @CHCHNews pic.twitter.com/VYwEmaGKLO — Sylvie Lendvay (@sylvie_lendvay) May 10, 2021 Halton region says they are following provincial criteria for expanding eligibility based on who is most at risk, but they have enough supply to do it early. There are several pilot clinics across the province vaccinating residents 18 and older. Four pharmacies in Hamilton are approved to administer Moderna. Each location will receive about 150 shots a week. Adults 40 and older can still book an AstraZeneca vaccine at a participating pharmacy. All booking availability will depend on supply. Local News UPDATE: Hamilton police arrest one person in connection with Mount Hope… WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton Halton Police are trying to prevent bicycle theft Local News Halton News Halton Police are trying to prevent bicycle theft By Sylvie Lendvay - April 19, 2021, 9:27 am Police Services across Ontario are trying to get ahead of bike thefts. Constable Frank Trasmundi with Halton Police says sometimes when people report their bicycle stolen, the owner won’t have the serial number. If that’s the case, police can’t return it or lay charges. He says downloading the app ‘529 Garage’ can help people file a report. “We will have picture of your bike, the serial number, and any distinguishing features so it will be easier for us to recover it if we find it.” says Trasmundi. Halton Police recovers 200 bikes per year on average. Only about 10-15 of them are returned. CHCH News AllCanada & The WorldCanada NewsEvening NewsHome Page News StoryLocal NewsHaltonHamiltonOntario NewsWorld News Ontario News Cinemas, theatres, spectator sports venues open at full capacity Saturday Ontario News Ontario reports 654 new COVID-19 cases Saturday Local News 541 Eatery will remain take out only in order to continue… Hamilton Music lovers, Supercrawl is finally here WATCH NOW Weather Traffic Shows Shows Dateline Shows ER Shows Your Home Your Vote Shows Evening News Shows 20/20 SEE ALL SHOWS Morning Live Schedule SHOP LOCAL Chching Home Local News Halton If you don’t live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor Local News Halton Main News Story News If you don’t live with someone, assume they have COVID: Burlington Mayor By Sylvie Lendvay - December 9, 2020, 10:11 am With cases on the rise in Halton Region, Burlington’s Mayor Marianne Meed Ward residents should be concerned. “The simplest message I could give to residents is this: If you don’t live with somebody, assume that they have COVID and conduct yourself accordingly.” Even with the temptation to gather this holiday season, she is urging residents to follow public health guidelines. “Our [Burlington] numbers are going up again, a little bit. There’s been a lot of talk about a vaccine coming; we know we’re getting that but that’s not the silver bullet. That’s not the only solution. We are going to continue, for at least a year, to need to be keeping physical distance, hand washing, wearing a mask when out in public. Those measures are going to be critically important throughout 2021.” Halton reported 92 new cases of COVID-19 Tuesday. St. Anne Catholic Elementary school in Burlington has had to close down one classroom after 4 cases were reported Tuesday night. There are currently active 14 outbreaks in Halton region. The region’s Medical Officer of Health says the region continues to see community transmission. She is asking residents to avoid carpooling, and having coffee and play dates. Local News Halton News Is Halton heading back to a modified Stage 2? By Laura Brody - October 23, 2020, 8:52 pm Premier Doug Ford is concerned about Halton region’s rising case numbers and says a decision will be made by Monday whether or not to send the region back to modified Stage 2. Halton region is approaching 2,000 total COVID-19 cases; half of which have been recorded in the last two months. “We’re going to have to discuss that over the weekend and we’ll have that answer on Monday. But folks in Halton, I know they’re doing a great job. It’s concerning right now. I’ve seen the numbers go up.” said Premier Doug Ford. “The premier has been terrific to work with throughout this. We recorded 16 new cases today. That’s like 1 in 35,000 people here. I think curves on small numbers are very unreliable ways to judge the future.” said Oakville Mayor Rob Burton. Oakville has already restricted indoor group fitness classes and team sports. The modified Stage 2 would prohibit indoor dining, and close gyms, fitness centres, cinemas and performance venues. It was a reminder to keep shoulders and stomachs covered – in accordance with the school’s dress code policy. But just two days ago, police announced they were investigating reports of sexual assault and harassment at the school and the timing of today’s announcement left some female students feeling as though they were being blamed. Matt Ingram reports.
